properties.Spill_Desc: Soil impacts were discovered during removal of the separator and associated flow lines.
properties.Root Cause: Unknown

properties.Spill_Desc: PDC discovered a reportable historical spill at the Schneider 1 and 22-21 facility while removing production lines during battery abandonment. Current recovery efforts are mitigating impacts.
properties.Root Cause: On January 8, 2018, historic petroleum hydrocarbon impacts were discovered during plug and abandonment activities.
properties.Preventative Measure: The facility was decommissioned and will not be replaced.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: While deconstructing the Weichel 26N-11HZ tank battery facility, petroleum hydrocarbon impacted soil was encountered within the subsurface lined containment. The volume of the release is unknown. The petroleum hydrocarbon impacted soil is being excavated. Based on the volume of impacted soil excavated, the release was reported to the COGCC on March 9, 2018. The excavation details and analytical results will be summarized in a supplemental report. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: While deconstructing the Weichel 26N-11HZ tank battery facility, historical petroleum hydrocarbon impacts were encountered within the subsurface lined containment. The volume of the release is unknown.
properties.Preventative Measure: The excavated portion of the Kerr-McGee tank battery has been deconstructed and the site will be restored to its pre-release grade. One oil tank and one partially-buried produced water sump located south of the excavated area will remain at the site.

properties.Spill_Desc: During decommisioning of facilitiy soil impacts were discoverd along produced water dump lines.
properties.Root Cause: Historical impacts were discovered during dismantlement of the tank battery.
properties.Preventative Measure: The site was dismantled and reclamation has occurred.  Noble Energy conducts routine draw down tests of produced water vessels and AVOL inspections of facilities and well heads.

properties.Spill_Desc: During reclamation activities historical impacts were discovered at the Berg 1 location where the produced water and oil dumplines were located.  An environmental site assessment has been scheduled.
properties.Root Cause: During reclamation of the oil and gas facility historical impacts were discovered near the produced water vessel and oil and produced water dumplines.
properties.Preventative Measure: The location was plugged and abandoned and excavation of impacted soil above COGCC was completed.  Noble follows COGCC Rule 1100 pertaining to flowline tests and conducts routine draw down tests of produced water vessels to ensure integrity.

properties.Spill_Desc: Following an asset acquisition in 2017, Extraction completed a review of equipment condition associated with well pad "Pard Inc. 3" (Location ID: 320059), and tank battery "Pard 3 Tank Battery" (Location ID: 444456). A pressure test in the flowline between the wellhead and tank battery failed. In order to identify potential impacts, limited excavation along the flowline, and in-situ characterization with a direct-push rig were conducted and confirmed impacts. This form is being submitted to document and manage the recently identified historical impacts associated with the flowline.
properties.Root Cause: While removing the flowline, soil impacts were observed in the sidewalls and base of the excavation. It appeared that identified historical impacts resulted from unaddressed corosion and pipeline integrity issues. Site investigation results, including lab data, are provided as attachments in this supplemental report.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed flowline, which initiated this project, has been removed and abandoned. The site will be final reclaimed.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: Historical impacts were discovered during flowline abandonment activities at the Duane E. Nelson 41-33 (2-68) #1-X wellhead. The release became State reportable on March 27, 2018, due to the quantity of impacted soil excavated. Soil excavation activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: Historical impacts were discovered during flowline abandonment activities.
properties.Preventative Measure: Site infrastructure has been removed and will not be replaced.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: While excavating a flowline at the PC Gas Unit #1-26 facility, historical petroleum hydrocarbon impacts were encountered. The volume of the release is unknown. The petroleum hydrocarbon impacted soil was excavated. Groundwater was encountered in the excavation at approximately 4 feet below ground surface. On March 26, 2018, groundwater sample GW01 was collected from the excavation and submitted for BTEX analysis. Laboratory analytical results indicated sample GW01 exceeded the COGCC Table 910-1 allowable levels for benzene at a concentration of 42.4 µg/L. The excavation details and analytical results will be summarized in the supplemental report. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1. The soil and groundwater sample analytical results are summarized in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. The analytical report is attached.
properties.Root Cause: While excavating a flowline at the PC Gas Unit #1-26 facility, historical petroleum hydrocarbon impacts were encountered. The volume of the release is unknown.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline was replaced and cathodic protection was installed. The site will be restored to its pre-release grade.

properties.Spill_Desc: Historical impacts were discovered associated with the Herbster PMF 26-15 flowline while another operator was treching in flowlines from a new oil and gas pad.  An environmental assessment was completed and remediation will be scheduled.
properties.Root Cause: While another operator was trenching in flowlines, historical impacts were discovered where the Herbster PMF 26-15 flowline was previously located.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline was removed during the plugging and abandonment process.  Noble pressure tests flowlines per COGCC 1100 series rules.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: During plugging and abandonment activities at the HSR-Wheeler 8-30 facility, soil with historical petroleum hydrocarbon impacts were encountered while removing the flowline. The volume of the release in unknown. Groundwater was encountered in the excavation at approximately 6 feet below ground surface. On June 15, 2018, groundwater sample GW01 was collected from the excavation and submitted for BTEX analysis. Laboratory analytical results indicated sample GW01 exceeded the COGCC Table 910-1 allowable level for benzene at a concentration of 45.0 µg/L. The complete assessment details and analytical results will be summarized in a supplemental report. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1. The excavation soil and groundwater sample analytical results are summarized in Table 1 and Table 2, respectively. The laboratory analytical reports are attached. Excavation activities are ongoing.
properties.Root Cause: During plugging and abandonment activities at the HSR-Wheeler 8-30 facility, historical petroleum hydrocarbon impacts were encountered while removing the flowline. The volume of the release in unknown.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline was permanently removed and the excavation will be restored to its pre-release grade.

properties.Spill_Desc: Water was observed in ROW during pipeline inspection  Water transfer line was isolated and will remain out of service until repair.
properties.Root Cause: External corrosion. Post-failure analysis confirmed the coating was damaged.
properties.Preventative Measure: A hydro-tested joint of pipe was used for repair. The repair welds at each end of the section of pipe used for replacement were x-rayed to ensure integrity and the pipeline was leak-checked at normal operating pressure successfully.

properties.Spill_Desc: During production the seal on the oil transfer line malfunctioned releasing 3bbls of oil inside containment.  The liner, within containment, that prevents liquid from reaching the ground surface malfunctioned releasing 1bbl of the released oil to the ground surface, beneath the tanks.  The other 2bbls of oil have been recovered.  The tanks will be removed and remediation will be scheduled.
properties.Root Cause: The seal on an oil transfer pump failed during production which was attributed to a manufacturer defect.  The liner was also installed incorrectly resulting in the oil reaching the ground surface beneath the production equipment.
properties.Preventative Measure: A pipe flange running into the oil transfer pump had its bolts loose resulting in the oil release.  A new gasket was installed and the bolts were tightened.  The liner was also replaced per the manufacturers specifications.
properties.Detailed Root Cause Type: Fatigue of gasket and/or mechancal failure

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: Overnight, the heater treater on location went down due to low pressure and was shut in, when the fluids/pressure equalized the dump lines were reopened. A bad check valve allowed fluid to back flow through an offline compressor and fill the blow down and stack. When the compressor was blown down it released a currently unknown volume of condensate to the ground outside containment. The release was contained to the location. Emergency locates were called in and remediation is underway.
properties.Root Cause: A bad check valve on an offline compressor allowed fluid to back flow through the compressor and into the blow down stack. When the compressor was brought back online and blown down it released approximately 25 bbls of condensate from the stack and on to the ground.
properties.Preventative Measure: The compression team was coached on routine preventative maintenance procedures. A clean out was added to the vent stack to allow it to be drained in the event of another valve failure.

properties.Spill_Desc: During maintenance activities an unintentional release was discovered at the Bacon 3 flowline.  Excavation of impacts are currently underway.
properties.Root Cause: During maintenance activities an external hole was discovered on the flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: Approximately 20 feet of flowline was removed and replaced with schedule 80 pipe.  The line was flushed and abandoned per COGCC Rule 1100 series rules.  The well head will be scheduled to be plugged and abandoned.  Noble pressure tests all flowlines per COGCC Rule 1100 and conducts routine AVO inspections of locations.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A produced water dumpline failed and released approximately 137 bbls of produced water to the subsurface. 3 bbls of produced water were released to the surface, but remained on location. Emergency locates were called in and remediation and repairs are underway.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion caused the dumpline to fail
properties.Preventative Measure: Chemical treatment and grounding procedures are being used to prevent line failure

properties.Spill_Desc: Approximately 4 bbls of produced water was discovered on a produced water transfer pipeline near the Horsetail 08D facility. The cause of the release is currently under investigation. The pipeline was shut in, isolated, and the free liquids recovered. The line will be excavated and repaired. The section of line removed will be sent to a third party inspection company for analysis. Impacted soils will be mechanically removed and disposed.
properties.Root Cause:
The 4 inch carbon steel line failed due to internal corrosion.  

The spill occurred on a buried produced water pipeline on the southwest corner of the Horsetail 08D pad.  The overburden soils were excavated and the impacted soil staged on-site pending disposal.  Approximately 70 feet of the pipe was removed.  Intial field observations indicate that the cause was due to internal corrosion.  A section of the removed pipe will be sent to a metals laboratory for analysis.
properties.Preventative Measure:
We installed a 3.75 inch internal diameter Polyflow Thermalflex pull through liner from the water skid to the flex steel corridor.  The Polyflow liner couples to the stainless steel fittings in order to reduce the potential for corrosion.  In addition, the Polyflow liner is constructed of a multi-layer polymer for chemical resistance, low permeation, and temperature resistance.  

Whiting is currently evaluating options to prevent pipeline leaks from internal corrision.  This may include, but is not limited to, pipeline removal and replacement or lining of existing pipeline.

properties.Spill_Desc: A dump line failed between the separator and tank battery. The dump line was isolated and free-standing fluids were recovered by a vac truck. A subsurface investigation is underway.
properties.Root Cause: Per Brett Middleton, Baker Hughes determined Microbial Induced Corrosion as the root cause analysis.
properties.Preventative Measure: All piping removed from tanks to separators and chemical program has been revamped.

properties.Spill_Desc: At the Critter Creek 11-62-15 SWSE on 7/12/18 at 15:07 hrs.  The oil hauler was pushing oil back into the tank and failed to close the load line valve before he disconnected his hose.  Before the line was controlled, 1 bbl or oil in containment and 1bbl of oil out of containment was spilled.
properties.Root Cause: An oil hauler failed to close the load line valve before disconnecting the hose.
properties.Preventative Measure: The oil hauler was refreshed on proper loading procedures.

properties.Spill_Desc: During abandonment procedures at the Rehmer 1 flowline an unintentional release was discovered.  A site assessment was completed to determine the extent of impacted media.  Remediation will be scheduled.
properties.Root Cause: During plugging and abandonment procedures an unintentional release was discovered on the flowline runnning from the oil and gas well to the separators.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline will be abandoned per COGCC 1100 series rules.  Noble Energy conducts flowline pressure tests to determine integrity.

properties.Spill_Desc: Estimate 35 bbls.  Soil damage on facility property.  Estimates based flowrates, water removed by truck, and the volume of water contained within that pipeline.  The spill has been contained, cleanup is in progress, and repairs were made to the line. A 6” PVC pipe joint failed during a routine water transfer from system tanks to clean tanks.  On this facility, the clean tank is in a different berm system than the system tanks.  It is transferred using a 220 foot line.  The line broke near the upstream berm, but out of containment.  An employee immediately recognized the problem and, within one minute, isolated the spill. Employees further prevented the spill from extending to the adjacent cornfield using diking and other means of containment.  A pre-existing ditch, installed by NGL, also prevented exposure to this property.  Water did, however, travel the length of the ditch, but did not threaten other waters or property. NGL has begun remediation.  LTE will for soil contamination once
properties.Root Cause: A 6" PVC pipe join failed during a routine water trasnfer from systems tanks to clean tanks, under normal operating conditions.
properties.Preventative Measure: Consistent and routine visual and operational inspections on the all joints and piping within the facility.  Continue the constant inspections in order to catch this quickly, as we did, and continue making sure the containment is in place and functioning properly.

properties.Spill_Desc: At about 2:15 AM night operators discoverd a leak about 100' SW of collection station 10.  Additional operators and clean up crews were called in, and the station was shut in.  Approximately 37 Barrels of fluid were released containing 2.6% oil cut (0.95BBL of oil).    Approximatley 33BBLs of fluid were initally recoverd, and the area was water washed at daylight.
properties.Root Cause: Fiberglass leak, repaired with a Fiberglass Wrap and tested.
properties.Preventative Measure: repaired with a Fiberglass Wrap and tested.

properties.Spill_Desc: During maintenance activities a flowline release was discovered.  Excavation is currently underway.
properties.Root Cause: During maintenance activities to uncover the flowline at the Cydney White D33-1 location internal corrosive holes were discovered attributing to the unintentional release.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline will be cut, capped, and abandoned per COGCC 1100 Rules.  The oil and gas well will be scheduled for plugging and abandonment.  Noble Energy pressure tests all flowlines to ensure integrity.

properties.Spill_Desc: Approximately 3 bbls of produced water was discovered on a produced water transfer pipeline near the Horsetail 08D facility during cleanup of a previous release on the same line. Spill/Release Point ID: 456078. The cause of the release is currently under investigation. Impacted soils will be mechanically removed and disposed.
properties.Root Cause:
The 4 inch carbon steel line failed due to internal corrosion.

The release occured on a buried produced water pipeline on the west side of the Horsetail 08D pad. The impacted soils were excavated and stockpiled on a liner for offsite disposal. Initial observations indicate that the leak was caused due to internal corrosion. A section of the pipe will be sent to a metal lab for analysis.
properties.Preventative Measure:
We intalled a 3.75 inch internal diameter Polyflow Thermaflex pull through liner from the water skid to the flex steel corridor.  The Polyflow liner couples to the stainless steel fittings in order to reduce the potential for corrosion.  In addition, the Polyflow liner is constructed of a multi-layer polymer for chemical resistance, low permeation, and temperature resistance.  

This line has been shut in and Whiting is looking for ways to prevent internal corrosion.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: At approximately 1:30 am on 7/26/18, a truck driver struck a Bonanza Creek wellhead that was behind a barrier.  The truck severed a wellhead flowline that released pressure and completions water related to nearby completions activity.  The incident was reported immediately and Bonanza Creek personnel responded to the location and shut-in the well head.  Bonanza Creek personnel are currently on location with a vac truck removing all pooled completions water and assessing the released volume and surface impact.  The release was contained to the well pad.
properties.Root Cause: A BCEOC contractor hauling frac sand ran over a wellhead while turning around on location.
properties.Preventative Measure: BCEOC has implemented multiple policies including light plants for night time truck staging, a traffic analysis prior to completions to ensure proper room is available.

properties.Spill_Desc: While excavating dump lines to decommission a site, historical suspected soil impacts were observed. Vertical and horizontal definition is being pursued with conventional excavation, and clearance samples will be collected from the bottom and sidewalls of the excavation.
properties.Root Cause: While excavating dump lines to decomission a site, historical soil impacts were observed on the base of the excavation.  Based on the apparent source and extent of the soil impacts, it appears that the soil impacts are historic, and likely resulted from a previous piece of equipment or activity causing a discharge which was not recognized or addressed.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed dump lines, which initiated this project, have been removed to decomission the site.

properties.Spill_Desc: Approximately 150 barrels of produced water was released within lined seconary containment. The release occured at approximately 8:30 p.m. on August 1, 2018. Cleanup was initiated and is expected to be completed on the afternoon of 8/2/2018. Great Western personnel made notifications.
properties.Root Cause: Cause was human error.
properties.Preventative Measure: Additional training will be conducted to prevent recurrence of the problem.

properties.Spill_Desc: Approximately 150 barrels of produced water was released within lined seconary containment. The release occured at approximately 8:30 p.m. on August 1, 2018. Cleanup was initiated and is expected to be completed on the afternoon of 8/2/2018. Great Western personnel made notifications.
At 9:19 am operators discovred a leak on the injection line just past Fee 87.  The line was immediately shut in and vac trucks were called to collect all free floating liquids.
properties.Root Cause: Steel Corvel Coating Internal Corrosion Failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: Replaced with Stainless Steel.

properties.Spill_Desc: During pressure testing it was discovered that the oil dumpline running from the separators to the oil tanks did not hold pressure.  The location was immediately shut in and the line was uncovered.  The unintentional release developed at a threaded union.  Excavation is currently underway.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause for the unintentional release was a cross threaded pipe that was not fastened properly.
properties.Preventative Measure: The line was replaced with schedule 80 pipe and anodes were attached to direct electricity off the pipe.

properties.Spill_Desc: Fitting on 1-inch dump line washed out inside the separator resulting in the release of approximately 7 bbls of produced water.  The water ran outside of the separator unit and accumulated in a low-spot immediately behind the separator.  Immediately upon discovery of the spill, the dump line was shut down and the defective fitting was replaced.  Crews are excavating the impacted soils now, and excavated materials will be temporarily land-farmed on site inside a bermed containment structure.  After all impacted soils have been excavated, the excavation and the spoil materials will be sampled to ensure that COGCC 910-1 cleanup standards have been met.
properties.Root Cause: Fitting on 1-inch dump line washed out inside the separator, allowing 7bbls of produced water to run out of the separator unit and pool in a low spot behind the separator unit. PetroFlag readings of impacted soils ranged from 46 ppm to 110 ppm -- well below the 500 ppm threshold for TPH.  Soils from the impacted area were excavated and stockpiled on TEP surface pending results of analytical data.  Excavation around separators will be backfilled with clean soils and road base materials.
properties.Preventative Measure: Continue routine equipment inspections and maintenance

properties.Spill_Desc: A gas leak was identified and the wells associated with the header were shut in and the lines flushed. After a few hours, fluid started to surface. Once the fluid was removed and the contaminated soil removed, a historical leak was uncovered. It is unknown what the source of the historical leak is. The header has been disassembled until all contaminated soil is removed. Flowlines will be pressure tested once the header is back in service.
Produced water release from underground water line.  Source will be excavated.
properties.Root Cause: External corrosion of steel water line isolated by fiberglass conncetion
properties.Preventative Measure: Anodes were installed and connected to the steel during the repair.

properties.Spill_Desc: A 3" corvelle coated spool released 15.71 bbl of injection (produced) water, and 0 bbl of oil to land.  The well was shut in upon discovery, and the area was water washed.  Soil samples below pipe will be taken prior to backfilling.
properties.Root Cause: Steel Corvel Coating Internal Corrosion Failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: Replaced with Stainless Steel.

properties.Spill_Desc: A block valve was inadvertently closed, causing the pipeline to the pit to overpressure and rupture.  The well was taken out of service until repairs are made.  The water was not contained and zero barrels were recovered.  It did not reach waters of the state.
properties.Root Cause: A Timber Creek Employee inadvertently closed a block valve at the pit causing the line to overpressure and rupture half way between the wellhead and pit.
properties.Preventative Measure: Operators will be instructed on the correct procedure for valve locations and workings.  If they are unsure, call their supervisor for clarification.

properties.Spill_Desc: During a routine visit to the location, the lease operator noticed fluid coming out of the ground near the separator units.  The line that failed was isolated and emergency response operations initiated immediately.
properties.Root Cause: During a routine visit to the location, the lease operator noticed fluid coming out of the ground near the separator units. The line that failed was a dumpline. It was isolated and emergency response operations initiated immediately. All impacted material was removed followed by the collection of confirmation soil samples from the four walls and base. As stated in the "Spill/Release Detail Report" tab on the previous Supplemental Form 19 (COGCC Document ID 401756539), no fluids were recovered during the initial spill response. The primary failure mechanism or "root cause" was determined to be Microbial Influenced Corrosion (MIC) as seen in the previous dump line failure (Spill/Release Point ID 456039) on this location. Attached to this Supplemental Form 19 is the Dump Line Corrosion Analysis performed on the above mentioned failed section of pipe conducted by Baker Hughes on 8/9/2018. Given the fact that both dump line failures occurred on the same location with similar fluids being conveyed through them, it is reasonable to conclude MIC as the root cause of failure for this dump line.
properties.Preventative Measure: To prevent MIC reoccurrence on this flowline and other flowlines associated with this location, a biocide program is being incorporated into the producing wells and surface equipment as recommended by Baker Hughes.

properties.Spill_Desc: During production a surface release was discovered at the Trebor B11-66,67,68,69-1HN produced water dumpline running from the separators to the produced water tanks.  Excavation of impacts in currently underway.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion formed on the produced water dumpline causing the unintentional release.
properties.Preventative Measure: The internal corrosive hole was at the 6 o'clock position and was repaired with 2 feet of 2 inch schedule 80 steel pipe, 2 inch schedule 80 collar, and 2' 2000 pound hammer union.  The pressure test was at 400psi for 45 minutes and passed prior to bringing it back on line for production.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: During plugging and abandonment activities at the UPRR 43 Pan Am Y #2 facility, soil with historical petroleum hydrocarbon impacts were encountered at the tank battery while excavating around the dump lines. The volume of the release in unknown. Based on the volume of impacted soil excavated, the release was reported to the COGCC on September 7, 2018. The assessment details and analytical results will be summarized in the supplemental report. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: During plugging and abandonment activities at the UPRR 43 Pan Am Y #2 facility, soil with historical petroleum hydrocarbon impacts were encountered at the tank battery while excavating around the dump lines. The volume of the release in unknown.
properties.Preventative Measure: The facility is being deconstructed. The excavation will be restored to its pre-release grade.

properties.Spill_Desc: The three inch flowline from the Fed Osprey well, at approximately 5' below ground surface, corroded and released fluids to surface.  COGCC Inspector Bret Evins discovered the release and notified Foundation personnel.  A vac truck was brought to location late in the afternoon of 9/7 and removed between 1/4 and 1/2 bbl of standing fluid.  On 9/11/18, after emergency locates cleared, Foundation exposed the flowline to find the hole and make repairs.  At that time, soil was screened from the excavation with a PID and confirmation samples collected for overnight analysis at Summit Scientific for GBTEX and DRO.  Samples results were returned early on 9/12/18.  Toluene was detected in the samples collected from the excavation base and the north sidewall, but was below the Table 910-1 standard.  Foundation plans to haul impacted soils (~5 yds) to the Waste Management Ault facility.  Once the soil is disposed of, Foundation will request closure with associated documentation.
properties.Root Cause: A pinhole leak developed on the flowline between the well and treater.  The pinhole was caused by internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The 3" steel line which had corroded was replaced with a new 2" poly line in order to prevent reoccurrence.

properties.Spill_Desc: The leak occured while transferring water with a transfer pump that was connected to the main water line system. The hoses were connected using a camlock fitting. One of the ears on the fitting worked loose causing the hose to leak at that point. The operator was on site and immediately shut down the pump. The leak consisited of a small puddle approximately 2.5 BBls of produced water outside of the tank containment. The water was vacuumed up using a water truck that was dispatched from H&K trucking. There were no visable signs of hydrocarbons present.
properties.Root Cause:
The leak occurred while transferring water with a transfer pump that was connected to the main water line system. The hoses were connected using a camlock fitting. One of the ears on the fitting worked loose causing the hose to leak at that point. The operator was on site and immediately shut down the pump. The leak consisted of a small puddle approximately 2 bbls of produced water outside of the tank containment. The water was vacuumed up using a water truck that was dispatched from H&K trucking. There were no visible signs of hydrocarbons present. See attached letter for additional details. 

The leak occured while transferring water with a transfer pump that was connected to the main water line system. The hoses were connected using a camlock fitting. One of the ears on the fitting worked loose causing the hose to leak at that point. The operator was on site and immediately shut down the pump.
properties.Preventative Measure:
Discussions have occurred with our water pump operators regarding their operations and the use of hose fittings. They have been instructed that cam-lock fittings are to be pinned at all times when hoses are in operation.

Discussions have occurred with our water pump operators regarding their operations and the use of hose fittings.  They have been instructed that cam-lock fittings are to be pinned at all times when hoses are in operation.

properties.Spill_Desc: While excavating dump lines to decommission a site, historical suspected soil impacts were observed. Vertical and horizontal definition is being pursued with conventional excavation, and clearance samples will be collected from the bottom and sidewalls of the excavation.
properties.Root Cause: While excavating dump lines to decommission a site, historical soil impacts were observed on the sidewalls of the excavation. Based on the apparent source and extent of the soil impacts, it appears that the soil impacts are historic, and likely resulted from a previous piece of equipment or activity causing a discharge which was not recognized or addressed.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed dump lines, which initiated this project, will be removed to decommission the site.

properties.Spill_Desc: Approximately 5 bbls of produced water and 3 bbls of crude oil was released at the Razor 25 CPB facility due to a hole in the fire tube.  The released was confined within the lined containment and a vacuum truck was utilized to remove the free liquids.  The pea gravel will be removed and properly disposed.  Upon removal of the pea gravel the liner will be inspected for integrity.
properties.Root Cause: Inspection of the treater identified that the fire tube failed due to scale buildup causing an insulating effect which caused the steel to weaken.
properties.Preventative Measure: To prevent future issues we will be applying chemical to the treater to inhibit scale buildup.

properties.Spill_Desc: Approximately 5 bbls of produced water and 3 bbls of crude oil was released at the Razor 25 CPB facility due to a hole in the fire tube.  The released was confined within the lined containment and a vacuum truck was utilized to remove the free liquids.  The pea gravel will be removed and properly disposed.  Upon removal of the pea gravel the liner will be inspected for integrity.
properties.Root Cause: Inspection of the treater identified that the fire tube failed due to scale buildup causing an insulating effect which caused the steel to weaken.
properties.Preventative Measure: To prevent future issues we will be applying chemical to the treater to inhibit scale buildup.

properties.Spill_Desc: Puncture, trinagular shape was detected along produced water line. Release of fluids on the well pad and into a Storm Water catch basin. No release to sensitive areas or waters of the state. No information yet available as to the cause.
properties.Root Cause: Excavator tooth pulled top off of pipe sometime in the past without notifying operator.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 09/14/18 at 13:10 a flowline leak was discovered, shut-in and isolated.  The flowline is from the Loudder 14-7 #2 well to the Loudder tank battery.  The leak was discovered by the pumper.  The well was shut in and the extent of the release was walked by the pumper.  The release was contained by creating a soil berm at the low end of the release.  A vac truck was on site within ~15 minutes and began removing liquid.  A clean-up crew was dispatched to help the vac truck remove the liquid.  145 bbl of liquid was recovered from the surface consisting of ~3 bbl oil and ~142 bbl water (see attached picture of wellhead sample from 9/13/18 showing 2% oil cut).  The clean-up crew prepared the oil stained soil for removal.  Eagle Enviromental was dispatched to take a soil sample and a water sample from a small pond in a low spot in the field located ~140' past the end of the release.  The oil stained soil will be removed on 9/17/18 by M&M Excavation and hauled to disposal at Waste Management.
properties.Root Cause: External corrosion of 2" steel flowline.  The size of the hole was smaller than a dime.  A murphy gauge was being used on the flowline set to shut down at + or - 15 psi.  The leak was so small it did not create greater than 15 psi drop in flowline pressure.  It is believed that the flowline was laid in 1960.  Material is 2" thin wall steel with no external coating.
properties.Preventative Measure: Flowline is being replaced with 2-3/8" thick wall steel flowline that is wrapped.

properties.Spill_Desc: Subsequent to flowline pressure testing fluids appear to have migrated back from the Debeque area to this pad. A low pressure release of fluid occured from an abandoned line on the pad and from a cut in a line near the edge of the pad. The leak from the cut line was previously reported on document 401764160. Onsite meeting with COGCC and BLM on sept 20 determined that the spills at this location should be addressed via submission of separate Form 19s. Vertical and horizontal deliniation of this spill will begin on Sept 20, 2018. Deliniation of spill 457384 will also begin on Sept 20, 2018.
properties.Root Cause: Failure by previous Operator to abandon “frac” line appropriately or to identify the damage to the pipe and repair or replace and to supply complete records to new Operator.
properties.Preventative Measure: Personnel will inspect all lines in the area to insure no unidentified lines are plumbed in the system without capability of isolation. Lines will be isolated and or removed from the system.

properties.Spill_Desc: This newly generated Initial Form 19 is intened to correct Lat/Long errors and correct County ID. Spill flowed from puncture, trinagular shape was detected along produced water line.  Fluid from puncture traveled thru culvert and into a Storm Water catch basin. No release to sensitive areas or waters of the state. No information yet available as to the cause. The simultaneous release of fluids on the well pad from an abandoned (cut-off) line has been assigned to a different Form 19 (Doc Num 401768884).
properties.Root Cause: Failure by previous Operator to abandon “frac” line appropriately or to identify the damage to the pipe and repair or replace and to supply complete records to new Operator.
properties.Preventative Measure: Personnel will inspect all lines in the area to insure no unidentified lines are plumbed in the system without capability of isolation. Lines will be isolated and or removed from the system.

properties.Spill_Desc: Lease operators began observing trending that indicated a leaking flowline associated with the K22 596 3C-27 well. The flowline was isolated, purged, and taken out of service. Site assessment is currently underway with impacted material being removed via hyrovac due to a high concentration of flowlines in the area.
properties.Root Cause: Lease operator began observing trending that indicated a leaking flowline associated with the K22 596 3C-27 well. The flowline was isolated, purged, and taken out of service. Corrosion was determined to be the root cause of the flowline failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: Preventative measures are currently being evaluated with Caerus operations staff. Once a conclusion has been reached, the preventative measures will be detailed in a supplemental eForm 19.

properties.Spill_Desc: While pressure testing frac lines near the PA 22-25-695 location (COGCC ID 335123), a split int the frac line occurred which resulted in the release of approximately 80 bbls of produced water.  The water flowed into a nearby dry drainage feature and traveled a distance of approximately 1/4 mile down gradient.  Upon observing the line rupture, on-site personnel immediately ceased the pressure test and cut the water supply.  An equipment operator used a loader to install two temporary check dams in the drainage below the spill to prevent water from traveling futher down the drainage.  No surface or ground water resources were impacted.  A vac-truck was used to recover approximately 20 bbls of water.  A 3rd party environmental consultant was dispatched immediately after the release to document the area impacted by the release, conduct field screening of impacted soils, and collect samples for lab analysis.  The defective frac line was removed, replaced with new line, and re-tested.
properties.Root Cause: A split in a frac line occured during pressure testing, allowing ~80  bbls of produced water to be released.  The segment of line that split was seamed pipe (versus extruded pipe).  The failure occurred along the longitudinal seam where the pipe was welded during fabrication.  Thickness testing was conducted on adjoing pipe segments and all were found to be sound.
properties.Preventative Measure: Continue to pressure test lines for potential fail points, preventing larger scale spills from occuring.   Going forward, TEP will segregate seamed pipe from extruded pipe.  Extruded pipe will only be used where we are fraccing with higher pressures and with proppant.  Seamed pipe will only be used when fraccing with lower pressures and no proppant.

properties.Spill_Desc: Fluid released from Fee 22 lateral line.  The lateral was isolated and well shut-in.  Standing fluid was picked up via vacuum truck, and clean up of impacted soils will be completed.  Soil samples (including below pipe) will be taken to show conformance.  Depth and cause of leak is still being determined, and will provide update on supplemental form.
properties.Root Cause: Steel Corvel Coating Internal Corrosion Failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: Replaced with Stainless Steel.

properties.Spill_Desc: Dump valve got stuck open when the well came on. The tank was a bottom fill and was near capacity when pressure came through. Due to the tank level condensate came out of the thief hatch. The switch shut on its own. The release was all confined to containment that has a liner. All condensate was sucked out.
properties.Root Cause: Dump valve got stuck open when the well came on. The tank was a bottom fill and was near capacity when pressure came through. Due to the tank level condensate came out of the thief hatch. The switch shut on its own. The release was all confined to containment
properties.Preventative Measure: Lease operators will monitor

properties.Spill_Desc: This spill and affected soil is seperate from the ongoing EMC remediation project.  A 1/2" schedule 80 stainless steel pipe nipple on discharge pump A failed, releasing fluid above ground (no subsurface contamination aside from the minimal soak in that occurred prior to clean up).  The entire station was shut-in, and all fluids were contained within the Chevron property boundaries and SPCC containment.  275 bbl of standing fluid was recovered via vacuum truck, and the affected soil is being removed from location.  Fault analysis on the pipe nipple is ongoing and will provide cause and future preventative measures in supplemental.
properties.Root Cause: Fatigue Failure of stainless threaded pipe nipple on discharge of pump due to vibration.  Pump vibration was fixed and nipple configuration was change/shortened.  Pump is currently out of service.
properties.Preventative Measure: Future plans for starting the pump back up will include removing all threaded nipples and installing welded connections.

properties.Spill_Desc: Dump line inside the skim tank battery failed due to corrosion of the carbon-steel pipe releasing an estimated 20 bbls of produced water inside a lined, metal secondary containment structure.  No fluids were released outside of the containment structure, and 100% of the water released inside containment was recovered using on-site pumps and equipment.  The defective line has been repaired.

Dump line inside the skim tank battery failed due to corrosion of the carbon-steel pipe releasing an estimated 20 bbls of produced water inside a lined, metal secondary containment structure.  No fluids were released outside of the containment structure, and 100% of the water released inside containment was recovered using on-site pumps and equipment.  The defective line has been repaired.
properties.Root Cause:
Dump line inside the skim tank battery failed due to corrosion of the carbon-steel pipe. Pumps on-site were used to recovere all released material 

Dump valve got stuck open when the well came on. The tank was a bottom fill and was near capacity when pressure came through. Due to the tank level condensate came out of the thief hatch. The switch shut on its own. The release was all confined to containment
properties.Preventative Measure:
equipment failure - continue routine maintenance and repair faulty equipment as needed

Lease operators will monitor

properties.Spill_Desc: Appears the water line was damaged during installation and had weakend over time and ruptured. Water line valves were closed to isolate the water and a water truck recoved 1 BBL of surface water as well as the remaining water in the isolated line. The damaged portion of pipe was removed and replaced. Water line was pressure tested after repairs were made. Soil samples have been taken and a supplimental Form 19 will submitted with results. Area was treated with 500 lbs of agricultrial grade pellets and straw will be stiched in to prevent erosion and help hold moisture

While walking the pipeline corridor, a member of our pipeline staff observed an area of ground surface subsidence.  After removing soil with a hydrovac in this area, a failed portion of a line was found.  It was immediately isolated and purged of all fluids.  Excavation of impacted soil is currently underway.
properties.Root Cause: While walking the West Fork Pipeline corridor, a member of the Caerus pipeline staff observed an area of ground surface subsidence. After removing soil with a hydrovac from the area of concern, a failed portion of pipeline was observed and immediately isolated and purged of all fluids. On October 10th, 2018, Nalco Champion performed a failure analysis on the failed portion of pipe from the West Fork 10-inch pipeline. Based on the size and shape of pitting, iron sulfide deposits, low levels of H2S, and microorganism counts, the analysis determined Microbial Influenced Corrosion (MIC) to be the primary mechanism or “root cause” of failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: As of October 17th, 2018, it is undetermined whether the WF10” pipeline will remain in use. If the pipeline is re-commissioned, Nalco Champion will continue to treat each lateral line that feeds into the WF10” pipeline with EC1317A corrosion inhibitor as well as continue use of a biocide treatment program with slug and pill treatments.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 9/29/2018, ~7:40 PM, the Conrtol Room Operator received a sump  high level alarm at the Love Ranch 8 Pond E&P facility pump building (located on the Love Ranch 8 well pad, Location ID 335717).  The lease operator responded to location and discovered the 2 inch tee off of the 4 inch pump suction line had failed resulting in a produced water release of ~10.6 Bbls.  The pump were shut down, and the line was isolated.  Impacted soils were removed, Table 910-1 confirmation sample(s) will be collected, data pending.
properties.Root Cause: On 9/29/2018, ~7:40 PM, the Conrtol Room Operator received a sump high level alarm at the Love Ranch 8 Pond E&P facility pump building (located on the Love Ranch 8 well pad, Location ID 335717). The lease operator responded to location and discovered the 2-inch tee off of the   4-inch pump suction line had failed resulting in a produced water release of ~10.6 Bbls. The pump was shut down, and the line was isolated.   Root Cause:  Equipment failure dur to possible deadhead of pump increasing temperature of fluid and piping
properties.Preventative Measure: Installed ESD on sump level alarm and low flow shutdown

properties.Spill_Desc: Laramie discovered a leak in the flowline on the referenced well 10/3/18. Laramie has excavated 5-6 yds of material and intends to dispose of it at a State Approved E&P Waste Facility (Greenleaf). Volume lost is unknown. Leak was detected by moist soil with hydrocarbon odors. No standing fluid was present. This well is a low volume, low pressure producer which had been shut-in while Laramie drilled and completed a Buzzard Creek Unit well on the BCU 13-A pad. Most likely the well built up just enough pressure to break loose a corrosion spot in the line. Fluid loss was 3-phase: Gas, Condenate, Produced water. Last daily production for the well was 20mcf/day
properties.Root Cause: No idea, the COGCC database will not bring up anything, it looks like an empty database entry.

properties.Spill_Desc: Faulty isolation valve discovered by pipeline maintenance crew while gathering information and measurements in preparation of replacing carbon steel valves in this segment of the water gathering line.  An estimated 5 bbls of water was discovered to have leaked into the can on 10/11/18.  Upon discovery of the leak, this segment of the line was immediately taken out of service thereby stopping the leak.  The defective valve will be replaced on 10/15/18, at which time soils will be field screened and sampled to determine if further cleanup will be required.
properties.Root Cause: Faulty isolation valve discovered by pipeline maintenance crew while gathering information and measurements in preparation of replacing carbon steel valves in this segment of the water gathering line. Upon discovery of the leak, this segment of the line was immediately taken out of service thereby stopping the leak.
properties.Preventative Measure: Continue routine maintenance and replace faulty equipment as needed

properties.Spill_Desc: During abandonmnet  of legacy produce water lines operated by previous Operator, Laramie personnel identified suspected contaminated soils. 3rd party environmental consultant was called out to gather samples for analysis. Sample results came back 10/15/18  high in TPH and BTEX. See attached report and photos of site.
properties.Root Cause: Root cause was a valve leak. Minor mechanical failure.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On October 12, 2018, historical impacts were discovered below the former flowline location at the Robert M Burch GU #1 site. The release became State reportable on October 15, 2018, due to the quantity of impacted soil excavated. Soil excavation activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: Historical impacts were discovered below the former flowline location at the site.
properties.Preventative Measure: Site infrastructure has been removed and will not be replaced.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A pressure relief valve (PRV) malfunctioned causing approximately 12 bbls of oil to be released. The majority of the release remained inside lined containment with a small portion (less than a barrel) misting outside containment. The misted release was contained to the well pad.
Pumper noticed gas vapor coming from ground adjacent to the access road to the Horseshoe Canyon No. 3 Well pad. Wells and line were shut-in. See photo and attached map.
properties.Root Cause: Root cause was corrosion of gas line.

properties.Spill_Desc: An unintentional release occurred along the produced water line running from the separator to the production tanks.  An environmental assessment was conducted and impacted media above COGCC Table 910-1 standards is present at the location.
properties.Root Cause: During production it was determined the produced water line at the separator did not have integrity and the line was shut in.
properties.Preventative Measure: The location will be plugged and abandoned and all flowlines will be abandoned per COGCC 1100 series rule.  Source removal will be initiated and a remediation workplan will be submitted.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK personnel was pressure testing a flowline and in the process of removing a bullplug to install the gauge, a valve in the closed position failed and caused a produced water and oil release. The bullplug was immediately stabbed back in place, the standing fluid removed with a vacuum truck and a roustabout crew was deployed to location. The contaminated soil has been hauled off to a certified disposal facility and confirmation samples have been collected and sent to the laboratory for BTEX, TPH, SAR, EC and hP analysis. A new valve was installed on top on the valve that failed.
properties.Root Cause: A valve in the closed position failed when a bullplug was removed in order to install a gauge to pressure test the valve.
properties.Preventative Measure: A new valve was installed on top of the faulty valve

properties.Spill_Desc: During production at the Kohlhoff USX AB 17-01P the produced water line developed a leak.  The location is shut in and the line has been uncovered.  Excavation of impacted soil is underway.
properties.Root Cause: Three internal corrosive holes were identified on the produced water dumpline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The current line will be removed and replaced with 75' of red thread pipe.

properties.Spill_Desc: During production the produced water line developed an unintentional release to the ground surface.  The location is shut in and repairs/remediation will be scheduled.
properties.Root Cause: The produced water line fittings in the 2" line failed due to corrosion from outside in.
properties.Preventative Measure: The fittings were replaced and a protective coating was applied to deter corrosion.

properties.Spill_Desc: A flowline leak was discovered on Monday 10/22/2018 and immediately shut-in. The release was estimated to be less than 1 barrel and less than a reportable quantity. A hydrovac truck was used to recover liquid from the surface. Following utility locates, excavation of the 4-inch diameter pipe began on Friday 10/26/2018 to remove any residual impacts and to expose the pipe to evaluate repair. During excavation, potential historic impacts were encountered which extended to a dry ditch. Olsson collected soil samples on Monday 10/29/2018 and were submitted fo Table 910-1 parameters.
properties.Root Cause: A pinhole leak, which appeared to be caused by corrosion, was discovered between the Colorado State #2 oil and gas well and the Black Hollow oil field tank battery at coordinates latitude 40.615700 and longitude -104.830620. This flowline was tested as part of the flowline testing Notice to Operators in 2017 and passed.
properties.Preventative Measure: Great Western will either abandon the flowline in place or remove it in accordance with COGCC Rule 1105.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: Historical impacts were discovered during flowline abandonment activities at the Kugel W 4-3 wellhead. The release became State reportable on October 31, 2018, due to the quantity of impacted soil excavated. Soil excavation activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: Historical impacts were discovered during flowline abandonment activities.
properties.Preventative Measure: Site infrastructure has been removed and will not be replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: A corrosive hole was discovered on the produced water line running from the separator to the tanks.  The location is shut in and excavation is underway.
properties.Root Cause: The produced water dumpline developed an internal corrosive hole which was at the 6 o'clock position.
properties.Preventative Measure: The 10 foot section was replaced with 2 inch schedule 80 steel pipe and connected with collar and hammer unions.

properties.Spill_Desc: Hot Oilers were heating treated water on the staging pad. He was steaming his lines and must have created a pressure bubble. This caused a line to blow off the 10" water line that was supplying frac. He spilled about 70 bbl. of treated water. Half in, half out of containment. A vac truck was on location to suck up all fress standing fluid. The compacted base of the staging pad that was impacted by the release will be taken to the appropriate landfill when staging location is removed.
properties.Root Cause: Hot Oilers were heating treated water on the staging pad. He was steaming his lines and must have created a pressure bubble. This caused a line to blow off the 10" water line that was supplying frac.
properties.Preventative Measure: Inspect hose connections

properties.Spill_Desc: BP notified of produced water pipeline release by landowner. Pipeline was isolated and release stopped at 10AM on 11/4/18.  Containment and recovery operations underway.
properties.Root Cause: Root Cause is unknown at this time and under investigation.
properties.Preventative Measure: A report on preventative measures and pipeline surveillance will be provided in a future report.

properties.Spill_Desc: While scraping and removing roadbase from the wellpad in preparation for site reclamation, historical suspected soil impacts were observed. Vertical and horizontal definition is being pursued with conventional excavation, and clearance samples will be collected from the bottom and sidewalls of the excavation. In accordance with the submitted Form 27 submitted for this project, collected samples will be field-screened and submitted for laboratory analysis. Please refer to the submitted Form 27, COGCC Document #: 401786956, for further details.
properties.Root Cause: While removing roadbase from the wellpad, historical soil impacts were observed south of the former tank battery underneath the roadbase. It appears that equipment failure of the marked flowline underneath the sample area caused a discharge of fluids, resulting in soil impacts; however, impacts may also have originated from tank battery equipment failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: The entire site is being decommissioned and will be reclaimed. More details will follow on an f27 submittal pending investigation.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 11/10/18 ~3:50 pm a produced water release was discovered on the YCF 1-35-1,  ~60 BBls produced water was released (14 BBLS inside lined secondary containment and ~45 outside containment) due to failure of the 3” inlet suction valve to produced water disposal pump. The tank/pipeline were isolated from pump and a water truck removed free standing fluids (~50 bbls produced water recovered).  Spill did not leave location.
properties.Root Cause: 3" inlet suction valve to produced water disposal pump failed, Root Cause:  vibration due to improper valve installation
properties.Preventative Measure: Valve will be replaced, contractors will be trained on proper valve installation

properties.Spill_Desc: Sunday afternoon, Taos 1-10 well was found to have a flowline leak inside treater house located inside containtment at tank battery. Well was shut in to stop flow, used vacuum truck to clean up free fluid on surface, pulled 5bbls of oil and water, estimate 10-15 bbls total leaked.  Cleaning up oily soil to plastic lined rolloff containers, will dispose of contaminated soil to registered disposal facility.
properties.Root Cause: The cause for this leak was corrosion/ wear in the flow line. The line was never deemed to be broken or to have came undone.
properties.Preventative Measure: For preventative maintence, we replaced the orginial steel pipe with a new poly pipe, which is a more durable line.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A produced water line running from the State Antelope J-1 to the State Antelope O-1 CPF failed at an elbow inside a valve can. The failure resulted in approximately 20 bbls of produced water/oil being released to the ground. The release location is off of the J-1 well pad but on the BCEI flowline ROW. The majority of the release was contained to the valve can. The line was shut in and a vacuum truck was dispatched immediately to drain the product from the can. Hydrovacs are on site today removing the impacted soil around the valve can. Once complete, confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis. Analytical results will be included in a supplemental F19.
properties.Root Cause: An HDPE section of the produced water line failed at the crimp between two joints.
properties.Preventative Measure: The HDPE section of the line was removed and replaced with steel schedule 80 pipe.

properties.Spill_Desc: A property developer encountered potentially impacted soils while performing a Phase II investigation in the parcel of land surrounding the tank battery associated with the Neumann 1-15 well.  A total of nine soil borings were advanced throughout the parcel.  At one of the borings adjacent to the tank battery, PID readings were elevated at approximately 7.5 feet bgs, a soil sample was submitted for BTEX/TVPH and TEPH analysis, and PVC piping was used to collect a grab water sample.  The analytical results of that soil sample have led to further investigation by 8-North to confirm the presence of and delineate the extent of the potential impacts.  The results of the grab water sample were non-detect.  Additional site investigation efforts by 8-North are on-going.  Environmental crews are working to determine the source and nature of the release.  Forthcoming laboratory analysis will determine the nature and source, which are both presently unknown.
properties.Root Cause: A property developer encountered potentially impacted soils while performing a Phase II investigation in the parcel of land surrounding the tank battery associated with the Neumann 1-15 well.  It appears that the soil impacts are historic; however, the source has not yet been confirmed.

properties.Spill_Desc: A contractor for Extraction was boring a new line under KPK's consolidation flowline (currently shut-in due to line being stung East of release) and an abandoned flowline, when they encountered a historical release via drill cuttings and tie-in access. The contractor working for Extraction is currently finishing the installation of their new pipeline and clearing enough room in order for KPK to commence removing the historically impacted soil. There are no live lines in the area and the only active line was flushed before this release was discovered.

On 11/28/18 ~9:00 AM, a produced water release was discovered on the YCF 35-12-1, ~12.5 Bbls produced water was released due to failure of the 2” steel discharge line from the produced water pump.  The tank/pipeline were isolated from pump and a water truck removed free standing fluids (~0.5 bbls produced water recovered).  Spill did not leave location.
properties.Root Cause: 2" steel discharge line from produced water disposal pump failed; Root Cause:  External Corrosion
properties.Preventative Measure: Line will be replaced and steel discharge lines from produced water disposal pumps in the Yellow Creek field will be checked for corrosion

properties.Spill_Desc: During operations a flowline release was discovered.  The line/location was shut in and excavation of impacted media is underway.
properties.Root Cause:
A split occured in the flowline resulting in the unintentional release.

The Thompson 3 location root cause (Doc # 401855313) was external corrosion.  The flowline was fixed per the supplemental Form 19 information and will be on the schedule to be P&A’d.
properties.Preventative Measure: A 15 foot section of pipe was cut out and replaced with schedule 40 steel.  The repair was made in order to flush the line for plugging and abandonment procedures.  Noble Energy pressure tests flowlines in accordance with COGCC 1100 Series Rules.

properties.Spill_Desc: Pumper arrived on scene while making his normal route and discovered that there was a 100'x60' area with 1" of water standing behind the pumping unit. Pumper shut down all of the wells that flowed into the pipeline and the leak was stopped. Using the size of the surface impacted we calculated a total of 89 bbls of produced water was released onto the surface. Roustabout crews have been called and should be on location 12/3/2018 to determine the cause of failure and repair the flowline.
properties.Root Cause: Cause of Spill: It was determined that the cause of the spill was a failure in the 3” fiberglass line where the line makes a 45 degree curve back to the facility. One side of the connection was starting to separate due to not being properly glued when originally constructed.
properties.Preventative Measure: The 45 degree section of the fiberglass pipeline was replaced with a new section and was properly glued into place. Extra measures were taken to install wooden stakes around the connection to support both ends of the pipeline and 45 degree section to help with soil expansion and contraction.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On December 1, 2018, approximately 15 barrels of produced water were released inside lined containment at the Hopper State 9N-34HZ production facility. Soil assessment activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: A release occurred inside secondary containment due to internal corrosion of a dump line located between the separators and the produced water vessel.
properties.Preventative Measure: The corroded dump line was removed and will be replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: The accumulation of fluid inside the secondary containment (around tanks) was discovered during regular pumping operations. Another pumper/vac truck was dispatched immediately to recover the released fluids. Cause of release appears to be failure of the tank due to corrosion but this is still under investigation. Volume of fluid release is estimated to be between 50 and 100 bbls. Volume of fluid recovered is not yet known but is estimated to be a minimum of 60 bbls. The majority of the fluid release was confined to the secondary containment around the tanks. 1 to 3 bls of fluid appears to have left the lined secondary containment via a hole in the liner. Laramie is in the process of gathering final details related to fluid volumes and will have a third party gather samples during a deliniation of the spill. Investigation of the liner/containment leak is ongoing.
properties.Root Cause: Point of release was determined to be a small hole in the valve that was connected to the tank. Fluid escaped from the hole and collected in the lined secondary containment. approximately 100 bbls was released and 75 bbls were recovered. A hole was discovered in the secondary containment liner that allowed fluids to escape outside the secondary containment (see attached diagram). The hole appears to have been at a weld point on the valve.
properties.Preventative Measure: Laramie will examine valves and flanges at weld points to identify potential compromises.

properties.Spill_Desc: Release of water from a water transfer line.  The produced water flowed approximately 280' from the release point.  The line was shut in and water ceased to flow; no recovery was possible due to weather conditions.
properties.Root Cause:
The leak was found to be a crack  in a 3” fiberglass produced water pipeline  approximately 5 feet inside the casing from the end of the casing.  Upon further excavation of the fiberglass pipeline on the exterior of the road bore casing it was found that the fiberglass pipe was originally installed with a bend that caused a stress within the casing.  The relative immobility of the steel casing to the fiberglass was a contributing factor to the crack in the fiberglass pipeline.

Failure of fiberglass water transfer line due to appearent damage from rocks or debris and road crossing encasement.
properties.Preventative Measure:
The fiberglass pipe was padded inside the casing during reinstallation. 

Fiberglass segment will be replaced with steel section

properties.Spill_Desc: During operations a 2 inch above ground pipe on the wellhead froze causing an unintentional release of 3bbls of a mixture of condensate, produced water, and crude oil.  The location is shut in.  Repairs and cleanup will be scheduled.
properties.Root Cause: The unintentional release was caused by a 2”bypass line at the well head that froze and broke.
properties.Preventative Measure: The 2” line was removed and ends capped. This configuration that bypassed the motor valve was not needed.

properties.Spill_Desc: Anadarko was excavating to remove an asbestos coated flowline nearby KPK's fiberglass consolidation line. During Anadarko's excavation, the contractor hit KPK's line causing a release of approximately 1/2 bbl of oil into the irrigation ditch. The ditch is currently dry and was during the incident. The standing fluid was vacuumed and the contaminated soil will be excavated and disposed of once Anadarko has cleared the location removing the line.
properties.Root Cause: Anadarko was excavating to remove an asbestos coated flowline nearby KPK's fiberglass consolidation line. During Anadarko's excavation, the contractor hit KPK's line causing a release of approximately 1/2 bbl of oil into the irrigation ditch. The ditch is currently dry and was during the incident. The standing fluid was vacuumed and the contaminated soil will be excavated and disposed of once Anadarko has cleared the location removing the line.
properties.Preventative Measure: The portion of the line to be repaired will have tracer wire installed.

properties.Spill_Desc: Soil impacts were discovered during removal of the separator and associated flow lines.

Bolts had loosened on a valve on a flowline riser.  The flowline was disconnected from the wellhead.  The flowline was put on a vacuum and the valve was changed.  A COGCC inspector arrived at the location shortly after discovery, and performed an inspection on the release.  Impacted soil at the location will be excavated.
properties.Root Cause:
Bolts had loosened on a valve on a flowline riser.  The flowline was disconnected from the wellhead.  The flowline was put on a vacuum after the incident was discovered, and the valve was changed.  It is not clear how the bolts became loosened.

As described in the initial Form 19, bolts had loosened on a 2" ball valve on a flowline riser that was disconnected from the wellhead.  The flowline was put on a vacuum by Kloberdanz Oilfield Services and changed.
properties.Preventative Measure:
The valve on the flowline riser was replaced.  The Sooner 10-28 well is scheduled for plug and abandonment in early March, 2019.  All surface equipment will be removed prior to the P&A, including the flowline riser.  

Foundation has submitted a Form 6 Intent to Plug and Abandon this well and is in the process of scheduling this work in 2019.

properties.Spill_Desc: Anadarko was excavating to remove an asbestos coated flowline nearby KPK's fiberglass consolidation line. During Anadarko's excavation, the contractor hit KPK's line causing a release of oil (<1 bbl). The flowline release coincided with an additional release 850' to the north (Spill Release Point 459955). The release was witnessed by COGCC, who observed the oil release in mist form causing contamination from the release point to the irrigation ditch west for the release point. The ditch is currently dry and was during the incident. The damaged section of flowline has been repaired and visual presence of oil pooling or staining has been removed.
properties.Root Cause: Anadarko was excavating to remove an asbestos coated flowline nearby KPK's fiberglass consolidation line. During Anadarko's excavation, the contractor hit KPK's line causing a release.
properties.Preventative Measure: The portion of flowline has been repaired and will be pressure tested before backfill.

properties.Operator Name: UTAH GAS OP LTD DBA UTAH GAS CORP
properties.Spill_Desc: During normal operations of the DCU #1 SWD well location, the lease operator discovered a release of produced water near the Salt Water Disposal well head, from an apparent failure of the flow line between the injection pump and the well head.  The line was not under pressure at the time of discovery, but was isolated to prevent further release.  Initial estimate of volume released is approximately 5 barrels, with more accurate determination to be made after flow line is excavated.  Evidence of moist soil from the release extended from the well area on the working surface, and into stormwater diversion and containment.  No release was made off pad location.
properties.Root Cause: The Lease Operator arrived to the DCU 1 Salt Water Disposal location on Dec. 11th, 2018 and noticed moisture staining at surface near well head.  It was discovered that from during the last injection run, a pinhole had developed in the flow line between the pump and the well, resulting in approximately 5 bbl of Produced Water to be released primarily in the soil near the point of release.  As with the previous related incident in December of 2016, a pinhole was found on the same 2 inch flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: Produced Water testing is in progress and the failed flowline is being analyzed for corrosion and metal integity. Initial repairs have been made with affected portion of line replaced and pressure tested (witnessed by COGCC staff on site - Inspection 401874064).  Appropriate corrective actions will be taken after results of water and metal testing is complete.

properties.Spill_Desc: During annual pressure testing of dumplines on well pad, one dumpline failed pressure test. The line was isolated and one calls were made to allow for excavation of the line. The line will be excavated in its entirety, the leak was located and samples and delineation were conducted by third party environmental contractor. The leak was located, the leaking line portion was removed entirely and replaced with new pipe. The Dump line is 2" fusion bonded carbon steel installed 3/2006. Line to be excavated 12/13/18 and samples will be taken 12/14/18. Please the comments section of this submittal for additional infomation.
properties.Root Cause: Root cause was corrosion of dump line in low spot where fluids had accumulated

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A valve on the produced water load line froze and split releasing approximately 45 bbls of produced water inside a lined containment. The tank was bottomed out and the valve was replaced. A truck is enroute to remove the water from the lined containment.
properties.Root Cause: A valve froze and split on a produced water load line.
properties.Preventative Measure: Heat trace will be utilized to keep the valve from freezing.

properties.Spill_Desc: At 9:54 am MST, a contract welder noticed a produced fluid spill at Emerald 31AX, and a Field Specialist was dispatched.   The Field Specialist shut off the well upon arrival at 9:58 am MST.  Injection water (no oil) was releasing from a 1" stainless steel ball valve above ground on the injection skid down onto the ground (release point above ground).  Fluids were retained within the well pad's earthen berm as well as the well pad's lease road.
A historic spill was observed while abandoning a short flowline segment between the wellhead and road.  Spill mitigation efforts are underway.
properties.Root Cause: On December 13, 2018, historic hydrocarbon impacts were discovered during plug and abandonment activities at the Olander U14-14 wellhead.
properties.Preventative Measure: The wellhead was plugged and abandoned.

properties.Spill_Desc: While pressure-testing 10-inch poly line, pipeline personnel noticed a drop in pressure.  Upon further investigation, water was found coming to surface within the pipeline right of way at the location noted above.  The water ran down a hillside a short distance where it intersected an access road and traveled in the barrow ditch a distance of ~800 feet, then crossed under the road through a culvert and flowed onto an adjacent hay field for another ~250 feet.  Upon discovery, personnel immediately shut-down the pumps to the pipeline and a vac-truck was dispatched and recovered ~ 5bbls of water from the barrow ditch and low spots.  Soil samples were collected from 5 locations along the spill path immediately after the spill and each were field-screened for TPH using a PetroFlag kit.  The results for TPH ranged from 0 - 132 ppm incidating that the water was clean with only trace amounts of hydrocarbon.  Samples have been sent to lab for confirmation analyses.
properties.Root Cause:
A water pipeline developed a small hole resulting tin the release. Upon discovery, the line compromised section of pipe was exposed, removed and replaced. Affected soil in the barrow ditch, irrigation ditch, and pasture area will be excavated and replaced with clean fill. All soils removed from these areas will be temporarily stockpiled on land owned by TEP until final disposition of the soils can be determined.  Prior to placing any clean fill in the excavated areas, additional soil samples will be collected to ensure that all impacted areas have been cleaned up to background conditions.  
After excavating and exposing the poly-line in preparation to make repairs, the failure point was closely examined and it was determined that the poly pipe failed where two sections were fused together.  The pipeline contractor who performed the initial work was called in to repair and replace the joint that failed and to correctly fuse the segments together.  Crews decided to excavate / expose the pipeline to the next fused segment, and discovered a similar unacceptable fuse / weld.  Even though the second joint did not leak, it was deemed unacceptable and the decision was mad to sleeve the 10-inch poly with a new 4-inch flex pipe that is pressure rated to 750 PSI, which is well above the actual operating pressure of the water line (250 – 300 PSI).  The total distance sleeved was approximately 1,600 LF.
properties.Preventative Measure: Frequent testing of pipelines with similar age, type and location.

properties.Spill_Desc: Phyical/mechanical failure of a nipple valve, looks to be cracked. All fluids were confined to the lined secondary containment. Fluids were recovered using a vac truck. Approximately 70 bbls of fluid was inside the containment.
properties.Root Cause: Laramie staff discovered a leak in the piping below the weir system inside the tank battery containment. A nipple was broken at a hammer union. Staff fixed the leak by replacing the nipple. Pumper recovered 65 bbls of liquid out of the containment. No liquid escaped the containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: Laramie is continues to examine all field equipment on a regular basis in an effort to identify potential mechanical failures.

properties.Spill_Desc: Spill occured while loading a tanker truck.  As soon as the leak in the line was discovered loading operation halted and valve closed immediately.   Spill occured and stayed on roadbase surface at tank load out area.  No oil left the pad.   Free liquid was vacuumed and recovered.  Impacted pad roadbase and underlying soil, if any, will be scraped up and taken to landfill for disposal.
properties.Root Cause: 7:30am tank truck was being loaded with oil and compartment being filled overflowed.  Loading was immediately stopped when overflow was noticed.  Spill estimated at 2 bbls outside containment.  Root cause was oil truck driver was distracted and not focusing on job.
properties.Preventative Measure: Incident was discussed with the driver and supervisor.  Importance of spill prevention and focus on job at hand was conveyed. With concequences of future incidents up to and including termination.

properties.Spill_Desc: A suspected leak from a flowline on pad routing from the wellhead to the separator.  A small dike was created, using hand shovels, to prevent water from leaving location. Cause and type of failure is unknown.  Area of impact initially reported as 16'x16'x12" deep.
