properties.Root Cause: Please see attached the failure analysis identifying internal corrosion was the cause of this dumpline failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: Caerus is performing a field wide chemical use applicability study to identify best chemicals to be used for the best application.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 8/1/2019 ~8:AM, a produced water release was discovered on the YCF 2-35-1. ~4.46 Bbls produced water was released due to a 1" nipple threads breaking from the PSV in the pump house. The nipple and tee were replaced with a 1" 90 fitting. A  water truck removed free standing fluids from the lined secondary containment inside the pump house (~4.45 Bbls produced water recovered) an additional 0.014 of heavy spray occurred outside the pump house onto gravel, impacted soil/gravel has been removed. Spill did not leave location.
properties.Root Cause: Broken Threads on 1" nipple - Root Cause: Vibration
properties.Preventative Measure: 1" nipple and tee were replaced with 90 degree fitting

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On August 1, 2019, a 1-inch blow down valve at the Robin 36-9HZ well pad was inadvertently left open on the inlet riser to temporary tanks following a preventative maintenance procedure. This resulted in the release of approximately 31 barrels of produced water inside the lined containment. The details are summarized below. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: On August 1, 2019, a 1-inch blow down valve at the Robin 36-9HZ well pad was inadvertently left open on the inlet riser to temporary tanks following a preventative maintenance procedure. This resulted in the release of approximately 31 barrels of produced water inside the lined containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The field personnel will be retrained on proper preventative maintenance procedures.

properties.Spill_Desc: Production personnel discovered a leaking produced water line riser on the east edge of the GM 343-32 pad (COGCC location ID 335492).  This water line gathers produced water from the MV 18-32 location (COGCC location ID 335240) and the GM 343-32 well pad.  The water is then sent to the GM 11-33 tank farm (COGCC location ID 335144).  The leaking water line was recently pressure tested on May 6, 2019, and successfully passed the test indicating no loss of pressure.  Upon discovery of the leaking riser, the line was shut down and water production was temporarily transferred to an 80 bbl tank located at the GM 343-32 well pad location.  The produced water that was released entered a culvert and traveled a short distance where it was contained in an off-site storm water retention basin.  The impacted soils were field-screened using a PetroFlag kit, and the TPH content of the soils ranged from 107 - 173 ppm.  The leaking riser will be excavated and repaired during August 7 - 9, 2019.
properties.Root Cause: Leaking produced water line pipe riser fitting.
properties.Preventative Measure: The defective carbon steel riser and associated fittings were replaced with stainless steel to prevent any future incidents at this location.  Continue to conduct routine pressure testing and replace equipment as failures occur.

properties.Spill_Desc: During a routine site visit, a dumpline leak was observed near the production separators.
properties.Root Cause: The failure occurred on the 90 degree elbow where the line transitioned from a horizontal to vertical orientation near the production separator associated with the dumpline.  The root cause was internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The line will be evaluated for corrosion inhibitor chemical injection.

properties.Spill_Desc: A rubber gasket failed on the produced water discharge line at the Golding 4 pump house causing a release of approximately 130 bbls of produced water.  The water was released onto the edge of the tank battery pad and ran down a gentle slope a distance of approximately 100 yards where most of the water was collected and contained in a dry storm water sediment basin located near the access road.  A vac-truck was used to recover ~100 bbls of produced water from the sediment basin.  The remaining ~30 bbls soaked into the dry soils and could not be recovered.  Samples from impacted soils were collected for lab analysis, and field screening measurements for TPH ranged from 52 ppm to 216 ppm.  The water was recovered quickly from the storm water basin, and there were no impacts to surface or ground water resources.  The rubber gasket was replaced with a metal gasket rated for higher operating pressures to prevent any future issues.
properties.Root Cause: A rubber gasket failed, allowing produced water to flow off the edge of the pad near the pump house.  The water traveled off location a distance of approximately 200 feet where is collected and was contained in a stormwater catchment basin.  A small volume of water also flowed down a barrow ditch along the access road for a distance of approximately 100 feet.
properties.Preventative Measure: Upon further investigation of the incident, it was determined that the rubber gasket that was used to repair a flow meter was incorrect for the application.  The rubber gasket was rated for 150 psi, and the pressure through the water line / flow meter exceeded the pressure rating of the gasket.  The rubber gasket was replaced with a steel gasket that was rated appropriate to the application.  The flow meter had recently been rebuilt and the wrong gasket was used to repair the flow meter.  Both quipment and human error are the root causes of this incident.
properties.Detailed Root Cause Type: Fatigue of gasket and/or mechancal failure

properties.Spill_Desc: During operations a flowline release was discovered.  The line/location was shut in and excavation of impacted media is underway
properties.Root Cause: During operations a flowline release was discovered. Root cause of flow line failure was external corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Frenzel B15-5 flow line was repaired. Due to the history of failures of the Frenzel B15-5 the well is shut in along with the Frenzel B15-6 well head. Both well heads will remain shut in till P&A'd.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A closed valve overpressured a regulator valve and caused oil to leak out of the regulator. Approximately 10 bbls of oil were released inside containment. The back pressure regulator was replaced and the lines were returned to service. A vacuum truck is being dispatched to recover the released oil and impacted ballast material.
properties.Root Cause: A closed valve overpressured a regulator valve on a separator causing oil to leak out of the regulator.
properties.Preventative Measure: BCEI employees and contractors are coached to double check their work and verify all required valves are in the correct position prior to returning a piece of equipment back to service.

properties.Spill_Desc: Laramie discoveed a wet spot on pad that appears associatted with a flow line or dump line release. The exact source is not yet known. all lines to and from the onsite tanks were turned off. Deliniation and sampling is scheduled for aug 22, 2019

Flowline failure occurred at the NW corner of WRC 11 & 12 on August 17, 2019. Notification of the release was provided by Mountain View Fire Dept following a 911 report of the release. The failure occurred around 1:45 pm, with an estimated 30 gallons of hydrocarbon fluid released. Upon notification of the flowline release, KPK shut-in the line. A vac truck was brought in to remove any free standing product. Excavation work began on August 19, 2019, to remove contaminated soil and expose location of the flowline failure.
properties.Root Cause: Flowline failure occured along a 4" carbon steel pipe, between the 5 O'clock and 6 O'clock position. Flowline failure due to corrosion on the exterior of the flowline. Wells associated with this facility include: Leppla Estate 1 (API #05-123-08101), Leppla Estate 2 (API #05-123-08194), Leppla Estate 3 (API #05-123-09152), Leppla Estate 4 (API # 05-123-09165).
properties.Preventative Measure: Large section of flowline (~1,200 feet) stung with 3-inch poly pipe to remove potential failure points along original 4” carbon steel flowline. Post repair pressure test witnessed by COGCC staff on 10/07/19.

properties.Spill_Desc: On August 21, 2019 a water facilities operator arrived on the G1SW injection location and identified a small amount of pooled water around the MCU injection pipeline and building.  Upon discovery of the pooling liquid, the MCU injection pipeline was shut in and pressure tested.  The pipeline failed pressure testing and has been taken out of service, awaiting additional investigation and repair.
properties.Root Cause: The injection pipeline failure was due to internal corrosion on the carbon steel pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pipeline was replaced with HDPE pipe to remove the potential for internal corrosion.

properties.Spill_Desc: The elbow of the flowline burried at the wellhead about 4ft down realeased oil. Susan Sherman was called. Vacuum truck came and sucked up all oil. All impacted dirt was piled and bermed. Operator will contact Landowner and Lincoln County LGD to inform of release.

A spill of ~ 200 bbls of produced water occured at the Rulison Centralized Water Management Facility on 8/25/19 when a 1-inch nipple on the DAF chemical coagulant injector failed due to corrosion.  Fortunately, the entire volume of produced water was captured and contained within the lined, metal secondary containment structure.  The corroded nipple was replaced with a stainless steel replacement nipple and fitting.  The produced water that was released was pumped back to a tank upstream of the failure point.  In addition to equipment failure, a contributing factor is human error.  The contract operator failed to perform hourly checks as required by procedure.  As a result, the leak should have been identified and fixed much quicker than it was.  The importance of following established procedures were reviewed and reiterated with the operators.  100% of the water that was released was captured and recovered, and there was no release outside of the containment structure.
properties.Root Cause: A 1-inch nipple on the DAF chemical coagulant injector failed due to corrosion, releasing ~200 bbls of production water into the lined secondary containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The carbon steel nipple and fitting that failed due to corrosion were replaced with a stainless steel nipple and fitting to prevent failure at this specific point in the future.  Water Management personnel also met with the contract water operator staff and reitterated the importance of conducting hourly inspections as outlined in the agreed-upon procedures.  In addition, the importance of conducting routine inspections and timely maintenance of equipment was reinforced with the responsible personnel.

properties.Spill_Desc: Injection water leak (produced water) on 4 inch fiberglass line, cause not known yet.  Isolated lines/wells that feed lateral.  Made notifications to COGCC, BLM and CDPHE.  Liquids entered (Un-named) dry feature, remaining standing liquids were vac trucked up. Spill travel approximately 1900 feet.  50.58 bbl spilled to land, 5 bbls was recovered.  Water washing spill area with clean water is on going.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On August 28, 2019, a failed flowline from the Held 12-14I8 well resulted in the release of approximately 10 barrels of condensate and crude oil into an unnamed flowing irrigation ditch. Absorbent booms were deployed to contain the release, and vac trucks were used to recover the impacts. On August 28 and 29, 2019, 20 surface water samples were collected from ten locations (SW01 through SW10) upstream and downstream from the release location. Laboratory analytical results indicated detectable levels of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and/or total xylenes in samples SW01-2, SW02-2, SW03, SW03-2, SW04, SW05, and SW09. Assessment and remedial activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a supplemental report. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1. A Site Map depicting the release location and surface water sample locations is attached as Figure 2. The surface water results collected to-date are summarized in Table 1.
properties.Root Cause: On August 28, 2019, the flowline from the Held 12-14I8 well failed due to external corrosion, resulting in the release of approximately 10 barrels of condensate and crude oil into an unnamed flowing irrigation ditch.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline will be replaced, and the site will be restored to its pre-release grade.

properties.Spill_Desc: Water dump line from separator to storage tank formed a hole from what is believed to be corrosion resulted in produced water spill.
properties.Root Cause: Water dump line from separator to storage tank formed a hole from what is believed to be corrosion resulted in produced water spill.
properties.Preventative Measure: The line was replaced prior to being brought back online. Water dump lines of similar vintage and history being replace throughout the field.

properties.Spill_Desc: Stuck dump valve inside tank battery secondary containment. Stuck valve resulted in release of approx 50 bbls to the lined secondary containment. Truck was onsite within 20 minutes of discovery. 40 bbls of fluid has been recovered. Fluid is still being removed from the secondary containment. No evidence of released fluids outside the containment.
Turned off well.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: While performing annual flowline pressure testing, three separate lines failed to hold pressure. When the lines were excavated, impacted soil was discovered around each of the compromised lines. The released volume is currently unknown, but is not believed to be over 5 bbls. Excavation, line repairs, and soil remediation are currently scheduled and awaiting line locates. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis. Analytical results will be included in a subsequent Form 19.
properties.Root Cause: While performing annual flowline pressure testing, three separate lines failed to hold pressure. When the lines were excavated, impacted soil was discovered around each of the compromised lines.  The releases from the flowlines were determined to be the result of internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Chemical treatment will be used to mitigate internal corrosion

properties.Spill_Desc: At approximately 8:00 am moist soils were noted by the operator on west end of the pump house building.  It is assumed there is a leak in the connection of the 2 inch piping going to the produced water pump.  The flow line was blocked in and the pump removed from service.  Once the one call has cleared the area can be excavated to find out what is causing the moist soils around the pump house.
properties.Root Cause: Failure of steel pipe from the pump at a 90 degree bend due internal corrosion.  See the attached photo of pin hole leak site.
properties.Preventative Measure: The steel pipe will be replaced with stainless steel, which is corrosion resistant.  Corrosion inhibitor will be added to the system as preventative measure as well.

properties.Spill_Desc: Flowline failure occurred at the NW corner of WRC 11 & 12 on August 17, 2019. Notification of the release was provided by Mountain View Fire Dept following a 911 report of the release. The failure occurred around 1:45 pm, with an estimated 30 gallons of hydrocarbon fluid released. Upon notification of the flowline release, KPK shut-in the line. A vac truck was brought in to remove any free standing product. Excavation work began on August 19, 2019, to remove contaminated soil and expose location of the flowline failure.
properties.Root Cause: Flowline failure occured along a 4" carbon steel pipe, between the 5 O'clock and 6 O'clock position. Flowline failure due to corrosion on the exterior of the flowline. Wells associated with this facility include: Leppla Estate 1 (API #05-123-08101), Leppla Estate 2 (API #05-123-08194), Leppla Estate 3 (API #05-123-09152), Leppla Estate 4 (API # 05-123-09165).
properties.Preventative Measure: Large section of flowline (~1,200 feet) stung with 3-inch poly pipe to remove potential failure points along original 4” carbon steel flowline. Post repair pressure test witnessed by COGCC staff on 10/07/19.

properties.Spill_Desc: A rubber gasket failed on a flange connection at the PA 22-25-695 completions can resulting in the release of approximately 4.9 bbls of filtered produced water.  The water line has a rated working pressure of 250 psi and the line was being operated at 230 psi when the spill occurred.  When the gasket failed, water sprayed out and away from the flange connection and the completions can.  Some of the water entered a shallow, dry, ephemeral drainage feature and traveled a distance of approximately 200 feet where the flow stopped.  A smaller volume of water ran down the edge of the access road a distance of approximately 60 feet.  A vac truck was used to recover ~ 2 bbls of pooled water.  Soils samples have been collected and sent to the lab for analysis.  Initial field screening measurements for TPH ranged from 1 ppm to 280 ppm.  The faulty gasket has been replaced and the line will be tested prior to resuming normal operations.
properties.Root Cause: A rubber gasket failed on a flange connection at the PA 22-25-695 completions can resulting in the release of approximately 4.9 bbls of filtered produced water. Produced water flowed for a distance of 205 feet within a dry ephemeral drainage feature where it stopped. Vac trucks recovered any free standing liquids where pooling occurred.
properties.Preventative Measure: Although the equipment and fittings were being operated below the recommended working pressures, the flange gasket still failed.  Upon further inspection of the gasket after the incident, external weathering and cracking of the rubber gasket material likely contributed to the failure.  The defective gasket was replaced with a new one and other gaskets on the system were inspected for integrity.  The system was tested and closely inspected prior to resuming normal operations.  The contract water operator was instructed to continue routine maintenance and inspections of equipment, replacing worn or broken equipment as needed.
properties.Detailed Root Cause Type: Fatigue of gasket and/or mechancal failure

properties.Spill_Desc: After transferring a truckload of crude oil from the truck loading/unloading area to crude oil tank T-116A located in the Yellow Jacket Compressor Station tank farm, one of the plant operators was watching the SCADA screen and noticed that the fluid level of T-116A was dropping slowly. Since no other activities were taking place at the time, such as drawing off water or transferring oil to the reboiler fuel tanks, the operator shut the tank valve and looked for leaks on the transfer pipe. After finding no leaks at the surface, the transfer pipe was filled with water and pressure tested which indicated that there was a leak which was assumed to be on approximately 100 feet of the buried portion of the line. An air-vac unit was used to pothole along the line starting at the truck loading/unloading area and a leak was found on a section of uncoated piping inside the secondary containment of the tank farm. A pinhole was observed on the top of the uncoated 3-inch carbon steel pipe.
During operations a hole developed in produced water line.  The location is shut in and an excavation to remove impacted media is underway.
properties.Root Cause: During operations a hole developed in produced water trunk line.  The location is shut in and an excavation to remove impacted media is underway. Failure of produced water trunk line was due to internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Produced water trunk line was abandoned in place and all the separator water dump lines were co-mingled with the separator oil dump lines. Co-mingled dump lines were then pressure tested at 120lbs for 30 minutes.

properties.Spill_Desc: A spill to land of Produced (Injection) water from near WAG skid at Fee-90X, aprroximately 30.55 bbls.  Zero oil.  16 bbls was recoved with a vac truck and spill area was water washed with 160 bbls of clean water from the Main Water Plant and 160 bbls of water was recovered.  Probable cause is internal corrosion on 3 inch Corvel coated spool.

Valve on the bradenhead line was left open after testing. Approximately 5 bbls of produced water was released and contained around the wellhead area by crews, who also collected approximately 4 bbls of the produced water from the surface. Valve was closed upon discovery.
properties.Root Cause: Valve on the bradenhead line was left open after testing. Approximately 5 bbls of produced water was released and contained around the wellhead area by RamCO crew, who also collected approximately 4 bbls of the pooled produced water from the surface. Valve was closed upon discovery. After water was collectd by vac truck, a backhoe was brought in to scrap the impacted surface. Approximately 12 yards of impacted material were removed fromt he surface. Confirmation soil samples were then collected from the impacted area, as well as 1 native sample from outside of the impacted area, and taken to Origins Laboratory in Denver where they were analyzed for BTEX, DRO, GRO, EC, pH, and SAR. All results came back within Table 910-1 limits confirming successful cleanup. A site figure and lab analytical results report are attached to this form.
properties.Preventative Measure: Make sure pumpers are mindful of valve positions when completing work.

properties.Spill_Desc: Off load line valve was not fully closed by pumper during fluid transfer operations. Fluid was released at a low rate. Volume of release was 14.8 bbls, confirmed via SCADA readings from the tank. No fluid was recovered. The fluids migrated from the concrete loadout (impervious) surface to the soils around the concrete and were absorbed. Soil sample collection will be performed as soon as staff can be scheduled. No anticipated impacts to surface or ground water. the spill was confined to the pad surface in proximity to the storage tanks.
properties.Root Cause: After offloading prodcued water, driver closed valve to tanks and left site. Valve had not closed completely and slowly leaked produced water out on ground. Valve and Backflow valves were inspected for damage.
properties.Preventative Measure: Laramie re-inforced policy with water hauler to be more observant when conducting operations, especially at nights when no other personnel are present. Drip pans will be used for any leaking fittings at the truck end. Laramie is re-evaluating layout of facility and offload procedures  to determine if there are any actions that might prevent future incidents, or reduce impacts if another spill occurs.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 9/24/2019 ~3:35 PM a line leak was called into the XTO control room. Operators were immediately dispatched to location. Produced water was coming up throught the ground by the produced water disposal line/pig luncher. The line was immediately isolated and locked out. After excavation, a 2" hole was found in the 3" Shawor poly water line. The impacted soil will be properly disposed of. No waters were affected
properties.Root Cause: Failure of the shawcor line that was install by previous operator BOPCO - Root Cause: incorrect pipe selection
properties.Preventative Measure: Line is scheduled to be abandoned

properties.Spill_Desc: A gas lift flowline leak was identified during a routine air emissions inspection.  The failed flowline was depressurized and shut in.  A soil sample was collected from soil beneath the failed flowline on 9/27/2019.
properties.Root Cause: Bad weld
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed piece of pipe is being replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: Water dump line from separator to storage tank formed a hole from what is believed to be corrosion resulted in produced water spill.
properties.Root Cause: Water dump line from separator to storage tank formed a hole from internal corrosion resulting in produced water spill.  Investigation revealed that while a corrosion inhibitor chemical treatment program had been implemented at the facility there was a delay between the start of production and the start of use of corrosion inhibitor at the location.  This delay allowed produced water to flow through uncoated steel pipe without any inhibitor, resulting in premature corrossion of the water dump line.
properties.Preventative Measure: The produced water line was completely removed and replaced.  Highpoint is continuing to work with 3rd party vendors and corrosion experts to optimize our corrosion inhibitor program.  We are also evaluating using composite pipe for water dump lines to eliminate steel corrosion as a root cause.

properties.Spill_Desc: Fluid was being transferred from the Debeque WHF via pipeline. A valve mechanism within the valve can may have been improperly aligned. Fluids filled the valve can and migrated across the surface, down the CR 200 roadway, across additional surface and discharged into a flowing irrigation channel. The produced water flow was turned off as soon as it was discovered. Spill trailers were brought to the site and brought to bear within 20 minutes of discovery. Pumper/vac truck were also onsite to collect fluids. Sample was conducted along the path of the spill, both soils and water. Since the liquids were released to waters of the US we have also reported this to the Environmental Release Hotline. Roan Creek is approximately 200 feet from the point where the fluids entered the irrigation ditch. None of the fluids are believed to have entered Roan Creek or the Colorado River, but the irrigation ditch flows for a considerable distance in the direction of the Colorado River.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A comingled dumpline released an unknown volume of produced water to the subsurface. The cause of the release is believed to be internal corrosion but a formal investigation will take place and additional details on the cause and total release volume will be provided in a supplemental F19. Any impacted soil will be removed and confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion caused a comingled separator dumpline to release approximately 10 bbls of produced water below the ground surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Chemical treatment will be utilized to reduce corrosion issues.

properties.Spill_Desc: A produced water (Injection Water) leak occured at the 10 inch North Loop Injection Isolation valve set near the Kitty Fairfield A1 well location.  3.97 bbl of liquid was spilled to land, 2.0 bbls was recovered.The proper isolation valves were closed to stop the leak.  All proper notifications, internal and external were made.
properties.Root Cause: A spill to land of Produced (Injection) water from near Kitty Fiarfield valve set at the 10 inch North Loop Isolation , 3.87 bbl Zero Oil.  2 bbls was recovered.  Cause was internal corrosion on a 10 inch Corvel coated above bround line.
properties.Preventative Measure: Line was replaced with stainless steel

properties.Spill_Desc: A Produced water leak occured on flowline near LN Hagood A 15X on a 3 inch flowline.  16.83 bbls of produced water went to land.  10 bbls were recovered.  Area was water washed with clean water from the Main Water Plant, amount used to water wash will be reflected on the Supplemental form 19.  Lines were isolated to stop leak and all proper notifications were made.  Leak occured on BLM land and the required written notification will be completed on a NTL3A by the required deadline.

On October 7, 2019 at approximately 8:40, a Production Foreman reported to the OCC and EHS that a Contract Lease Operator had found a leak on a dump line at the H26NW. A puddle of water was discovered around the dump line as it goes underground behind the separator. There was a area of stained gravel and soil in the vicinity. Water was observed in an intentional low spot for stormwater collection on the edge of the pad. A vac truck was dispatched to remove as much free standing fluid as possible; they were able to recover 5 BBLs. A hydrovac was then dispatched to remove impacted soil around the failed line to determine point of failure.
properties.Root Cause: The dumpline failure analysis deteremined the primary failure mechanism is erosion caused by the abrupt direction difference of flow.  The failure point was found to be where the 2.5 inch line flows perpendicular into the 3.5 inch line.  Please refer to the attached failure analysis report prepared by Baker Hughes.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline is being rebuilt using stainless steel, a non-corrosive material.

properties.Spill_Desc: Approximately 3:00 pm on 10/09/19, a third-party performing excavation activity, struck the Leppla Estate #2 flowline causing a release of ~2 bbl of hydrocarbon fluid. Damaged flowline was immediately shut-in and a hydrovac truck brought in to remove any free-standing liquids.
properties.Root Cause: Three (3) inch fiberglass flowline struck by third party performing excavation activities in the area.
properties.Preventative Measure: 3 foot section of damaged flowline was removed and replced with similar 3 inch fiberglass flolwine. Flowline was pressure tested on 12/19/2019 to confirm repairs were successful.

properties.Spill_Desc: While rigging down completion equipment, contractor failed to follow procedure and drained lines from manifold onto ground. Normal operating procedure is to vacate lines with a wter truck prior to disconnecting from manifold. Contractor Negligence!!
properties.Root Cause: Contractor failed to follow procdure during rig down of completion equipment. Nomal operations is to evacuate(suck out) all water out lines and manifolds prior to breaking loose and rigging down. Contractor appeared to have broken lines loose with water still in them.Contractor and Laramie is investigating why the procedure was not followed. As these lines and manifolds are before the pumps, the water in the lines was produced water only.
properties.Preventative Measure: Laramie met with Contractor to discuss incident. The procedure in place was sound. Failure to follow by personnel was the cause. However, Laramie and contractor did discuss different way to evacuate the lines prior to rigging down.

properties.Spill_Desc: A produced water leak on the town trunk line near the WH Colthorp A1 well. Line was isolated to stop leak.  All fluids went to land area being water washed with clean water from Main Water Plant, will reflect amount on supplemental form 19.  All proper notifications were made.  Cause not know at this time.

On 10/13/2019 ~6:30 AM lease operator discovered the manifold on the produced water tank had frozen and broke causing the produed water release. ~26.0 bbls was released onto the surface of the pad and ~220 bbls remained inside the lined secondary containment. A water truck was immediately called and removed all free standing fluids. All tanks will be locked out until repairs to the manifold are complete. Spill did not leave location. Impacted soil will be properly disposed of. No waters were affected.
properties.Root Cause: Manifold froze and came apart Root Cause: Freezing
properties.Preventative Measure: Manifold will be replace - heat trace will be installed to assure no freezning issures will occure

properties.Spill_Desc: Still sorting out details but it appears there was a hole in the poly pipeline near the tie-in to crestone. Pipeline had feature to automatically shut off. Spill is contained and was on facility pad.
properties.Root Cause: Believe in laying the pipe that part of pipe was damaged. During the flowline test it didn't rupture but after conituous pressure it caused a hole in the pipeline near tie in point.
properties.Preventative Measure: Better examination of the pipe before and after being installed. Our monitoring system immediately shut down the pipe but there was still a release to the pad and some of the constructed road base nearby.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK was notified about a flowline release that had occurred on 10/16/19 while the crop land was being irrigated. KPK immediately responded, shutting in associated wells stopping any further release. KPK is currently working with landowner to gain access to the release location with a backhoe to remove impacted soil and to make necessary repairs to the flowline. A neighboring landowner (not the landowner on which the release occurred) contacted the Weld County Sheriff Office and CDPHE OEPR to report the release.
properties.Root Cause: Flowline failure occurred along a 3" fiberglass flowline, around the 6 O'clock position (estimate). Flowline failure due to soil shifting/settling. A single well is associated with the flowline failure: Nessu #1 (API #05-123-07762).
properties.Preventative Measure: Flowline will be repaired by replacing the damaged section of flowline with new fiberglass flowline. Estimated 3 ft. section of flowline will be replaced with new fiberglass flowline. Flowline will be pressure tested to confirm repair. Pressure test will be charted and provided in supplemental submittal. Backfill of excavation area will be properly compacted to prevent future settling.

properties.Spill_Desc: This location is located on private land within the Southern Ute Indian Tribe boundary.  The purge valve on the flowline on the water gathering failed and allowed ~4bbls or produced water to back flow onto location.  The release remained on location but soaked into the ground preventing any water to be recovered.
properties.Root Cause: Purge valve on water gathering failed allowing water to back flow onto location
properties.Preventative Measure: Purge valve was repaired

properties.Spill_Desc: On 10/16 a 4' X 4' area of moist soils were noted around the produced water flowline valve set for Totem Wells 4 and 5.  The moist soils were excavated down to 4 feet where the 2" flow line was found to be cracked.  The flowline failed at the junction where the line transitions from fiberglass to steel.  Once excvaved it was evident that the spill exceeded the 42 gallon reporting threshold.  The produced water impacted soils will be cleaned up to table 910-1 standards and the flow line will be repaired.
properties.Root Cause: A failed pipe support and soil settling put stress on the fiberglass flow line, which eventually cracked causing the leak.
properties.Preventative Measure: Once all of the contaminated soil has been excavated, pipe supports will be built specifically for this area.  The pipe supports will be designed for this specific location and will be strong enough to support the pipe despite minor settling.

properties.Spill_Desc: ~8:00 am a lease operator arrived on site to find produced water outside the pump building. Upon further investigation it was determined the check value outside the pump building malfunctioned causing PW to flow back into the discharge suction line. This caused the sump pump to over work and over heat, shutting down allowing the PW to be released inside and out the pump house. The check value has been replaced and the discharge system is under review for new routing to prevent any farther occurrence. A water truck was immediately called to remove all standing fluids. No waters were affected. Spill did not leave location
properties.Root Cause: Freezing weather caused the check value out side the pump building to malfunction. This allowed PW to back flow into the discharge suction line. The sump pump over heated causing it to shut down.  Root Cause: freezing weather
properties.Preventative Measure: Check value was replaced, heat trace was installed, discharge system is under review for new routing to prevent any further occurrence.

properties.Spill_Desc: The load line for a curde oil storage tank broke releasing crude oil and produced water into secondary containment.  The site has been secured, spill controlled, and facility shut-in.  Spill recovery and clean-up efforts are underway.
properties.Root Cause: On October 30, 2019, approximately 182 barrels of crude oil and 67 barrels of produced water were released into secondary containment at the Trimar Farms 29 Section production facility. Following the release, an inspection indicated that trapped water froze between the ball valve and seat, which compromise the oil drain valve.
properties.Preventative Measure: Routine inspections will be conducted to reduce volumes of produced water in crude oil storage tanks.

properties.Spill_Desc: Fluids were released from the suction manifold on frac tanks. Lines were not contained/shut off properly by contractors. Fluids accumulated rapidly and breached the perimeter berm. Fluids flowed to a sediment catchment basin, over flowed the basin and continued downgradient for approximately 60 feet. Flow channel from basin is estimated at 1 foot wide. Fluid recovery vehicles are in the process of pumping up as much fluid as possible.
Approximately 3.6 bbls of produced water released from a water gathering system. Isolation via closing valves.

On November 1, 2019, freezing temperatures cracked a gate valve on an oil loadout line at the Raindance Pad (Facility ID: 430504).  Approximately 26 bbls of crude oil were released into lined secondary containment.  There is currently no evidence that impacts migrated outside of the lined containment.  All 26 bbls were recovered using a vacuum truck and returned to the oil tanks.  Impacted pea gravel from inside the secondary containment is being removed and hauled off for disposal at an approved facility.  The equipment and liner will be washed using a hot water pressure washer and the liner will be inspected for integrity before clean pea gravel will be replaced.
properties.Root Cause: On November 1, 2019, freezing temperatures cracked a faulty gate valve on an oil loadout line at the Raindance Pad (Facility ID: 430504).  Approximately 26 bbls of crude oil were released into lined secondary containment and later recovered.  No impacts migrated outside of the lined containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The faulty gate valve has been replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: Laramie discovered an accumualtion of fluids inside the tank battery secondary containment about mid-day on Friday, Nov 1. Approximately 114 bbls of fluid was released and it mixed with snow/ice inside the containment. a total of 130 bbls was pumped from the containment and disposed of at Greenleaf. A small area outside the containment exhibited staining/fluid, likely seeping from a compromise in the liner. The amount outside the containment is estimated to be 15 gallons. The root cause of the release resulted from a failed heat trace on pipeing and frozed lines.

At the produced water tank for the Guttersen 31T-221 well, the produced water load line was compromised (potentialy due to frozen valve), spilled approximently 18 bbls of produced water inside secondary containment.  The respective well was shut-in and spill mititigation and clean-up efforts are underway.
properties.Root Cause: On November 3, 2019, approximately 18 barrels of produced water were released into secondary containment at the Guttersen Pad 4 production facility. After reviewing the faciliy automation data, it was determined the load line valve was initally compromised on 11-1-2019 due to the valve freezing, causing a slow leak.  The leak was not visually observed during routine facility inspections or automation tank level review, thus the load line valve was not replaced before the second freeze that caused the valve to crack, thus releasing a reportable volume inside secondary containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: Reinforce the importance of daily visual inspections and reviewing tank automation data to facility operations employees.

properties.Spill_Desc: Corrosion of a water dump line resulted in the release of approximately 20 bbls of produced water on the down-stream side of the low pressure separator.  The water ran off location and followed a barrow ditch along the access road for ~250 yards to the south.  All of the water stayed inside the ditch and none was discharged to an un-named drainage below West Anvil Point.  A check dam was created in the barrow ditch to prevent any water from entering a culvert.  The flow of water never made it to the check dam.   The defective pipeline has been replaced and pressure tested, and is functioning properly.  Soils impacted by the release were field screened with a PetroFlag kit.  Total Petroleum Hydrocarbons (TPH) levels were measured at 3 locations along the flowpath and ranged from from 173 to 226 ppm ... well below the COGCC cleanup standard for TPH.  Soil samples have been collected and sent to an analytical lab to determine if 910-1 cleanup standards have been exceeded.
properties.Root Cause: Corrosion on a water dump line resulting in 20 bbls of produced water being released.
properties.Preventative Measure: Continue routine maintenance and repairs of equipment as needed.  The need to conduct frequent, thorough, and diligent inspections of all equipment, piping, and fittings is continually emphasized during routine training and tailgate safety meetings.

properties.Spill_Desc: On the evening of 11/3/19 the Young 14-1 injection well was being turned on (treater lost pressure a couple days before and the battery was shut down) and Sam Bradley forgot to open the valve at the well.  When the injection pump was turned on the pressure came up and dropped back to zero.  The pump was shut down and the isolation valves were closed.  The line was inspected and water had surfaced at the point of the leak.  Less than 5 barrels of produced water, no oil, no soil staining or odor.  The surface is sand and the fluid immeadieatly soaked in.  Maintenance crew came out on 11/4/19 and the line was repaired.
properties.Root Cause: Battery was shut down a couple days prior due to the separator loosing pressure.  Sam was turning the injection well on and forgot to open the valve at the wellhead before turning on the injection pump.  The point of failure was at a collar in the flowline where a section of fiberglass flowline is changed over to a steel flowline.  The fiberglass flowline had a hole in it just before the collar.
properties.Preventative Measure: Proper training of Sam Bradley on double checking valve status before adding pressure.  Impetro will also implement a lock-out / tag-out program.  Having a more formal program for turning lines on and off should help prevent similar failures.

properties.Spill_Desc: Pumper discovered produced water leaking inside the metal, lined secondary containment structure at the BCU 442-36-199 well pad.  The water was leaking around a flanged valve.  The root cause of the release is equipment failure.  Trending records for this tank indicate that ~85 bbls of produced water were released from the tank / valve.  A vac-truck recovered 85 bbls of produced water plus an additional 15 bbls of storm water that accumulated inside the containment.  The pumper was able to isolate the faulty valve and water manifold until repairs were made.  The liner and containment structure were closely inspected, and the integrity of both is good.  There were no impacts outside of the containment structure, and virtually 100% of the released fluids have been recovered.
properties.Root Cause: Root cause of incident is equipment failure.  A flanged valve on the produced water tank mainifold failed.  It is suspected that a gasket within the flange cracked as a result of recent cold weather and temperatures.  Consequently, the gasket failed to form a tight seal at the flange valve connection thereby allowing water to leak from the valve and into the secondary containment structure.
properties.Preventative Measure: The faulty valve and gasket have been replaced and the system has been repaired.  The water lines, fittings, and valves have been tested and are functioning properly.  Pumpers have been instructed to pay close attention to any fittings, valves, and gaskets that may be susceptible to wear and failure from exposure to the elements and temperature fluctuations.

properties.Spill_Desc: Laramie staff regular inspection of facility noted produced water leak from piping connected to production tanks at a relatively slow rate. Fluids had accumulated in the secondary containment. Leak was isolated and contained by turning of valve. A water truck was onsite within 30 minutes, fluids were pumped from the containment. As the spill area was examined a small wet area was noted at the outside edge of the containment. Laramie believes the liner was compromised near the midpoint of the ffluid accumulation in the containment. Fluid migrated and saturated soils outside containment. Laramie dug out the saturated soil and put it in a tub plastic tub for disposal. Laramie estimates 1 to 3 gallons of fluid infiltrated less than 1 cu/yd of soil outside the containment. The cause of the release appears to be a corroded pipe union.

On November 7, 2019, at 11:00 am land owner notified KPK about a potential flowline leak. KPK immediately shut-in flowline (Facility #8 Consolidated Line) same day. KPK is actively working on solution to mobilized equipment to the release location to contain and begin recovering released product. Release location located in a drainage collection location making it difficult access with heavy equipment.
properties.Root Cause: 10-inch carbon steel line (Facility #8 Consolidation Line) failed at the 6 O’clock position due to corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: 10-inch carbon steel line will be stung with 3-inch poly line. Flowline will be pressure tested before associated well operations resume.

properties.Spill_Desc: Last night after a water hauler pulled a load, the water load line sprung a leak from a pinhole on the bottom of the pipe. This hole was from long term internal corrosion. The load bucket valve was shut but the valve on the water tank outlet was left open and water slowly leaked from the pinhole into containment. A vac truck removed approximately 22 bbls last night and 10 bbls of standing production water this morning. Total volume spilled is estimated at 35 bbls, all in containment. Nikki Graber with COGCC was contacted via telephone 11/9/2019 at 10:25 am and voice message was left providing notification of the release.
properties.Root Cause: On the evening of 11/8 the water hauler pulled a load, the water load line sprung a leak from a pinhole on the bottom of the pipe. This hole was from long term internal corrosion. The load bucket valve was shut but the valve on the water tank outlet was left open and water slowly leaked from the pinhole into containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The section of line that experienced failure was replaced on 11/9/2019.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 11/14/2019, a release occurred on a produced water transfer pipeline near the Horsetail 08D facility. Approximately 6 bbl of produced water was released. Upon discovery, the line was immediately isolated, and a crew was dispatched to recover the free liquids.

A water truck driver was on site at the 17F on 11/13/2019 at approximately 1:30 pm and noticed fluid had come to the surface of the pad.  Upon further investigation, it was discovered that a flowline on the pad was leaking underground.  The line was immediately shut in, and a hydrovac truck was called to suck up standing water.  Currently, locates are being requested so that repairs can be made to the underground flowline.  It was calculated that approximately 13 BBL of produced water was released. Verbal notification was made to Steven Arauza on 11/13/2019 at 5:07 pm.
properties.Root Cause: A two-inch steel dumpline that connects the production separators to the onsite production tanks corroded.
properties.Preventative Measure: All existing dumplines will be replaced with corrosion-resistant stainless steel lines.

properties.Spill_Desc: Failed pressure test at the P16OU.  Spill is not visible on the surface, but we are suspecting a leak undgerground.  Once the area is excavated, we will update spill size if needed.
properties.Root Cause: Corrosion
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed portion of line was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: Failed pressure test. Spill is not visible on the surface, but we are suspecting a leak undgerground. Once the area is excavated, we will update spill size if needed.
properties.Root Cause: The dumpline failed at the first elbow downstream of the production separator.  The root cause is internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: All dumplines on this location will be replaced with corrosion resistant stainless steel lines.

properties.Spill_Desc: Dumpline annual pressure tests were being conducted, this one failed. Caerus constuction team was brought in to identify cause of the pressue test failure. during Hydrovacing the pipeline impacts were observed.
properties.Root Cause: Corrosion
properties.Preventative Measure: The portion of the line that failed was replaced.  All flowlines on this pad will continue to be tested annually per COGCC regulations.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: Following pigging operations, a valve was left open on a receiver resulting in approximately 10 bbls of oil being released to the ground once the line was returned to service. The oil and impacted soil were immediately removed. Additional investigation will take place when utility locates are clear. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis. Analytical results will be included in a supplemental eForm 19.
properties.Root Cause: Following pigging operations, a valve was left open on a receiver resulting in approximately 10 bbls of oil being released to the ground once the line was returned to service.
properties.Preventative Measure: BCEOC personnel are coached on verifying proper valves are closed prior to restarting equipment.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A valve was left open on a produced water tank load out releasing approximately 10 bbls of produced water inside the lined containment. The produced water and impacted ballast material will be removed. The integrity of the liner will be checked prior to covering the liner with new ballast.
properties.Root Cause: A contract water hauler left a manifolded production tank load line valve open.
properties.Preventative Measure: Contractors are coached on closing every valve that they open.

properties.Spill_Desc: Water dump line from separator to storage tank formed a hole from what is believed to be corrosion resulted in produced water spill.
Water hauling company failed to close load out line valve, resulting in a produced water spill in containment.
During normal production operations a water line going to the water production tanks failed, releasing approximately 10 barrels of produced water. Produced water line was shut in and isolated.
properties.Root Cause: During normal production operations 3 inch produced water trunk line failed due to internal corrosion, releasing 10 barrels of produced water.
properties.Preventative Measure: Underground 3 inch produced water trunk line that failed was taken out of service. A new 3 inch schedule 80 produced water trunk line will be installed above ground.

properties.Spill_Desc: A partially open recycling line blowdown valve resulted in a release of approximately 10 barrels of oil.
properties.Root Cause: A partially open recycling line blowdown valve resulted in a release.
properties.Preventative Measure: Great Western will conduct additional training to ensure proper positioning of valves.

properties.Spill_Desc: During production an unintentional release occurred from the produced water dumpline.  The facility is currently shut in and repairs will be scheduled.
properties.Root Cause: The produced water line developed a leak subsurface.  The probably cause is corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Noble has implemented a chemical program for corrosion of flowlines.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 11/14/2019, a release occured on a produced water transfer pipeline near the Horsetail 08D. Aprroximately 6 bbl of produced water was released, Upon discovery, the line was immediately isolated, and crew was dispatched to recover the free liquids.
properties.Root Cause: The release occurred on a buried produced water pipeline on the south side of the Horsetail 08D flowline. The impacted soils were excavated and stockpiled on a liner for offsite disposal. Initial observations indicate the lease was cause by internal corrosion. The section of pipe was replaced with Polyflow Thermaflex pull through liner and all fitting will be replaced with stainless steel.
properties.Preventative Measure: A 2.75” internal diameter Polyflow Thermalflex pull through liner will be installed from water skid to the flex steel corridor. The Polyflow liner couples to the stainless steel fittings in order to reduce the potential for corrosion. In addition, the Polyflow liner is constructed of a multi-layer polymer for chemical resistance, low permeation, and temperature resistance.

properties.Spill_Desc: Treater drain line froze and split at an elbow; well had been shut-in for the winter and most of the fluid had been drained however a small amount remained in the bottom of the treater and caused the pipe to burst.  The spill was contained within the bermed area and was recovered using a hydro-vac truck within hours after it was discovered.  No fluid was observed outside of the containment area.  All contaminated material has been removed and hauled to disposal.

On November 28, 2019 the lease operator had discovered gas hissing from a gas sales pipeline down stream of the separation of liquids from the gas stream.  The lease operator noted no odor of produced water or condensate and that no stained soil was identified at the gas leak point.  The equipment was shut in until a full investigation could be conducted.

At ~11:45 am on 12/16/2019 an XTO lease operator found produced water free standing inside 2 valve cans on the PWDD (Produced Water Distribution and Disposal) ROW, south from PCU 296-6B location. A water truck was called to location and ~2 barrels of PW was removed from the valve cans. Excavation is needed to determine source of the release, pending approval from BLM.
properties.Root Cause: Corrosion caused a pin hole in the Produced Water line
properties.Preventative Measure: Area of corrosion was cut out and replaced with like material by way of welding it into place.

properties.Spill_Desc: During the dump line pressure test the operator heard gas releasing, no fluid was observed on the ground surface.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the incident was internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Caerus is in the process of replacing both dumplines at the site with stainless steel.  Caerus will coordinate with, and provide pressure testing information to the Western Integrity Inspector Inspector - Richard Murray.

properties.Spill_Desc: A failed dumpline was discovered during a pressure test.  The line was immediately de-energized and taken out of service.
properties.Preventative Measure: Once the root cause has been determined, ways to prevent a future occurrence will be presented.

properties.Spill_Desc: pressure test on flowline failed on 13b well
properties.Root Cause: The elbow immediately beneath the wellhead where the line transitions from a vertical orientation to a horizontal orientation failed due to corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The elbow was replaced.  Lease operators will continue to monitor production data for other potential failures and conduct pressure tests on production flowlines.

properties.Spill_Desc: A spill of 1.03bbl of produced water and 0bbl of oil was discovered at approximately 10:30 Thursday morning, December 26th.  The line was shut-in at 10:50 am.  Spill came from corrosion on a 4" injection lateral line going to the UP 67-32 well.  It began on the location and broke through the berm and traveled south of the well pad.  Standing fluid was removed by Vac-truck.  Water-wash to be completed and total amounts of recovered fluid will be reported on supplemental form 19.

A gasket failed on one of the initial C2C flowline risers. This caused a 13 BBL spill that was entirely contained to the well pad and was completely cleaned up using a vac truck. This gasket failure was noticed around 3pm on Saturday, December 28, 2019 and flowline was quickly shut down and vac truck removed any water from dirt clay well pad.
properties.Detailed Root Cause Type: Fatigue of gasket and/or mechancal failure

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK was notified by farmer about oil that had surfaced in corn field. At the time of notification, KPK had already blown down and shut-in the flowline to address other issue within the Nesssu system (Spill ID 468756). The flowline has not been brought back into service since being shut in. KPK has not be able to perform subsurface investigation, and can only estimate the volume of released fluids based on surface observations. KPK will be able to report results of subsurface investigation in supplemental Form 19.
properties.Root Cause: 3-inch fiberglass flowline failed causing a release of an unknown amount of hydrocarbon fluid. Once excavation activities begin and where the flowline failed can be observed, a Supplemental Form 19 will be submitted with more accurate flowline failure information.
properties.Preventative Measure: Flowline was already shut-in upon notification of the release. Damaged section of flowline will be repaired. Flowline will be pressure tested before being placed back into service.

properties.Spill_Desc: Lapp A22-689 flow line developed a leak releasing 2 barrels of oil and water outside of containment. Well is shut in and free standing liguid recovered by vac-truck.
properties.Root Cause: Lapp A22-689 flow line developed a leak releasing 2 barrels of oil and water outside of containment. Well is shut in and free standing liguid recovered by vac-truck.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 1/14/2020 at ~3:30PM While on routine site visit at the Hatch Gulch Pig Launcher area an XTO lease operator discovered spraying produced water coming from the 1/2" stainless steel ball valve that is used to isolate the grease port. Upon further investigation it was discovered the the ball valve had frozen causing it to crack, spraying procuced water onto the ground. ~3 bbls of standing fluid was removed by a vacuum water truck. ~.71 bbls was found to be frozen mixed with snow. The 1/2" ball valve was immediately replaced. Remaining .71 bbls will be removed and properly disposed of.
properties.Root Cause: The ball valve was a Quandrant 1/2" stainless steel class 1500 ball valve. The valve is above grade and is used to supply grease to the flow line valve below grade. Water had gotten past the grease and froze in the valve causing the release.
properties.Preventative Measure: will implement a more frequent greasing schedule for the valves which should insure water not to be trapped the valves and eliminate future occurrences.

properties.Spill_Desc: Produced water release from a steel line.  Released water flow approximately 100-115 feet from release point an terminated near vavle can.  Release was confined to pipeline right of way.   Water line was isolated and blown down. Vac truck used to recover approximately 5 bbls of produced water.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the release was internal corrosion due to water buildup along the identified section of the gathering system.
properties.Preventative Measure: The repairs consisted of removal and replacement the effected section of the gathering system. In addition an valve set and riser which a contributed to the collection of water in the pipeline was removed.

properties.Spill_Desc: A drain line valve on the oil tank froze and split, resulting in the release of approximately 58 bbls of oil all within secondary containment.
properties.Root Cause: A hole was identified at the base of the 300 bbl crude oil Tank 3 near the wall/tank bottom weld. Based on observations, the hole may have been caused from internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: All eight 300 bbl crude oil tanks and both partially buried produced water tanks will be removed from the location. The produced water tanks will be removed under a Form 27. One new 400 bbl crude oil tank and one new 150 bbl steel produced water AST will be installed.

properties.Spill_Desc: During completions, a leak developed in the flowback manifold, resulting in the release of approximately 4 bbls of brine water outside of secondary containment.
properties.Root Cause: During completions, a leak developed in the flowback manifold, resulting in the release.
properties.Preventative Measure: The leak was fixed. A safety meeting was held and communication procedures were updated.

properties.Spill_Desc: during drilling operations on the FED 15C-13-496 well. there was a equipment failure where a gasket failed and released estimated 20BBL of drilling mud. rig shut down operations and well which stopped release. drilling mud was on snow packed ground and recovered with equipment.

Upon arrival at the PA 313-33 tank facility this morning, the TEP pumper discovered that a vent valve on the water main water inlet line was not completely closed and was leaking produced water inside the lined, metal secondary containment structure.  It is estimated that approximately 50 bbls of produced water had leaked; however, the entire volume was completely contained within the containment structure.  The perimeter of the containment structure was inspected and there are no impacts outside of the containment.  The root cause of the spill is human error as it was determined that a water management contractor had inadvertently not completely closed the vent valve.  TEP has investigated the matter and has reviewed the proper procedure for setting valves at the tank farm with the contractor to prevent this incident from occuring in the future.  TEP production personnel has also inspected all valves and fittings to ensure integrity and proper function.
properties.Root Cause: Water management contractor accidentally left vent valve open after pulling load from tank battery.  Root cause of the incident was human error.  All water was contained within the secondary containment structure, and there were no impacts to soils or water resources outside of the containment structure.
properties.Preventative Measure: TEP has investigated the incident and reviewed the correct procedures for operating the valves with the contractor.  TEP production personnel has also inspected all valves, fittings, hoses, etc. to ensure proper operation.  TEP personnel also closely inspected the secondary containment structure itself and the walls and poly liner are in good condition.

properties.Spill_Desc: During pressure testing activities for the F23 pad, Caerus field personnel identified a failed pressure test on the water transfer dumpline at the location.  During initial inspection of the failed section of the water transfer dumpline, Caerus identified a second hole in the dumpline.  The wells on the location were shut in and Caerus is currently in the process of excavating the dumpline release locations to determine the extent of the release.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of failure was internal corrosion of the water transfer dumpline.
properties.Preventative Measure: Caerus is utilizing a supercore internal corrosion treatment application to prevent reoccurrence of the internal corrosion identified at this pad.

properties.Spill_Desc: A half inch cracked piping below a pressure gauge spilled water from Drip Trap 6, on the gas gathering system, to the ground.  Area was field messured with messuring tape by Field Specialist.  When leak was discovered, system was isolated to stop leak.  Snow around the spill area was removed, no visalble standing fluids were present.  Root cause and corrective actions have not been completed at this time, but will be documented before spill closure.
properties.Root Cause: A spill occured due to a pressure gauge/piping freezing.  Freezing caused by lack of heat trace protection.
properties.Preventative Measure: Extending heat trace and insulation on equipment.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: Impacts were encountered following the discovery of a pinhole leak in the produced water dump line below a separator at the Sack 37C-6HZ production facility. Groundwater was encountered within the excavation at approximately 8.5 feet below ground surface (bgs). On February 6, 2020, a groundwater sample (GW01) was collected and submitted to Origins Laboratory for analysis of BTEX by USEPA Method 8260C. Analytical results received on February 7, 2020, indicated that the benzene and toluene concentrations in groundwater sample GW01 were out of compliance with the COGCC standards. Soil excavation activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1. The groundwater sample location is illustrated on Figure 2. The groundwater analytical results are summarized in Table 1 and the analytical laboratory report is provided as Attachment A.

~3:30 am on 2/5/2020 Operations began having issues with freezing at the Piceance Creek Unit Secondary TB. Temperature at that time was between -12 and -22 degrees F. The outlet pumps for this tank was not showing flow and started faulting out. While trying to determine why, the operator witness PW overflowing. Upon investagation it was found that the outlet valve downstream from the pump was frozen/stuck in the closed position preventing the tank from pumping out, an additional factor that led to the overfill was the the Hi-Hi transmitter that should have ESD'd the facility was also frozen. ~10bbls of PW was released inside lined secondary containment before facility was shut in to stop the release. All fluids were recovered by using a water transport truck and put back into the PWDD system.
properties.Root Cause: Freezing conditions caused the outlet valve downstream from the pump to freeze in the closed position causing the release. Another factor was the the Hi-Hi transmitter failed not allowing the facility to ESD (Emergency Shut Down).
properties.Preventative Measure: The Hi-Hi transmitter has been replaced and tested

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: The cause of the release is still under investigation, but it is believed that an oil dump line released a total of approximately 20 bbls of oil to the ground surface, subsurface, and poly-lined separator containment.  Following utility locates, the area will be excavated to expose the flowline and remove the impacted soil.  The flowline will be pressure tested following repairs and before being returned to service.  Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis. Analytical results will be included in a supplemental eForm 19.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion on an oil dump line allowed approximately 50 bbls of oil to be released to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dump line running from the separators to the production tanks is going to be completely removed and replaced. Chemical treatment as well as annual flowline pressure testing are utilized to verify the integrity of the lines.

properties.Spill_Desc: A leak occurred on the FEE-138X flowline, releasing 6.05 bbl of produced water and .09 bbl of oil to land.  Apon discovery, line was isolated to stop leak.  All proper notifications were made.  1 bbl of fluid was recovered.  Area was water washed with clean water from the main water plant.  Root cause and corrective actions not know at this time but will be documented before closure.
properties.Root Cause: A leak occurred on the FEE-138X flowline, releasing 6.05 bbl of produced water and .09 bbl of oil to land. Apon discovery, line was isolated to stop leak. All proper notifications were made. 1 bbl of fluid was recovered. Area was water washed with clean water from the main water plant.  315 bbl of clean water from water plant used to wash spill path, 325 bbl were recovered. 4 inch Fiberglass line failed due to age, Line will remain shut in until entire line is replaced.
properties.Preventative Measure: Replacing Entire line.

properties.Spill_Desc: Leak originated below grade from the Fee 11 flowline at the header for Collection Station 28.  Spill area was measured with measuring tape and wheel by the Field Specialist.  Upon discovery, the flowline was shut-in and standing fluid was removed by Vac-truck.  Root cause and corrective actions have not been completed at this time, but will be documented before spill closure.
properties.Root Cause: Leak originated below grade from the Fee 11 flowline at the header for Collection Station 28.  Spill area was measured with measuring tape and wheel by the Field Specialist.  Upon discovery, the flowline was shut-in and standing fluid was removed by Vac-truck.  Leak originated from 3" fiberglass flange failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: Flange will be replaced with new heavy duty flange.

properties.Spill_Desc: A lease operator was conducting pressure testing on the B26 produced water dumpline.  The lease operator noted a failed pressure test on the dumpline and located the spill location using a FLIR camera on February 18th, 2020.  The dumpline was taken out of service and environmental assessment and investigation are being conducted.  This dumpline line was last pressure tested on January 15, 2020.
properties.Root Cause: Caerus was conducting pressure testing on the B26 well pad and identified a dumpline which failed pressure test.  Caerus is in the process of excavating the dumpline to determine the exact point of failure.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline which failed was threaded pipe with buried collars.  Caerus is in the process of replacing the dumpline with a larger diameter welded pipe to ensure greater wall thickness to prevent further incidents.  Caerus is in the process of testing products which will reduce or remove the potential for internal corrosion of the dumpline.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: Internal corrosion caused a produced water dumpline on the North Platte 24-21-23HNC separator to release an estimated 40 bbls of produced water. Utility locates have been called in and remediation efforts will take place as soon as they clear. The line will be replaced and pressure tested prior to being returned to service. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis. Analytical results will be included in a subsequent eForm 19.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion caused a produced water dumpline on the North Platte 24-21-23HNC separator to release an estimated 40 bbls of produced water.
properties.Preventative Measure: Chemical treatment is utilized to reduce internal corrosion.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A riser on the RMI Oil-SA-CPF System released oil to the ground surface. BCEOC is reviewing production records to determine an approximate release volume. Vacuum trucks are currently on location recovering the standing oil. The riser will be repaired and pressure tested prior to being returned to service. The impacted soil will be removed and confirmation soil samples will be submitted for laboratory analysis. Analytical results will be included in a supplemental eForm 19.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion caused a fitting on a gathering line riser to release approximately 200 bbls of oil to the ground.
properties.Preventative Measure: Chemical treatment is utilizied to reduce corrosion. Daily inspections are used to catch any issues as soon as possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 2/26/2020 a Wexpro Operator observed saturated soil near the production separator at the Hiawatha Deep 3 wellsite in Moffat County, Colorado.  A test hole was hand-dug and the separator dump line was determined to be the source of the leak.  A small quantity of impacted soil was apparent, and the spill volume was estimated to be 5 gallons.  On 2/28/2020 the dump line was excavated following utility clearance.  Approximately 15 cubic yards of impacted soil was removed, revealing the spill was larger than previously known.  Based on this volume of soil, the release is estimated at 1-2 bbls.  Excavated soils have been placed on a liner and will be disposed of as RCRA exempt E&P waste.  Initial soil samples will be taken in the open trench to investigate and ensure impacted soils have been removed.
properties.Root Cause: The dump line has two points of failure. One pinhole near the elbow which appears to be corrosion related and once crack approximately 3 feet from the elbow. This crack bulges outward and may be related to a pressure event.  Black soil was encountered to 8 feet below grade (ft-bg) near the production unit, and has been the focus of this excavation.  This material is not saturated, has no hydrocarbon odor, and no elevated PID readings were observed when field screening the soil.  Spill remediation is being addressed and filed under a Form 27.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK discovered the flowline failure on 03/04/2020. Pooled fluids were observed ~800 ft. SE of the Burkhardt Seltzer #1 well (API # 05-123-08864). Upon discovery of the flowline release, KPK immediately shut-in the line. Excavation work to remove impacted soil and expose location of the flowline failure is scheduled to began on 03/05/2020, once excavation equipment can be mobilized to location.
properties.Root Cause: Flowline failed causing a release of commingled hydrocarbon fluid. Flowline release was discovered by the pooled fluids at ground surface. Section of flowline associated with release is a 4" carbon steel line. Flowline failed most likely due to corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Damaged section of flowline will be removed. 3" poly line will be stung through the exisiting 4" carbon steel line to prevent future failures along the same section of flowline. Flowline will be pressure tested before being placed back into service.

properties.Spill_Desc: During morning Signet Well Reviews, a Route Pumper noticed a drop in pressure at the K22 596.  The Pumper prioritized this location as an immediate site visit.  Upon arriving on location, the Pumper initiated the Flowline Pressure Testing Procedure.  It was clearly evident in the rate of pressure loss there is a failure somewhere along the flowline from well 13D-22, on the K22 596.  He noted there were no visible signs of surface impacts from the release.  The well is currently shut-in.  The Pumper will contact a Roustabout Crew to initiate Ground Disturbance procedures.
properties.Root Cause: The spill was on the flowline between the well and meter unit.  The spill was due to internal corrosion inside the flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: Caerus replaced the failed section of flowline.  Caerus will increase the amount of corrosion inhibitor used on this well to prevent the reoccurrence of this incident.

properties.Spill_Desc: A leak was detected along the Facility #4AW consolidated flowline on 3/13/20. Flowline was shut-in upon discovery to stop any further release of fluids. There were no pooled fluids at surface to recover at time of discovery, only surface staining.
properties.Root Cause: 10" carbon steel flowline failed due to external corrosion. Estimated point of failure was at the 12 o'clock position.
properties.Preventative Measure: 25 feet of existing flowline was removed and replaced with 4 inch poly pipe. Flowline pressure tested to confirm repairs on March 18, 2020.

properties.Spill_Desc: 4:00pm  16 Mar 20 we discovered a leak coming from the Janet pad dualpac. I had the well shut in and isolated the leak. Within 20 min had a Vac truck pull all standing fluid inside and outside the building. Total amount of fluid we determined was around 8bbls with 5 being contained within the building’s sump and 3 spilling out of the building on the surrounding ground. Continuing excavation of all contaiminated soil. When Cleanup is complete I have instructed Absaroka Energy and Environmental Solutions, LLC. To conduct soil samples.
properties.Root Cause: Corrosion on a flowline caused a pinhole.
properties.Preventative Measure: Replaced the failed sch40 flowline with a sch80. Will conduct a routine ultrasound of flowlines to determine if a failure will occur.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK was notified by Occidental Petroleum about the Cosslett #3 flowline release. Upon notification of the release, KPK immediately shut-in the flowline. Excavation equipment was brought in to remove surface staining only. Additional excavation could not be performed due to co-located flowlines in the area. A hydrovac unit will be needed to continue excavation activities.  No pooled liquids were present upon arrival at the location of the release. Based on the observation of minimal surface staining, it is estimated that the release was less than 1 bbl of fluid. Spill/Release notification is being submitted based on the Corrective Action requirement of Field Inspection Report (Doc #697600854).
properties.Root Cause: Area will be hydrovac'd to access damaged section of flowline and further investigate root cause of of the flowline failure. Flowline failure occurred due to ground settling as a result of recent installation of flowline by separate operator.
properties.Preventative Measure: Damaged section of flowline will be repaired and flowline will be pressure tested before being brought back into service.

properties.Spill_Desc: Produced water released from a gathering system.  Release point located in grazing pasture.  Water released flowed accross pasture and potentailly contacted agricultural wetland.  Gathering system was isolated.  Area fenced off to mitigate cattle access.  No recovered water.
flow line failed pressure test beening investigated.
properties.Root Cause: The failed portion of flowline was between the wellhead for the N. Parachute MF 10B E09 696 well and the associated meter skid.  After inspecting the flowline, it was determined that the failure was due to external corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed portion of flowline was replaced with brand new pipe.

properties.Spill_Desc: The release was discovered by a third party and reported to BP.  The release was stopped by isolating water transfer system.  No water was recovered from the release area.     Spill volume confirmed on 4/13/2020
