However, the pressure must have facilitated a weak spot to break through causing the leak.  The line has been excavated and is being repaired.  Corrosion on the carbon steel pipeline is the root cause of the leak.  Soil samples were collected from the impacted area and the pot-hole excavation.  The highest TPH reading from a PetroFlag screen of the soils was 165 ppm.  Confirmatory soil samples have been sent ot the lab.
properties.Root Cause: A pressure test conducted the day before on the same pipeline (which was maintained at 60 psi for 1-hour) is believed to cause a small, 1” hole on the upper (11 o’clock) portion of the pipeline. Upon discovery of the wet soils from a TEP pumper, the pipeline was shut off and the section isolated. A hydro-vac truck was used to hydro excavate soils to the of the pipeline for repairs to be made. Hydro-vac'd soils were hauled to the Rulison Centralized E&P facility for management.
properties.Preventative Measure: Continue with routine pressure testing and necessary repairs

properties.Spill_Desc: Produced water was observed on the pad surface during a routine site visit. The failed line was identified as a dump line and de-energized. No fluid has left the pad surface and there is no threat of fluid leaving the pad surface.
properties.Root Cause: The failure occurred downstream of the production separator connected to Tank 84128. The root cause was determined to be corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed piping will be replaced with stainless steel piping.

properties.Spill_Desc: Field Specialist found spill while conducting routine duties.  The flowline was isolated and vac truck pulled reamaining fluid off the line.  Standing fluid was recovered and returned to the system.  Area will be water-washed with freshwater from Main Water Plant.

The night operator identified a plumbing leak on the inlet to the gun barrel tank. All equipment was shut in and the spill was contained inside the secondary containment.  Water trucks have been dispatched to the location to remove all standing liquid inside the secondary containment.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the release is due to internal corrosion of the inlet piping to the gun barrel tank.
properties.Preventative Measure: The schedule 40 carbon steel piping has been taken out of service.  The inlet piping will be replaced with schedule 80 carbon steel to prevent reoccurrence of the spill.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On December 6, 2020, approximately 1.7 barrels of hydrocarbons were released to the ground surface outside of containment due to a flowline failure at the MAB 15-5HZ wellhead. Soil excavation activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: During a routine inspection, a release was discovered due to a flowline failure at the wellhead.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline was repaired. A copy of the MAB 15-5 flowline pressure test is attached.

properties.Spill_Desc: A flowline failure was discovered on the flowline connected to the N. PARACHUTE #EF10D D19B 595 well during daily production trending. The line was pressure tested and failed the pressure test. The line has been de-energized and the failure point was daylighted.  A soil sample was collected from the point of release on 12/10/2020.  Sample results will be presented to the COGCC once they have been received.
properties.Root Cause: The failure occurred immediatley beneath the ninety degree elbow where the flowline transititions from subsurface to the pad surface. This transition is approximately six feet below the meter skid connected to the 10D well. The root cause was determined to be internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed piping was replaced. Daily review of production data will continue to be trended in order to catch any potential failures.

properties.Spill_Desc: On December 17, 2020, a release occurred from a buried produced water line at the Razor 08E tank battery. Approximately 1 bbl of produced water was released. The cause of this release is currently under investigation. The line was immediately isolated, and a crew was dispatched to recover any free liquids.
properties.Root Cause: Approximately 1 bbl of produced was was released. On a carbon steel piping section, the coating appears to have been compromised, allowing external corrosion to be accelerated when combined with acidic soil conditions. This corrosion led to a pinhole leak in the piping.  The coating damage appears to be a result of poor installation craftsmanship and no cathodic protection in place.
properties.Preventative Measure: The section of line was isolated. Faulty carbon steel section of piping has been replaced with poly piping. Other sections of carbon steel piping at this facility have been evaluated and deemed fit for service. We are adding anodes to remaining carbon steel for cathodic protection. Going forward, all carbon steel applications will continue to be externally coated, but will also be evaluated for appropriate cathodic protection systems to aid in corrosion mitigation.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: An oil line on the Pronghorn D-28 well pad was responsible for releasing approximately 600 bbls of oil to the ground and subsurface. The line was isolated and remediation efforts are underway. The cause of the release is currently under investigation. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis. Analytical results will be included in a supplemental eForm 19.
The dumpline failed at the separator, the operator identified gas bubbling from the ground. The dumpline will be excavated to identify failure point, potential impacts and to make necessary repairs.

Gasket failed on 1" Ballon Valve on WAG-Skid.  Field Specialist isolated the line, notified supervisor, then called a Vac-Truck to remove standing fluids.  Area was washed with fresh water from the Main Water Plant.
properties.Root Cause: Operator discovered leaking valve at the well's WAG skid during daily routine duties, isolated line, made all proper notifications and replaced leaking valve.  Valve's internal gasket had failed.
properties.Preventative Measure: Replaced valve.

properties.Spill_Desc: PDC discovered a recent reportable spill on the Donn Lefflee due to a broken water inlet valve. The release has been stopped, all fluid has been contained on site and recovery efforts are under way.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: On January 4, 2021, extreme temperatures compromised the produced water dump on the North Platte K-O-28HNC separator resulting in approximately 5 barrels of produced fluids being released outside containment. The releases was completely contained to the well pad. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Confirmation soil samples will be collect and submitted for laboratory analysis.
properties.Root Cause:
On January 4, 2021, extreme temperatures compromised the produced water dump on the North Platte K-O-28HNC separator
resulting in approximately 5 barrels of produced fluids being released outside containment. The release was completely contained to
the well pad.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed equipment will be replaced and will be monitored according to routine maintenance intervals.

properties.Spill_Desc: A frozen dump line caused approximately 2 gallons to spill inside containment and mist outside containment at the Koehler 1, 2 (40.46668, -104.646689), Section 22 T6N R65W. Groundwater has not impacted. Surface owner and local government notifications are in process. A form 19 will be submitted within 72 hours of release discovery.
properties.Root Cause: On January 7, 2022, a pressure release valve was activated after the water/oil leg froze due to the pilot light went out on the burner, consequently releasing approximately 2 gallons of oil.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pressure release valve was activated and performed to its intended purpose. This pressure release valve will continually be monitored for similar occurrences in the future.

properties.Spill_Desc: On the morning of January 11, 2022, during hot oiling operations on the oil dump line, the line failed resulting in a release in the separator housing within unlined secondary containment. The release caused a fire and in response, incident command was set up and the separator was isolated from the shut-in facility. The fire was naturally extinguished. Further investigation will be conducted to verify the integrity of the line. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. A waste characterization sample from the source area will be collected and submitted for analysis of COGCC Table 915-1 constituents. If impacts are confirmed beneath the separator housing, confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for the Table 915-1 constituents present in the waste characterization sample.
properties.Root Cause: On the morning of January 11, 2022, during hot oiling operations on the oil dump line, the line failed resulting in a release in the separator housing within unlined secondary containment. The release caused a fire and in response, incident command was set up and the separator was isolated from the shut-in facility. The fire was naturally extinguished. Further investigation will be conducted to verify the integrity of the line. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. A waste characterization sample from the source area will be collected and submitted for analysis of COGCC Table 915-1 constituents. If impacts are confirmed beneath the separator housing, confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for the Table 915-1 constituents present in the waste characterization sample
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed equipment will be repaired and will be monitored according to routine maintenance intervals.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised valve on a produced water load line resulted in approximately 6 barrels of produced water being released inside of lined secondary containment. The release was completely contained in lined secondary containment. The pooled product was removed via vac truck. Impacted ballast material will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Photographic evidence will be provided demonstrating the removal of impacted containment fill and the condition of the liner following remediation efforts.
properties.Root Cause: A 3" nipple made of schedule 40 steel near the ball valve corroded, causing the release of fluids within lined secondary containment.
properties.Preventative Measure:
The nipple has been replaced with schedule 80 steel (double the thickness) to prevent future corrosion. The Operations personnel
were reminded to do thorough checks of the tanks during their weekly inspections.

properties.Spill_Desc: On the morning of January 11, 2022, the lease operator found a failed flowline had released an unknown quantity of multiphase fluid that daylighted to surface. The wellhead and flowline were shut-in. Further investigation will be conducted to verify the integrity of the line. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. A waste characterization sample from the source area will be collected and submitted for analysis of COGCC Table 915-1 constituents. If impacts are confirmed beneath the separator housing, confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for the Table 915-1 constituents present in the waste characterization sample.
properties.Root Cause:
On the morning of January 11, 2022, the lease operator found a failed flowline had released an unknown quantity of multiphase fluid
that daylighted to the surface. The wellhead and flowline were shut-in.  The root cause of the failure was corrosion.  Exact details regarding the mechanism (internal versus external) and location (top versus bottom of flowline) of the corrosion are not known at this time.
properties.Preventative Measure: Further investigation is being conducted to verify the integrity of the line.  The flowline has been flushed and both ends have been capped.

properties.Spill_Desc: While cleaning up what was originally believed to be a non-reportable release at a separator on the Anschutz Equus Farms 4-62-33 SWNW pad, the release became State reportable on January 11, 2022, due to the quantity of impacted soils excavated exceeded 10 cubic yards. The impacted soil will be removed and confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis in accordance with Table 915-1. The area is located within High Priority Habitat for Pronghorn winter concentration. In an effort to mitigate disturbance to wildlife, HPR proposed to CPW to limit working hours from 9:00 AM  to 3:00 PM.

The Operator arrived on location to find a fitting around a bull plug on the separator pack had corroded and was misting produced water. The Operator had been on location the day prior and stated that this condition was not present at that time. The line to the separator was isolated and  the associated well was shut in. He reported his finding to his supervisor who contacted OCC. Due to the nature of this event a volume estimate can not accurately be made.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised aboveground section of a produced water dumpline resulted in approximately 3 bbls of oil and 2 bbls of produced water being released to the ground surface. The line will be repaired and the impacted soil will be removed. The release was contained to the pad surface. Confirmation soil samples will be collected for COGCC Table 915-1 TPH (C6-C36), organics in soil, inorganics, and a source waste characterization sample for metals will be collected. Background samples for inorganic and/or metals comparison will be collected, as needed. The release did not occur within CPW high priority habitat.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion resulted in a pinhole forming on the dumpline in the 6 o'clock position.
properties.Preventative Measure: BCEOC has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A frozen/compromised above-ground, produced water dumpline released approximately 20 bbls of produced water inside of a lined secondary containment. The line has been isolated and will be repaired and pressure tested before returning to service. The impacted ballast material will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. The integrity of the liner will be confirmed before replacing ballast material. If the liner proves to be in an unsatisfactory condition, it will be cut back and the impacted soil beneath it will be removed and the liner replaced. The condition of the liner will be reported in a supplemental report.
properties.Root Cause: A valve froze and split, resulting in the release to the lined containment area.
properties.Preventative Measure: BCEOC utilizes heat trace and insulation where practical. BCEOC personnel are coached to visually inspect all fittings and connections

properties.Operator Name: ENERGY SEARCH CO ADBA ENERGY SEARCH CO INC
properties.Spill_Desc: Additional flowlines were encountered during removal of the off-location flowlines for the Energy Search Co -- North Colorado Boulevard (OWP) #4 well flowlines. Removal was performed by excavating 'potholes,' cutting the flowlines and pulling the cut segments. The additional flowlines had not been completely flushed and pressure tested and approximately 30 gallons of E&P fluids drained out of a cut segment of the line a low point in the flowline trench. The E&P waste was mixed with soil in the trench and was excavated, removed, and approximately 15 cubic yards of impacted soil was hauled to Waste Connections landfill in Erie, CO on 1/5/2022.

An unintentional release occurred at the Wells Ranch BB01 AF05 tank battery.  Approximately 2bbls of crude oil was released outside containment due to a scrubber dumpline freeze, allowing oil to build up, and forcing a pop off valve on a separator to release the oil.  Clean up is currently underway.  Confirmation soil samples will be collected for analysis of Table 915-1 TPH C6-36 and organics.  Residential soil screening levels will be utilized due to the surficial type of this spill.
properties.Root Cause: A scrubber dumpline froze, allowing oil to build up, and forcing a pop off valve on a separator to release the oil.  The HI-Hi sensor on the scrubber malfunctioned which allowed fluid to push to the separators.
properties.Preventative Measure: Automation replaced the sensor and was function tested to ensure it was working prior to bringing the location back on line.

properties.Spill_Desc: The lease operator responsible for the E19-595 discovered a flowline release via production trending on the 8C well.

While unloading a well on location, the lease operator observed fluid being conveyed to the pad surface on the southwest side of the western-most separator unit. The fluid appeared to be daylighting where the bypass line transitions from below ground to above ground.  The dumpline has been isolated and de-energized.
properties.Root Cause: Failed "T" joint on dumpline
properties.Preventative Measure: Failed "T" joint was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: On February 1, 2021, a flowline release occurred from internal corrosion at the 6 o'clock position of the steel flowline leading to the header located at Jilison 2A facility. The header system was immediately isolated and depressurized. All surface impacts were removed on February 2, 2022 and remedial activities including excavation are ongoing. KPK's primary contractor will collect soil samples from areas most likely to have been impacted, and to delineate the extent of contamination.  Soil samples will be analyzed for  TPH (C6-C36), Table 915-1 Organic Compounds in Soil, Table 915-1 metals, and Table 915-1 Soil Suitability for Reclamation (Electrical conductivity, Sodium adsorption ratio, and pH by saturated paste method, boron (hot water soluble)).
properties.Root Cause: On February 1, 2021, a flowline release occurred from internal corrosion at the 6 o'clock position of the steel flowline leading to the header located at Jilison 2A facility. Although COGCC records indicate the flowlines in the area of the release are 3" fiberglass lines, the fiberglass lines transition to steel lines at the header.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK will continue implementing its current integrity management plan. KPK is also working with Campos EPC to evaluate flowline integrity. Upon completion, KPK and Campos EPC will prepare an integrity plan to proactively address circumstances that likely contribute to potential flowlines releases or loss of integrity.

properties.Spill_Desc: Summit Meter House froze which caused Caerus Sales Line to build pressure and caused line failure.  Wells have been blown down and isolated.  Failure point was identified via excavation in sales line at approx. 4 feet below ground surface (bgs) and damaged section of piping was removed.  A soil sample was collected from the area most likely to have been impacted adjacent to the failure point.  Visual inspection indicated no staining within the excavation and and field screening results via PID indicated 0.45 ppm for the soil sample.  Soils removed during excavation were stockpiled onsite with an earthen berm containment.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause appears to be failed coating which resulted in external corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The sales line was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: Heater Treater malfunction. shut off well, closed all needed valves, called contractor to start cleanup

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised common oil dumpline resulted in a currently unknown volume of oil being released to the ground and subsurface. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Following the removal of the pooled product, a characterization sample was collected from the area exhibiting the most impact. The sample will be submitted for laboratory analysis in compliance with COGCC Table 915-1. The characterization sample results will be used to determine the required analyte list for confirmation soil samples. Analytical results will be included in a subsequent report.
properties.Root Cause: comprovised valve associated with the oil dumpline released crude to the surface and subsurface
properties.Preventative Measure: Bonanza Creek has implemented a robust and upgraded chemical and mechanical integrity program to prevent corrosive releases in the future.

properties.Spill_Desc: The operator on duty noticed that produced water tanks T-19 and T-2 were showing a zero level in the tanks and called out a Technician to investigate.  The Technician arrived on site at approximately 9:14 am, he noticed the spill and called the Supervisor.   The spill flowed across the facility to the North and hit County Road 38 and flowed approximately 75 feet east along the road before stopping.  The produced water was mostly frozen and a small berm was constructed to prevent additional produced water from leaving the site.  The tanks were isolated and the leak was stopped.  Some of the produced water is being pumped into drums and returned to the system, as it melts.  The cause was determined to be a failure of a threaded valve on the produced water line leaving an out-of-service pump, most likely caused by freezing and expansion.

PDC discovered a reportable release at the Goetzel Well Pad at the separators mainly inside of secondary containment, but also some misting outside the containment.  The source of the spill has been stopped and release clean-up and delineation activities are underway.

operator drove to location and noticed fluid bubbling near valve can. they called occ and initiated EH&S oncall. then proceeded to shut in valves to identify the leaking section of pipe. the operators were able to isolate the line and stop the leak. which went from the Murray facility under the road to a valve can. this shuts the Murray facility and the Wells on pads 1N and 1M

operator received a high LEL at the pump skid on the A36A, after investigating the operator could hear gurgling at the outlet of the pump below the surface. the operator isolated the line and the leak stopped. operator initiated EH&S on call.

A scheduled loadout from 3rd party water truck driver was scheduled for 2/14/2022, and notified Laramie that no contents were within tanks. Field personnel arrived to inspect and found a leaking frost free valve was leaking inside lined secondary containment. Liner failure was identified and no free fluids were held within containment. Some residual condensate is being recovered from working surface but it is assumed a majority of the fluid is below the tank battery. Tank and containment removal is pending. Initial soil sample collected at point of release 2/15/2022 and will be analyzed for Table 915.

The surface waterline developed a pin hole on the surface of the A24-496 pad receiving water from the J14. Onsite staff identified the release and were able to quickly shut in the water line. A surface soil sample was collected and the spill path was GPSed in by a consultant.
Note: Lat/Long update -39.694125/-108.125226
properties.Root Cause:
The surface waterline developed a pin hole on the surface of the A24-496 pad receiving water from the J14. Onsite staff identified the 
release and were able to quickly shut in the water line.  A hydro-vac truck recovered approximately 3 bbls of fluid.  A surface soil 
sample was collected along the spill path near the point of release. GPS data was collected for the soil sample and point of release 
by a consultant.
properties.Preventative Measure:
Pipeline failure was repaired and pressure tested.  Continuous monitoring will occur until the temporary waterline is removed from 
the site.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised 4” produced water manifold released approximately 60 bbls of produced water to the ground and subsurface. The majority of the release is believed to have been contained to the unlined valve-can. A vacuum truck was immediately dispatched to remove the standing surficial fluid. A waste characterization soil sample will be collected from the bottom of the valve-can prior to commencing remediation efforts. The characterization sample will be submitted for laboratory analysis to determine the required Table 915 analyte list for confirmation sampling. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. The manifold will be repaired and successfully pressure tested prior to returning to service.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion in the 6 o'clock position of the 90 degree fitting resulted in the release of approximately 60 bbls of PW being released to the ground and subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Bonanza Creek has implemented a robust and upgraded chemical and mechanical integrity program

properties.Spill_Desc: A plug on a 2" valve blind flange was missing releasing a mixture of produced water and fresh waste into the valve can. A pump truck was called and 15BBLs of fluid was recovered from the valve can.
Frost-free valve failure failed, resulting in a spill to the secondary containment.
properties.Root Cause: The frost-free valve failed to close during transport truck offloading operations, resulting in the release of fluid into the secondary containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The frost-free valve was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: A leak from a Balon valve at Condensate Tank #3 resulted in the release of approximately 47 bbls of oil all within unlined secondary containment.  The release was discovered during a routine site visit at approximately 8:00 am on Wednesday, February 23, 2022 and was immediately stopped and completely contained on-site. Neither surface, nor groundwater were impacted, no injuries occurred as a result of the release, and cleanup is ongoing.
properties.Root Cause:
A leak from a Balon valve at Condensate Tank #3 resulted in the release of approximately 47 bbls of oil all within unlined secondary
containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The Balon valve was replaced. Procedures updated to ensure the well operator conducting water draws confirms that no water is trapped between the primary and secondary drain line valves.

properties.Spill_Desc: Flowline spill daylighted at surface

Flowline between well house and well head leak discovered within the threading within the pipe. Immediately stopped and contained using man made dikes and berms.  Total volume is still being investigated.
properties.Root Cause: pipeline separated where thread met a flange due to temperature fluctuations and vibration
properties.Preventative Measure: soils beneath the pipeline were stabilized to prevent soil settling in the future

properties.Spill_Desc: Flow line leaked .
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion at the 6 O'clock position on flowline
properties.Preventative Measure: Section of corroded pipe will be replaced with HDPE pipe.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised valve on an oil tank resulted in approximately 60 bbls of oil being released inside of the lined secondary containment. There are currently no impacts to the ground surface. The valve has been isolated and will be repaired and pressure tested before returning to service. The pooled fluids and impacted ballast material will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. The integrity of the liner will be confirmed before replacing ballast material. If the liner proves to be in an unsatisfactory condition, it will be cut back and the impacted soil beneath it will be removed and the liner replaced. The condition of the liner will be reported in a supplemental report.
properties.Root Cause: A valve froze and split, resulting in the release to the lined containment area.
properties.Preventative Measure: BCEOC utilizes heat trace and insulation where practical. BCEOC personnel are coached to visually inspect all fittings and connections.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised aboveground produced water line resulted in approximately 20 bbls of produced water being released to the road base plated pad surface. The pooled fluid was immediately removed and a roustabout company was dispatched to remove the impacted soil.Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis of TPH (C6-C36), organics in soil, and inorganics in soil in compliance with COGCC Table 915-1. A waste characterization sample for metals will be submitted. Background soil samples for inorganics and/or metals will be collected and submitted as needed.
properties.Root Cause: internal corrosion resulted in a pinhole forming on the above-ground produced water line in the 6 o'clock position.
properties.Preventative Measure: HRP has implemented an upgraded chemical and mechanical integrity program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On March 3, 2022, a release of an unknown volume of produced water was discovered during a routine inspection at the Howard 28N-26HZ Production Facility. Site assessment activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: A produced water release was discovered from the dump line below the separator during routine activities at the Howard 28N-29HZ production facility. Site investigation activities into the root cause of this release are currently ongoing.
properties.Preventative Measure: The integrity of the facility infrastructure will be verified, and any affected equipment will be repaired and/or replaced. Site investigation activities into the root cause of this release are currently ongoing. Based on the site investigation results, additional corrective actions may be implemented to prevent the problem from reoccurring.

properties.Spill_Desc: During afternoon rounds (3/2/2022), the lease operator found 1 bbl of oil inside of lined secondary containment from a cracked valve. The release became reportable on 3/3/2022 when the approximately 1 BBL of oil mixed with standing snowmelt inside of containment, resulting in total volume of 5.5BBLs. The release was completely contained in lined secondary containment. Impacted gravel within containment has been started to be removed with hydro vacuum excavation. Photographic evidence will be provided demonstrating the removal of impacted containment fill and the condition of the liner following remediation efforts.
properties.Root Cause: A 6" valve cracked and failed. This valve was used to transport fluids to the truck load out. This facility no longer uses trucks to load out fluids. All fluids go thru the LACT unit first before proceeding into a pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The valve and related equipment to the truck load out was disconnected from the system and removed from service.

properties.Spill_Desc: During daily review of trending data for the 11D well, the lease operator noticed an anomaly on the 11D well.  The flowline was pressure tested and failed to hold pressure.  The well was shut-in to isolate the leak for excavation and repair.

KPK was notified of a release on 3/3/22.  KPK crew went to the site to investigate.  Excavation was performed to find/repair leak in the flowline.  When the site was initially inspected, there was no bubbling or movement of oil.  The well was shut in so repairs could take place.  Excavation reached greater than 10 yds of material and depth to groundwater on 3/7/22.

Operators arrived on location and were trying to diagnose and rectify a freeze in the production equipment. In trying to do so, they decided to bypass the separator and unload the well to the tank. When they did, the operators identified gas coming from the dumpline. The shut down the operation. A water truck was called in to suck up the free product. 1 BBL of condensate and 4 BBLs of produced/storm water were recovered.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion of the carbon steel dumpline was the root cause of this incident.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline will be replaced with Stainless Steel to prevent reoccurrence of this incident.

properties.Spill_Desc: A third party water hauler’s transfer hose ruptured while transferring produced water to the Critter Creek 24 production tanks. The ruptured hose resulted in approximately 7 bbls of produced water being released to the ground surface. The release was contained to the road base plated pad surface. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with COGCC Table 915-1.

A failure on an above ground bulk water line resulted in approximately 20 barrels of produced water being released inside of lined secondary containment. The release was completely contained in secondary containment. The water line has been isolated, and production re-routed. Pooled product was removed via vac truck. Impacted material will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Photographic documentation of clean-up activities will be provided in a supplemental Form 19 following the successful conclusion of remediation.
properties.Root Cause: Corrosion on the main water line to the water tank resulted in failure of the line which resulted in approximately 20 barrels of produced water being released inside of lined secondary containment. The release was completely contained in secondary containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed section of water line was removed and replaced with schedule 80 pipe.

properties.Spill_Desc: Connection at the treater failed; produced fluid filled and overflowed the containment berm; winds blew fluid into nearby wheat crop and banks of water evaporation pits; a mix of oil and produced water was outside the containment area; some oil was found in the water pits.  Producing wells were shut-in, produced fluid was recovered by vac truck, affected soil was scraped up into piles; oil was recovered from water pits.
PDC discovered a reportable spill at the Peschel 20 Sec Hz.  An underground water flowline near a separator failed. Spill clean-up and delineation activities are underway.

While trending production data, the lease operator responsible for the location discovered a flowline that appeared to be leaking.  The line has been de-energized and will not be used until the failure point is identified and replaced.

During routing LDAR inspections on the site, a gas leak was detected from the subsurface. Initial indications would indicate a failure of a supply gas line. Upon detection of leak, the facility was shut in, the area will be excavated and evaluated to find leak point and make associated repairs.
properties.Root Cause: During routine LDAR inspections, a gas leak was detected from the subsurface. Excavation was conducted to uncover the source of the leak for repairs. A leaking fitting on a gas supply line was discovered and repaired. Potentially impacted soil was removed and transported to a disposal facility.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed equipment has been replaced and will be monitored according to routine maintenance intervals.

properties.Spill_Desc: Internal corrosion created a pin-hole on the upper section of the Garden Gulch 8 Inch Pipeline.  Fluids surfaced in the access road of the Latham Laydown Yard.  Hydrovac was on-site to continually recover fluids that were collected in a hole that was created in the access road.  The pipe was potholed with a hydrovac.  Failed section of pipe will be cut out and a new section will be welded in place.  Impacted soil material is stockpiled on the Latham Laydown Yard within a compacted berm.
properties.Root Cause: Produced water was observed surfacing at the adjacent Latham Laydown Yard. It is estimated that approximately 30 barrels of produced water were released due to the flowline failure. The failed portion of flowline was exposed, and standing fluids were recovered via hydrovacuum.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed section of flowline was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 3/21/2022 at approximately 10:00 am (MT), Hilcorp discovered a 13-bbl release of produced water at the Southern Ute 33-9 20-2 Water Line (Sunnyside South System) in La Plata County, CO (37.08268, -107.85292).  Based on initial assessments conducted by Hilcorp personnel, a below-grade water pipeline released produced water fluids to the surface due to potential internal corrosion (root cause analysis is still underway).  Immediately upon discovery, Hilcorp operators isolated nearby wells, shut-in the pipeline, and removed all possible pooled fluids from the ground surface.  Approximately 10 bbls of fluid was removed from the ground surface via vacuum truck.  The remainder soaked into the surface soils (approximately 3 bbls).  At this time, operations has stated that released fluids flowed outside of the right-of-way, but ran along and onto an existing lease road in the area, and terminated into an unnamed, dry arroyo near Gaines Canyon.  No surface waters/groundwater was impacted.
properties.Root Cause: The cause of the release was internal corrosion.  As sediment accumulates in sections of the line over time, this contributes to the proliferation of microbes that eventually eat at the steel piping.
properties.Preventative Measure: Hilcorp will utilize a biocide injector at the Southern Ute 33-9 20-2 to counteract corrosion of the line going forward.  In addition, Hilcorp personnel replaced the failed section of pipe with 32 inches of new piping.

properties.Spill_Desc: A dumpline failed and released fluid that daylighted along the northwest side of the onsite tank battery near the pad entrance.  The fluid conveyed offsite within a diversion ditch that flows to the north and west along the northern boundary of the original pad disturbance.  Eventually the fluid exited the diversion ditch and entered the landowner's field southwest of the access road to the location.  The fluid then conveyed across the field to the north and east where it re-entered the roadside ditch associated with the access road to the location.  This roadside ditch outfalls into a stock pond approximately 433 feet northwest of the tank battery mentioned above.  Upon discovery of this release, the location was de-energized and multiple vacuum trucks and hydrovac vehicles were dispatched to the area to begin removing water within the pond mentioned above and all obvious impacted soil.  Please see operator comments for additional details.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause was determined to be corrosion of a ninety degree elbow where the line transitions from below ground to above ground at the tank battery.
properties.Preventative Measure: The line was replaced with a stainless steel line.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised thermal well on the State Antelope Y44-E14-13HNB separator resulted in an estimate of 25 gallons of produced water to be released to the ground surface. Approximately 20 cubic yards of impacted soil were removed. The impacted soil was removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Confirmation soil samples are scheduled to be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis.
properties.Root Cause: A thermal well on the south side of the separator failed due to internal corrosion, releasing approximately 25 gallons of produced water to the gound surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Civitas has implemented an upgraded chemical and mechanical integrity to help catch these types of issues before they result in a release.

properties.Spill_Desc:
Spill daylighted at surface. Line was isolated and depressurized. Surface impacts were cleaned up via Hydrovac to about a foot depth. Emergency locate has been called in, waiting on utility ticket clearance to continue excavation.

Work was halted by Sheriffs' Dept. on April 1ST for lack of a traffic plan.  Work resumed today, and a 8" HDPE liner was stung through the 10" line in a clean area, there was no impacted soil found at this location where the repair was initiated from. Clean soil was stockpiled and bermed to prevent excessive stormwater migration in the event of a precipitation event.    So far, no manifest has shown up at the office, it may show up later today.  The only impacted soil which was removed was by a hydrovac to determine the extent of the leak and initiate repairs.  The approximate amount of soil removed was 6yds3, by the hydrovac.
properties.Root Cause: Corrosion in steel pipe at 6 O'clock position.
properties.Preventative Measure: Line will be stung in and upgraded with HDPE line.

properties.Spill_Desc: During normal operations, a wet spot (10sqft) was noted close to the access road of the Horseshoe Canyon 1-22. The pipelines were shut in and locates were called in to begin excavation. It is assumed less than 5bbl of produced water was lost, will update when more data is received and calculated.

Cause of the release is unknown. Potential produced water release from MPU off-site flowline resulting in oil stain soil.  Staining was discovered by the landowner and upon operator notification the flowline was isolated. The resulting stain is approximately 4 feet wide and 30 feet long.

Operations was conducting dump line pressure testing, which failed. EH&S oncall was initiated. upon further investigation fluid had surfaced near tank battery. all dump lines we immediately isolated and wells were shut in. due to the proximatity of the dry drainage a hydrovac was dispatched and recovery of impacted soil began.
properties.Root Cause: The dumpline failure was due to internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline will be replaced with stainless steel to prevent reoccurrence.

properties.Spill_Desc: On the morning of April 1, 2022, during routine inspections, the lease operator discovered the drain line on the production tank had failed. The line failure caused the release of approximately 8 barrels of oil inside unlined secondary containment. The tank has been drained, and fluid recovery is underway. Due to knowledge that the released material was exclusively hydrocarbon fluids, Crestone proposes to submit all soil and groundwater samples associated with this release investigation for analysis of Table 915-1 organic constituents of concern. Impacted or potentially impacted soil may be excavated, removed, and disposed of at a licensed disposal facility.

Landowner Called KPK emergency line to report oil on surface. KPK immediately isolated and depressurized the flowline. All surface product and the top 1' of soil was removed on 4/2/22. KPK has called in a utility locate ticket and investigation will continue once utilities clear. Lat and Lon were taken using a cell phone in a know poor service area, KPK suspects the coordinates are off and will update the coordinates on a supplemental19 when a Garmin unit can be taken out to location.
properties.Root Cause: Unknown Third Party Interference, appears the line was struck by a third party sometime in the past and was incorrectly repaired and covered up without KPK knowledge. Repair consisted of a rubber/silicone tube clamped into place with radiator or dryer clamps around damage.
properties.Preventative Measure: Pipe will be repaired correctly will glued couplings.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water dumpline resulted in a currently unknown volume of produced water being released to the ground and subsurface. The line was isolated and will be exposed to conduct repairs. The line will be returned to service after a successful pressure test. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC disposal facility.
properties.Root Cause:
The cause of the release was detemined to be related to internal corrosion. The failure occurred in the 6 o'clock position near the
elbow of the dumpline.
properties.Preventative Measure:
Highpoint has implemented an upgraded chemical program and conducts annual on-location flowline testing. Automation is
used to monitor for production fluctuations and irregularities.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A third party water hauler left the load line open after bottoming out the production tank. As the tank began to refill it allowed approximately 150 bbls of produced water to be released. 30 bbls were contained within the load line containment and the remaining 120 bbls were released to the ground surface. The release was contained to the well pad. The impacted soil is being removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility.
properties.Root Cause: inadvertent release of approximately 120 barrels of produced water outside of lined containment on pad surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: BCEI personnel and contractors are coached to vertify the integrity of their equipment and processes during their daily checks and other duties.

properties.Spill_Desc:
KPK personnel were backfilling the existing excavation and compacting the soil.  The flowline was pressure tested 4/4/22; the line was depressurized following the test, but the line had fluid within it when the compaction wheel hit the line, causing a break in the poly line.  An emergency utility locate was called in, and hydrovac crews responded to vacuum out the free standing liquids.  Hydrovac initial response removed 55bbls.
Soils were excavated and confirmation soil samples were collected by MarCom 4/13/22.  Analytical results indicated some impacts remained in-situ, so additional excavation was performed.  New confirmation soil samples were collected by MarCom 4/28/22.  Analytical results are above Table 915-1 for SAR, but are at depths below 4'.

The spill occurred while excavating the area in preparation for a pigging project.  The 2 inch fiberglass produced water drain line was struck by a backhoe bucket at approximately 9:15 AM MDT on April 5, 2022.  Once it was observed the line was damaged, the line was isolated.  Approximately two barrels of produced water with hydrocarbon constituents flowed into the excavation.  The liquid was pumped out and placed into containment; the soils were excavated, placed in drums, and will be sampled for disposal.  Confirmation soil samples will be collected from the excavation once the impacted soils have been removed.  Approximately 2 bbl estimated.

Noble discovered a 25bbl release of produced water and crude oil from the below ground combined liquid line connected to the separators.  The line carries the mixed fluid to the midstream line for transport off site.  Hydro-excavation is currently underway.  Once vertical and lateral extents of the excavation are discovered a discussion with the COGCC will be held to determine if Table 915-1 RSL’s or GSSL’s can be used..  The full table 915-1 will be sampled for in soil.  Background samples will also be collected.  If groundwater is encountered a sample will be collected from the base of the excavation for analysis of Table 915-1 organics in groundwater.

During routine pressure testing on the common water line, the pipeline did not stabilize during the pressure test. The current volume of the spill is currently unknown and will be investigated. The pipeline has been shut in during investigation and potential repairs. No fluids daylighted from the subsurface, release is suspected until further investigation.
properties.Root Cause: During routine pressure testing on the common water line, the pipeline did not stabilize during the pressure test. The current volume of the spill is currently unknown and will be investigated.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pipeline has been shut in during investigation and potential repairs.

properties.Spill_Desc: Internal erosion caused a produced water dump line to release approximately 55 bbls of produced water inside of the lined production tank containment. The impacted ballast material will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. The integrity of the liner will be verified prior to replacing ballast.
properties.Root Cause: internal corrosion of a produced water dump line in the 6 o'clock position
properties.Preventative Measure: Civitas has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: During maintenance operations at the SLW Ranch B/01-64HN tank battery, impacts were discovered at the produced water dumpline.  Corrosion was observed as the root cause. Soil confirmation samples will be collected for analysis of the full table 915-1 suite of contaminants.  Excavation of impacted media is currently underway.

During pipeline repair and pressure testing activities, the Garden Gulch 8” waterline failed pressure test. Spill investigation activities located the suspected point of release near the valve can by the 33C pad (COGCC Location ID 335880).
properties.Root Cause: On April 19, 2022, the Garden Gulch 8” Pipeline failed a pressure test, and the Location was identified as a point of release. An unknown volume of produced water was released due to the flowline failure at 33C pad. The failed portion of flowline was exposed via hydrovacuum truck for remedial investigation.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pipeline will be assessed, repaired, and future pressure tests will be conducted prior to returned the pipeline in service.

properties.Spill_Desc: The lease operator identified a potential flowline release with the 1C-34 well through trending data. The lease operator went to the P27 pad and confirmed the flowline release, shut in the well for repair.

While conducting regular operations, the lease operator identified a produced water smell coming from the production skid area.  Upon further investigation, it was determined that the 1E-34 well flowline had developed a release.  The well was shut in and notifications were made.

While conducting monthly pressure testing on the location, the lease operator determined the water transfer dumpline failed pressure testing.  The dumpline was shut in and proper notifications were completed.

While conducting monthly pressure testing on the well pad, the lease operator determined the water transfer dumpline failed pressure test.  The dumpline was shut in and proper notifications were completed.

During routine hydro-testing on off-location flowline, testing indicated a failure in the flowline. Flowline had been shut-in. Upon further investigation, failure appears to be due to cleanup operations on the ditch damaging the flowline.. Investigation is ongoing to determine complete scope of damage.

PDC discovered a reportable spill at the Wells Ranch 43-34H facility separator condensate dump line.  The source of the spill is controlled and was outside containment. Spill clean-up and delineation activities are underway.

At approximately 12:30 p.m. on May 4, 2022, produced water was discovered to be leaking from a buried produced water transfer line near Black Sulfur Creek in Rio Blanco County.  A 4-inch flex-pipe produced water line ruptured spilling an estimated 50 - 100 bbls of produced water into nearby Black Sulfur Creek.  Immediately upon discovery,  TEP shut down and isolated the defective pipeline segment; Vac trucks were dispatched to recover water from impacted areas; Absorbent booms and check dams were installed at multiple locations along the creek; Impacted soils at the point of failure have been excavated to minimize contact with surface water; and surface water and soil samples have been collected from multiple locations from the impacted area.  The nearest residence is located ~1,500 feet downstream of the spill location.  TEP is communicating with the residents to minimize any potential exposure to Black Sulfur Creek until sample results are known.
operator pressure tested flow line and it failed the test. operator shut in well and reported
properties.Root Cause: Produced water and condensate were released during pressure testing of the flowline. The root cause was determined to be corrosion of the piping.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed section of flowline was removed and replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: PDC discovered a reportable spill at the Linsey 1 Sec Pad, at the LACT unit. The source of the spill has been controlled and groundwater was impacted.  Spill clean-up and delineation activities are underway.
properties.Root Cause: On May 12, 2022, PDC discovered a reportable spill at the Lindsey Sec 1 HZ Pad LACT unit caused by a valve failure due to thermal expansion resulting in a spill outside secondary containment. A total of less than one barrel of oil was released.
properties.Preventative Measure: Draining excess hydrocarbons from pipelines.

properties.Spill_Desc: Caerus Lease Operator was on-site conducting pressure testing on the Starkey 7. During testing the Operator noted a drop in pressure. He started to walk the Dump Line and observed fluids bubbling up onto the working surface. Wells are shut in.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause was determined to be corrosion of a dumpline on a straight section of pipe.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline was replaced with a stainless steel line.

properties.Spill_Desc: A pinhole formed in the 6 o’clock position on a dumpline valve resulting in approximately 12 bbls of produced water being released to the ground surface. The release was contained to the road base platted pad surface. Upon discovery, the separator was shut in and the valve was replaced. The impacted pad material will be removed and hauled under waste manifest to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis.

A compromised aboveground produced water line released approximately 5 bbls of produced water to the platted pad surface. The line will be repaired and successfully pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility under signed waste manifest. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis of Table 915-1 constituents. Analytical results will be included in a subsequent report.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion developed on the above ground produced water dump line at the 6 o'clock position.
properties.Preventative Measure: Extraction upgraded their chemical and mechanical integrity program to limit internal corrosion.  The facility also has increased AVO inspections.

properties.Spill_Desc: Landowner discover Product at surface on his property and notified KPK. The line has been isolated depressurized. The top 1' of impacted soil has been removed.

Operators noticed a frost on the gravel surface on the discharge side of the compressor facility and suspected a leak from the buried CO2 recycle piping. The plant was shut down and operators isolated and depressurized the recycle piping using block valves and confirmed that the leak was on the 4" recycle line. Investigation underway in order to pinpoint source of leak. Volume of CO2 gas discharged to atmosphere cannot be immediately determined but is de minimus.  Leak is from discharge piping and is therefore dry (no produced water).
properties.Root Cause: The incident involved a leak in a section of process piping that released a volume of CO2 gas calculated to be approximately 5 MCF (5,000 cubic feet). The calculated volume is based on the known process piping pressure of 1750 psi, the estimated duration of the release prior to isolation (20 minutes), and an assumed hole size of 0.01 inch. The process piping material is 4-inch diameter carbon steel and the suspected cause of the release is external corrosion. External corrosion is suspected because of the age of the piping and a recent discovery that cathodic protection of the piping in question may have been inadequate. Since excavation and inspection of the failed section of piping is impracticable, arrangements are being made to conduct a borescope inspection to evaluate the possibility of internal corrosion as well as a cathodic protection close interval survey of the failed section of piping. A detailed account of the incident and its root cause(s) is attached to this supplemental Form 19.
properties.Preventative Measure: Once the release was discovered, the affected section of process piping was isolated by closing one of the block valves and de-pressurized. The section of process piping has been taken out of service, locked and tagged pending abandonment. A review of the other Kinder Morgan central processing facilities was conducted and it was determined that only one other facility had a similar piping situation, however that section of process piping had already been isolated and de-pressurized.

properties.Spill_Desc: Initial Spill report, Operator mistakenly shut the inlet valve while leaving the well producing into that line, he thought he opened the bypass, but resulted in over pressuring the line and it broke spilling oil and produced water on the pad.  Standing liquids were removed with a vac-truck. Line will be repaired and pressure tested. Stained soil was stockpiled on site, placed on 6 mil plastic and subsequently removed.

Surface owner spotted the leak, called KPK which responded with a roustabout crew to shut in well, and scrapped up spilled liquids and road base. Impacted soils were placed on 6 mil plastic and bermed to prevent runoff.  Possible cause it that the line "Parrafined up", plugging the line, causing the rupture and subsequent leak.

PDC discovered a reportable spill at the Kawata 16 sec Pad at a produced water tank. The source of the spill is controlled and was inside containment. The volume and cause of the spill is being determined. Spill clean-up and delineation activities are underway.
The lease operator identified a loss in production through trending data analysis.  The well and flowline were isolated and proper notifications were completed.
Operator identified a dumpline failure which surfaced on location.

At 6pm, on June 1, BLM agents discovered a drip on location of the Baldy Creek 2-20 and notified Jim Graves (Vision Energy pumper). First thing on June 2, 2022, Jim traveled to location, closed the valve causing the drip. He determined that a wild animal (likely a bear) broke the barrier surrounding the well head and rubbed on the equipment, opening the valve that caused the leak.  In short: valve was closed and replaced by a plug, all parties agreed no water was impacted, Baldy Creek was in no way affected, no produced water left the location and only a 10'x10' area was affected by the spill. Vision understood that the volume was less than 1 bbl before the 24 hour expiration. Notification was still completed because of proximity to waters of Colorado. Soil sampling was completed - test results are delayed due to COVID.  Attached is a comprehensive description of the incident as first reported via email to both COGCC and BLM on June 2, 2022.

On June 9th 2022, KPK crews were conducting airline pressure testing at the facility in the SW/4 of Section 2, T1N-R67W on or near the Camenisch #1 Well location. During the pressure testing KPK crews mistakenly turned on the wrong valve running to the cut and plugged flowline that had previously released due to corrosion and damage. On June 9, 2022, Alex Ahmadian with Apex was coming to the site for a weekly inspection when he discovered the spill at 2:00 PM. After efforts to reach KPK, COGCC reached out to MarCom personnel (third party contractor for KPK), and MarCom personnel dispatched crews to the site. Excavation and removal of source and impacts began immediately using a vac truck.

An LDAR tech was conducting a LDAR inspection on the L15, and detected vapors. He completed a pressure test to verify the failure. The lines failed the pressure test. He shut in the associated wells and reported his findings.
properties.Root Cause: An LDAR tech was conducting a LDAR inspection on the L15, and detected vapors. He completed a pressure test to verify the failure. The lines failed the pressure test. He shut in the associated wells and reported his findings.  The failure point due to corrosion was identified within the flowline trench.
properties.Preventative Measure: Flowline will be replaced/upgraded and pressure tested before well is returned to production.  Continued monitoring is part of routine operation and maintenance.

properties.Spill_Desc: Caerus operators arrived to discover a leak in the valve can (Can O32OU) on the pipeline right of way East of the reclaimed H29OU location. The line coming from the F21 was isolated and the line to the E28 was opened to 100% to allow as much of the fluid as possible to flow to the E28 tank battery. Proper internal notifications were made and the emergency response was initiated. Booms were deployed and check dams were built to curtail the flow of E&P fluids. Cattle panels have been placed around the valve-can to keep wildlife and cattle out of the most impacted areas. 240 BBL’s of E&P fluid were recovered from the pipeline vault by a water truck. Those fluid were transferred to the tanks at the E28. A hydrovac was also utilized to recover saturated soils from around the vault. The Cause of the failure and the amount of fluid lost has yet to be determined.
properties.Root Cause: A valve malfunctioned.
properties.Preventative Measure: The body bleed valve was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: A spill occurred during removal of a flowline from the remote tank battery to the Habel #4 well. The coordinates of the oil/condensate spill were 39.83414 -104.30751. The oil/condensate spill remained within the flowline trench and impacted soils were excavated and removed to the tank battery pending offsite disposal.

The air team conducted a methane detection fly over. The fly over detected some methane on the 7F pad. Upon receiving this data the LDAR inspector went to investigate. He arrived on location and detected gas around the separators with his FLIR camera. Because this location is in the H2S area the decisions was made to shut in the location and let the H2S team investigate the matter in the morning. No H2S levels were seen on the LDAR inspectors personal gas monitor. The operators investigation the next morning found the sales line down stream of the separator did not pass pressure test. As a result the location was shut in.

A leak was called into our field office yesterday afternoon around 2:30 PM. After talking over the release with another gas gathering company, it was understood to be KPK's line.  A  crew went out to investigate, discovered a hole in the ground.  Well was shut in. Field PID reading found under 10 ppm in the hole.  I was informed and called Mr. Leonard and he said we did not have to do an accident report as the well was under control and no more gas was escaping from the flow line.
properties.Root Cause:
The valve at the inlet to the separator was shut-in while the flowline was pressurized from the wellhead. The flowline broke at the 12
o’clock position on the line. It caused a rapid and quick release of pressure with no release of liquids.
properties.Preventative Measure: The fiberglass wellhead flowline was repaired with a fiberglass repair kit.

properties.Spill_Desc: During morning rounds, operator discovered a 6” wheel valve going to the LACT had failed, release approximately 115BBLs of fluid inside lined containment. Site was immediately shut-in and trucking was dispatched to begin sucking out equipment. At the time of the report approximately 90BBLs have been recovered. Current volumes are estimates and updated information will be updated on subsequent report.
properties.Root Cause: 6" balon valve on line from tanks to LACT unit failed releasing approximately 115BBLs of fluid. Root cause investigation determined failure of valve to be linked to winter conditions freezing water in the valve and create a weak point in the gasket of valve. Over time, the gasket fails, leading to a spill.
properties.Preventative Measure: Investigation to install heat trace on valve sets to eliminate winter freeze issues on valves. Additional measures enhanced notification processes when water is detected in the oil.

properties.Spill_Desc: On Thursday, June 23, 2022 at approximately 2:00 PM, Civitas Resources was notified of a potential Grade 1 Gas Leak on XTR's PUC regulated Martin Systems Gathering Line. The line is not COGCC regulated and therefore does not have a COGCC Location ID. Approximate coordinates for the origin of the leak are 39.972199°, -105.015894°. Gas Gathering Line has been blown down and isolated as the investigation into the failure and cleanup are completed.
properties.Root Cause:
On Thursday, June 23, 2022 at approximately 2:00 PM, Civitas Resources was notified of a potential Grade 1 Gas Leak on XTR's PUC
regulated Martin Systems Gathering Line. A hydrovac was utilized to expose the line. External corrosion was determined to the cause of the release. The point of failure appeared to be in the three and nine o'clock positions on the line.
properties.Preventative Measure: Extraction is a wholly owned subsidiary of Civitas Resources. Since it's inception, Civitas has implemented rigorous pressure testing and mechanical integrity requirements as well as an upgraded chemical program.

properties.Spill_Desc: During facility pressure testing, crews pressured up combustor vent line to 9psi, during pressure test, operators observed fluids surfacing along the vent line. Pressure test on line was stopped and line was LOTO.
A oil dump line valve washed out and was observed by our field night crew thru automation.  Spill clean-up activities are underway.

A compromised separator dumpline resulted in approximately 3 bbls of produced water being released to the ground and subsurface. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled to a COGCC approved disposal facility. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis in compliance with COGCC Table 915. Analytical results will be provided in a subsequent report.
Water line valve had a mechanical failure on the Seeley 13C-30 Separator.  The spill was inside secondary containment .  Spill clean up operations underway.

Friction from the uni-strut automation equipment created a hole in the Federal USA 1 injection flowline immediately next to the injection well.  The injection well was shut in and proper notifications were conducted.
properties.Root Cause: The cause of the release was due to internal corrosion of the injection pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pipeline will be replaced with stainless steel to prevent reoccurrence.

properties.Spill_Desc: The lease operator arrived on location and identified fluid near the tank battery from a dumpline failure. The affected wells have been shut in and a request has been submitted for a hydrovac to begin clean-up activities. Surface fluid is estimated at less the 2 bbls.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the failure is corrosion and it occurred along a dumpline immediately east of the easternmost on pad separator.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline will be replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: On July 20, 2022 the landowner notified KPK of the release at the 3 Farms Consolidation Line valve. The release occurred within the "Tin Horn" of the valve and was caused by a valve seal failure. KPK dispatched crews to the site within one hour and immediately closed in the line, shut off the valve, and removed the source. Upon removal of the source KPK operators began removing free product from the "Tin Horn" (access to valve), and from the surface with a Vac Truck. On July 20,2022 MarCom personnel verbally notified COGCC staff of the release, and dispatched personnel to collect photos, coordinates, and begin an initial investigation. Upon clearance of the 811 locates KPK operators will begin full removal of impacted soils. COGCC will be provided with a 48 notice of confirmation sampling events, and a sampling plan will be provided in accordance to 915 requirements.
The weekend operators discovered a flowline failure on the D27. The location was shut in and the proper notification were made.

On July 22, 2022 KPK operators were conducting InfraRed (IR) camera inspections and discovered evidence of a release along the AJ #1 Natural Gas consolidation line. KPK crews immediately shut in the line and attached a Vac Truck to remove all remaining natural gas within the consolidation line. Upon completion of the shut in and removal process, IR cameras were utilized to determine that the source had been removed.

A call came into the KPK office on July 25, 2022, regarding oil coming out of the ground at the release location. KPK sent a crew to the area to evaluate the release and started shutting wells to isolate the leak.  Wells were turned on individually to determine from which well/flowline the leak came from.  The leaking flowline was then shut off to stop the leak.
properties.Root Cause: A steel joint that connects a fiberglass flowline to a fiberglass flowline failed due to internal corrosion at the 7 o'clock position of the steel joint. KPK was notified of the release by the landowner, but it was undetermined if KPK was the responsible party. In order to determine if the release was KPKs, KPK operators shut off the adjacent KPK valve. After doing so, the flowline release decreased until coming to a stop, allowing KPK to determine the release was in fact there's. During this time KPK operators were onsite removing free product with a Hydrovac Truck.
properties.Preventative Measure: Increased integrity testing of lines to ensure all pressures are consistent, and going forward replacing failed joints and transitions with a corrosive free material.

properties.Spill_Desc: During pressure testing of 8" trunk, pressure began to drop and a camera was utilized to determine location of release.
properties.Root Cause: Pin hole located from corrosion. Pic attached
properties.Preventative Measure: pressure testing regularly to ensure equipment is in good working order. Piping was sent to lab to clarify why corrosion occurred.

properties.Spill_Desc: Caerus operations was conduction pressure testing on the 8" waterline and the section from the C23 (335512) to the N23 (448427) failed pressure test, additional testing is underway to identify the point of release and or cause of failure. Caerus has notified adjacent landowners and has begun springs sampling in the area.

After leak was discovered, line was isolated, vac truck was used to pull water form line and ground.  Area was dug out, failed transition replaced and backfilled.   200 pounds of gypsum and 2 bales of straw were spread over area.   Line will be pressure tested before put in service.

On August 1, 2022 LOGOS received a call on our Emergency Contact line at 3:30 pm from Landowner George Morgan that a small 2" line was leaking gas from well in his pasture. LOGOS personal responded to the release and shut the well in. No liquids were associated with the release and the line was contained. The well continues to be shut in and one-calls have been made to repair the broken line. LOGOS determined that 3.775 mcf of gas was released to atmosphere as this was calculated from telemetry and how much gas the well makes in the day.

WOC has been operating a Centralized EP Waste MGMT FAC to treat and dispose produced wastewater since 2006.  The treated wastewater was transferred to permitted infiltration basins for final disposal.  Boron was monitored and reported only, entering the RIBs and at the monitoring well downgradient of the RIBs and had levels  between 2 and 3 ppm. The discharge permit was renewed in October 2021 and a limit of 0.75 ppm was placed on the water at the monitoring well 050B.  At this time WOC believes that the soils below the RIBs is saturated with various parameters such as; boron, sodium, fluoride, chloride that was allowed to be discharge under the previous discharge permits.  Changes in the discharge limits for the renewed permit required that WOC install a reverse osmosis filtration system which went on line on June 1, 2022.  The permeate water being discharged has very little minerals in the water and we believe that the treated water is leaching and moving various materials with it.
properties.Root Cause: Discharge of treated produced water having a boron level between 2 and 3 parts per million impacting the groundwater and raising the boron level to a level above the permitted level of 0.75 ppm.
properties.Preventative Measure: Working to develop a chemical process to pretreat the produced water prior to RO filtration and reduce the discharge level of boron to the RIBs.

properties.Spill_Desc: Fuse area on poly pipe failed.  Line segment was isolated and vac truck was used to pull water from line and surface water.   Electric fuse collar was used for the repair.  Two hundred pounds of ag grade gypsum and two straw bales will be spread over area.  Line will be pressure tested before put back into service

During maintenance capping operations on 8/5/2022, crews noted a failure of the maintenance line. The volume of the release could not be immediately determined. The line has been flushed and blown down until repairs and cleanup can be completed.

Leak from buried flow line.  Leak occurred at the well location, with a small amount leaving the location.  The spill has been controlled.  Pooled fluids were recovered with a vac truck and placed back into tank at Maudlin Gulch tank battery.  Some soil was scrapped up and will be disposed of later.
The operator arrived onsite and discovery a release into the Urethane spray in liner secondary containment. upon fluid remove a spill volume and cause will be determined.
properties.Root Cause: The water loadout valve wore out and failed.
properties.Preventative Measure: The valve was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: A produced water dump line at the Seyler B10-64-1HN Tank Battery failed a pressure test indicating a potential release of an unknown volume of produced water. The line was immediately isolated to prevent any additional release of produced water. A site investigation will be conducted to verify the integrity of the line and locate and define any leak areas.
properties.Root Cause: A produced water dump line failed a pressure test.
properties.Preventative Measure: Noble conducts routine AVO inspections of all oil and gas facilities.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: During facility walkthrough, operator discovered automation meter cap came loose and released approximately 6.2BBLs.Release was completely contained within lined secondary containment.

During remediation operations of the Hein Hart Tank Battery, the low pressure gathering line out of the Hein Hart was hit by the excavator bucket. Gas began to escape the line. Magpie crew immediately ceased operation, verified safety of crew members, proceeded to the nearest isolation point of the line and shut the valve. Dry gas escaped until pressure reached ambient. No visible contamination is present.
properties.Root Cause: Heavy equipment operation. Backhoe bucket struck exposed line. Hole in plastic line released gas.
properties.Preventative Measure: Heavy equipment operation has been reviewed for all magpie employees. Additional training for heavy equipment operators. More visual verification for excavation activity with the emphasis on slower methodical operation.

properties.Spill_Desc: Around 6PM on 8/12/2022, homeowner discovered oil leaking out of the ground, called the Fire Dept. who contacted KPK who shut in the well and fenced off the area. Initial line repairs were completed. Impacted soil was removed at the release point. The extent of soil impacts was determined utilizing excavation and soil borings.
properties.Root Cause:
A steel flowline failed due to external corrosion at the 6 o'clock position. KPK was immediately notified of the release and dispatched
crews to the site to shut in the line. A hydrovac was dispatched to remove any residual product from the line, the excavation, and
surface impacts to eliminate migration from the release site.
properties.Preventative Measure:
KPK is installing an inner sleeve in the existing line. Facility integrity testing schedules are being implemented to decrease the
potential of future releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: Plunger on the NPR 22A-3 was not operating as expected. Operator conducted a pressure test, which failed thresholds.
PDC discovered a flowline leak.  The well was shut-in and the cause of the leak is under investigation. Surface and subsurface impacts are in-process of clean up and delineation.
properties.Root Cause: Flowline for well 09-376HN had internal corrosion, resulting in a pinhole leak.  Root cause on what caused the corrosion is under investigation.
properties.Preventative Measure: PDC is completing a robust evaluation all the other flowlines for corrosion.  Pending the final evaluation results, PDC is considering to replace all flowlines with new ones that are larger and designed to more resistant to corrosion.

properties.Spill_Desc: Surface owner called KPK and informed them of a leak near county road 12.  KPK sent a crew to shut in wells and begin investigation, cleanup of leaking flowline.
Operator noticed drop in trending on well 10A-24. Pressure test was completed and failed.
properties.Root Cause: The internal corrosion occurred at the first 90 degree fitting on the flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The short-radius 90 degree fitting was replaced with a long-radius 90 degree fitting to prevent the incident from reoccurring.

properties.Spill_Desc: During morning operations, lease operator discovered a washed out valve body on water dumpline.

We had a spill of produced water (injection water) and oil spill near the Emerald 51X well.  API-05-103-07333.  Spill Location-40.102650, -108.895038
Amount spilled-19.29 bbl, of produced water and .36 bbl of oil, amount recovered-19 bbl.
Date-8/21/2022
Time-9:15pm-9:30pm
Line isolated and spill path is being water washed with fresh clean water from the main water plant.  Cause is unknown at this time. Depth of release was 4-5 feet below grade. all proper notifications have been made.
properties.Root Cause:
We had a spill of produced water (injection water) and oil spill near the Emerald 51X well.  API-05-103-07333.  Spill Location-40.102650, -108.895038
Amount spilled-19.29 bbl, of produced water and .36 bbl of oil, amount recovered-19 bbl.
Date-8/21/2022
Time-9:15pm-9:30pm
