properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water dumpline resulted in a spill that daylighted to the ground surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Highpoint has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: The dumpline on the location failed the scheduled pressure test. The dumpline was immediately isolated and shut in to control any future release from the dumpline.
properties.Root Cause:
The dumpline on the location failed the scheduled pressure test. The dumpline was immediately isolated and shut in to control any
future release from the dumpline. After further investigation, a small leak was discovered at a vertical dumpline connection near ground surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline will be repaired and returned to service following remediation of impacted soil.

properties.Spill_Desc: While a produced water tank was locked out for maintenance, an unused aboveground polyurethane produced water line became over pressured and ruptured. Three barrels of produced water was released before the line could be shut in. Clean up operation were initiated immediately.

A compromised produced water dump line resulted in 1.5 bbls of fluid to be spilled to the surface and an unknown volume to the subsurface. The spill was caught quickly, and subsurface impacts are expected to be minimal. The impacted soil will be removed following utility locates and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with COGCC Table 915-1. The location is within Pronghorn Winter Concentration High Priority Habitat.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water dump line resulted in 1.5 bbls of fluid to be spilled to the surface and an unknown volume to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Lease operators are coached to conduct routine AVO inspections at all oil and gas facilities.

properties.Spill_Desc:
Release detected on the south side of the Hingley #1 wellsite.  The spill was discovered by the pumper based on oil observed at the ground surface. The surface staining/oil area is approximately 400 sf. Surface staining and oil has been scraped at the surface in the areas downgradient of the release point and transported offsite for disposal.

The flowline from the Hingley #2 comes into this location south of the separator. The release point is the flowline from the Hingley #2 well site.  A consolidated line also enters the location near this release point. Crews have excavated the soil surrounding the line and are preparing to sting the line with 2'' poly to prevent a release from reoccurring. The flow lines in the area have been shut-in and blown down while we investigate the release.  

The landowner and the LGD have been notified.
properties.Root Cause: external corrosion was present on the 3'' steel wellhead flowline at the 7 o'clock position
properties.Preventative Measure: The wellhead line from Facility 4A to the Hingley @2 wellhead is being replaced with 2'' poly pipe that will be stung within the existing steel casing from the separator to 400' south where it will connect to preexisting 2'' poly pipe.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water dump line at the Regnier Farms 1J-19H separator resulted in 0.27 bbls of fluid to be spilled to the surface and a currently unknown volume to the subsurface. The impacted soil will be removed following utility locates and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with COGCC Table 915-1. Additionally, a waste characterization sample from the source area will be collected and submitted for analysis of COGCC Table 915-1 constituents.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised transition piece from poly to steel on the produced water line  at the Regnier Farms 1J-19H separator resulted in 0.27 bbls of fluid to be spilled to the surface and a currently unknown volume to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Crestone has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On July 17, 2023, a release of approximately 3bbls was discovered at the Walter 21 1-8HZ O SA facility location. Site assessment activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic location setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: The produced water trunk line failed due to corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The produced water truck line was repaired.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water dump line at the Anschutz-Williams 5-61-27-3340B separator resulted in 1 bbls of fluid to be spilled to the surface and a currently unknown volume to the subsurface. The impacted soil will be removed following utility locates and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with COGCC Table 915-1. Additionally, a waste characterization sample from the source area will be collected and submitted for analysis of COGCC Table 915-1 constituents.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water dump line at the Anschutz-Williams 5-61-27-3340B separator resulted in 1 bbls of fluid to be spilled to the surface and a currently unknown volume to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Highpoint has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 07/24/2023, while reading the meter at King Pyles #2 it was noticed that one of the SWD disposal lines had leaked.  The SWD disposal line was immediately shut in and the fluids were removed from the surface using a vacuum truck.  An estimated total of 16 bbls of produced water and 0.7 bbls of oil were removed from the surface on 07/24/2023. A temporary berm was constructed around the extent of the release area until additional excavation is complete.  Confirmation soil sampling will be completed following additional excavation activities are complete. A photo log showing the release area is included. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.  A Site Map Showing the extent of the surface release is provided as Figure 2.
properties.Root Cause: On 07/24/2023, while reading the meter at King Pyles #2 it was noticed that one of the SWD disposal lines had leaked. The cause of the pipeline release is under investigation.
properties.Preventative Measure: The cause of the pipeline release is under investigation.

properties.Spill_Desc: Pressure loss was noted during annual pressure test of the common dumpline. Facility was shut in and the line was blown down. No liquid surfaced so the release volume is unknown and exact failure point has not been determined.
properties.Root Cause: The dumpline on the location failed the scheduled pressure test. The dumpline was immediately isolated and shut in to control any future release from the dumpline. After further investigation, a small leak was discovered along a lateral section beneath the pad surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline will be repaired and returned to service following additional assessment of release extent.

properties.Spill_Desc: A Caerus inspector noted a wet spot on the ground above the dumpline corridor. Upon additional inspection it was discovered that the Hagen 15-13D dumpline was leaking. The well has been shut in and the line has been blown down.
properties.Root Cause: A Caerus inspector noted a wet spot on the ground above the dumpline corridor. Upon additional inspection it was discovered that the Hagen 15-13D dumpline was leaking. The dumpline was immediately isolated and shut in to control any future release from the dumpline. After further investigation, a small leak was discovered along a lateral section near a 90 degree elbow beneath the pad surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline will be repaired and returned to service following additional assessment of release extent.

properties.Spill_Desc: During flowline removal, a small volume of residual fluid was incidentally released into a bellhole excavated along the flowline, impacting the groundwater present in the excavation.
properties.Root Cause: During flowline removal, a small volume of residual fluid was incidentally released into a bellhole excavated along the flowline, impacting the groundwater present in the excavation. Best management practices were not followed by one contractor. A bucket was not placed under the flowline when it was pulled.
properties.Preventative Measure: Contractor will review spill prevention training materials.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water dump line associated with the bonanza creek produced water transfer system resulted in fluid to daylight to the surface at the State North Platte F26 location. The impacted soil will be removed following utility locates and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. Additionally, a waste characterization sample from the source area will be collected and submitted for analysis of ECMC Table 915-1 constituents.
properties.Root Cause:
A compromised produced water dump line associated with the bonanza creek produced water transfer system resulted in fluid to
daylight to the surface at the State North Platte F26 location.
properties.Preventative Measure: Bonanza has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 8/1/2023 at approximately 15:00, loss of pressure was noted on sales line between separator and meter during annual pressure test. The well site had been shut in while awaiting work over and was only pressured up the the annual test. The site was shut in.
properties.Root Cause: Leak in sales line due to corrosion. Discovered during pressure test.
properties.Preventative Measure: The sales line was replaced and upgraded from 3" steel to 3" flex pipe, which is composed of non-corrosive material.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK was pressure testing a flowline when the pressure was not holding. KPK crews began inspecting along the line searching for leaks and identified the surface release at this location. KPK found surface staining and reported the incident internally to Mani Silva. KPK crews arrived on site and immediately built a berm to contain the release at the surface, then used a hydro vac to daylight the line before digging, and immediately began excavation and off-site disposal of contaminated soil.
properties.Root Cause: The 4-inch steel flowline was shut in and evacuated prior to pressure testing the line. After the flowline failed the pressure test, KPK inspected the flowline and identified the surface release at this location. The spill was caused by internal corrosion of the 4-inch steel flowline (6 o'clock position).
properties.Preventative Measure: The 4-inch steel line was stung with a 3-inch poly line from the spill area to the south where the flowline joins the main line.

properties.Spill_Desc: While decommissioning the Goldberg N 14-25 flowline, when making the initial cut of the flowline, flush fluid and residual line fluid vacated the line to soil. Approximately 10 gallons of fluid was released. The spill area was immediately excavated, and 9 cubic yards of soil was removed. Five confirmatory soil samples were collected and submitted for laboratory analysis. Analytical data indicated impacts are still present in the western wall of the excavation and additional material needs to be removed.
properties.Root Cause: Flush and residual fluids were release during a decommissioning line cut.
properties.Preventative Measure: Decommissioning crews verify that flowlines have been flushed and isolated before initiating decommissioning actions by reviewing lock out tag out sheets and pressure readings.

properties.Spill_Desc: A field specialist discovered a produced water trunk line developed a leak at the LD28 Econode. An unknown quantity of fluid has been released and an investigation is ongoing. A waste characterization sample was collected and submitted to a certified laboratory for analysis of Table 915-1 analytes by ECMC approved laboratory methods.
properties.Root Cause: A produced water dump line developed a subsurface leak due to corrosion causing a release of an unknown quantity of produced water, into and below containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: Current underground produced water dump lines will be abandoned and converted to overhead lines. These lines will be easier to monitor for corrosion and replace should leaks develop. Additionally, produced water will be monitored for corrosive potential and treated as necessary.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised line resulted in approximately 1.5 bbls of fluid to be released to the ground surface and an unknown volume to the subsurface. Operations were immediately halted, and a vac truck was dispatched to remove the standing surficial fluids, which were limited to the pad surface. The line is scheduled to be exposed and repaired and will be pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised line resulted in approximately 1.5 bbls of fluid to be released to the ground surface and an unknown volume to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Crestone has implemented an upgrade chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related spills.

properties.Spill_Desc: Northern Colorado Constructors (NCC) was excavating a ditch & struck the flowline. NCC immediately called the Fort Lupton Fire Department (FLFD) & created a dam in the ditch to stop the spread of contaminated liquid from the northern portion of the ditch. The FLFD notified KPK of the release. The ditch filled with water from Big Dry Creek (BDC) that runs parallel to the ditch under construction, approximately 10' to the west. The creek is 5' to 7' higher in elevation than the ditch being constructed where the pipeline was damaged. Surface water from the creek seeped into the ditch & mixing with the spilled oil/produced water. KPK crews arrived on site, closed the pipeline valves, blew down the lines, & used 2 vac trucks to skim the oil from the surface of the ditch (turned containment pit). Oil was temporarily transferred to frac tanks. KPK installed 16 booms along the pit & NCC ditch downgradient to prevent migration of oil during skimming activities (see figures).
properties.Root Cause: Northern Colorado Constructors (NCC) was excavating a ditch and struck the flowline. See attached 811 ticket called in by NCC. Ticket referred to work being completed in the quarry operations area of the site. KPK responded "all clear" since KPK lines were not present in the quarry operations area.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK will continue to respond to 811 ticket requests with KPK flowline locations. As part of emergency response measures, an earthen dam was constructed near the release point to contain any hydrocarbon liquids and allow for liquids removal. Liquids were suctioned out and stored in frac tanks onsite in a lined,bermed area until offsite disposal, and the pipeline was capped. Impacted soils were removed from the ditch and stockpiled onsite in a lined, bermed area until they were transported offsite for disposal at a landfill. The ditch was backfilled with clay and groundwater amendment (COGAC-pH) to minimize the surface water from the creek seeping into the impacted ditch and mitigate any recalcitrant hydrocarbons. Manifests, disposal tickets and a SDS are attached.

properties.Spill_Desc: During frac operations, an oversight on pumping rate caused the blender tub to overfill on site resulting in ~3bbls of Produced water to be lost on working surface. System was shut down and a pump on site was utilized to recover 1bbl and put back into the system.
properties.Root Cause: During rigging down, contractor back over manifold piping resulting in break in piping/valve.
properties.Preventative Measure: 3rd party contractors (SOP) must utilize 2 people during backing up trailers and/or equipment.

properties.Spill_Desc: At 6:30 am, a KPK employee smelled oil in the area while driving to work on CR 19. The crew mobilized immediately to investigate a potential release near the Suckla E Battery and arrived at the site at 7am. The crews discovered oil and produced water (approximately 1 bbl), on the ground adjacent to one of the Casing vents for the Consolidated flowline to Facility 9 that crosses under CR 19. The bar ditch is currently dry north and south of the release area. KPK immediately isolated and shutin the section of pipe. Oil/produced water had migrated out of the vent on onto the ground. Crews used a Vac Master to recover free liquids and initiated excavation of the impacted soil. The vents are connected to a larger diameter steel casing under the road that is plugged on each end and vented to the ground surface. The flowline inside the casing under the road has leaked likely due to internal corrosion.
properties.Root Cause: The leak was caused by internal corrosion to a 4" steel flowline running under CR 19. The 4" flowline is contained within casing under the road. Oil and produced water followed the path of least resistance and exited the casing through the vent tube located about 15' west of CR 19. It is not possible to determine the exact position of the failure without digging up the road.
properties.Preventative Measure: The 4" steel pipe was stung with 3" polyline under the road and extending 100' south and 300' northwest of the release location on August 18, 2023 (see attached figure). KPK is in the process of replacing its steel lines with polylines to prevent future releases due to corrosion. A 10" steel line is also contained within the casing under the road. As a preventative measure, this 10" steel line will be stung with 8" polyline.

properties.Spill_Desc: An inlet valve at the Bledsoe 9 SWD facility was plugged which lead to a pressure build-up that sent back-flow to the Grays State Tank Battery, and also caused a failure in the piping at the Bledsoe 9 SWD facility. The piping failure at the Bledsoe 9 SWD caused a spill which stayed within the spill containment berm. Water pumps for both facilities were shut off and wells have been shut-in; Citation is in the process of hydro-vac cleaning the site.
properties.Root Cause: In inlet valve was partially closed which lead to a pressure build-up that broke the seal on an inlet line to the Bledsoe 9 SWD. This lead to a failure of a check valve, causing excess water to be sent to the separator of the Gray's State Tank Battery. The flow continued to leak at the broken seal of the inlet pipe. The produced water spill surfaced and stayed within the containment of the Bledsoe 9 SWD.
properties.Preventative Measure: The piping connection and seal were replaced at the inlet line. The check valve which failed is in the process of being replaced now.

properties.Spill_Desc: An inlet valve at the Bledsoe 9 SWD facility was plugged which lead to a pressure build-up that sent back-flow to the Gray's State Tank Battery. The backflow at the Gray’s State Tank Battery caused the production tanks to overtop and fill the spill containment berm, and some fluids left the containment area.  Water pumps for both facilities have been shut off and wells have been shut-in; Citation is in the process of hydro-vac cleaning the facility.
properties.Root Cause: In inlet valve was partially closed which lead to a pressure build-up that broke the seal on an inlet line to the Bledsoe 9 SWD. This lead to a failure of a check valve, causing excess water to be sent to the separator of the Gray's State Tank Battery which was then sent to the oil tanks. An equalization line was plugged between the oil tanks, so one tank overfilled and ultimately filled the containment and spilled over the western half of the containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The piping connection and seal were replaced at the Bledsoe 9 SWD inlet line. The check valve which failed is in the process of being replaced now. The equalization lines between the oil tanks have been replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: During rigging down operations, 3rd party contractor was moving a trailer and backed into manifold piping. The manifold was broke and a release occurred whtin containment and overtopped making it to working surface of pad. Estimated release was 3bbls of produced water.
The lease operator was conducting a pressure test on the underground flowline and discovered leak on the 10C well. The well was shut in, and proper notifications were completed.
properties.Root Cause: On August 16, 2023, the operator identified a leak in the flowline while conducting a pressure test, and the well was promptly shut-in. An unknown volume of produced water was released from the flowline. The point of release was identified as a pinhole in the flowline elbow.
properties.Preventative Measure: The damaged portion of flowline has been replaced, and flowlines are pressure tested on a routine basis.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator found leak from 1/2" needle valve. Operator isolated leak and notified EHS on call.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A third-party hauling company had a spill resulting in approximately 5 bbls to be spilled inside lined containment and 3 bbls to be spilled outside containment. The impacted pea gravel inside containment will be removed and hauled for disposal, and the integrity of the liner will be confirmed. The impacted soil outside containment will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. Additionally, a waste characterization sample of the impacted material will be collected and submitted for analysis of Table 915-1 constituents. Analytical results will be provided in a subsequent report.
properties.Root Cause: A third-party hauling company had a spill resulting in approximately 5 bbls to be spilled inside lined containment and 3 bbls to be spilled outside containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: A root cause analysis was conducted with the third-party water hauler and the hauling company has implemented an updated SOP to avoid future occurrences.

properties.Spill_Desc: A water operator noticed steam and liquid coming from the roadside edge while heading to the K10 pad. The water operator contacted OCC to report the incident. Pipelines within the area were shut in and it was determined that the West Fork 10” three phase gathering line coming from the O03 booster station had developed a leak. The line was shut in and the incident reporting was completed.
properties.Root Cause: Upon excavation, it was determined that the subject line failed due to external corrosion at the 6 o'clock position. Approximately 60 yards of soil were excavated and disposed of at Greenleaf Environmental during the initial repair.
properties.Preventative Measure: Following repairs, anodes were installed to provide additional cathodic protection. The subject line will continue to be pressure tested annually at minimum.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised above ground water dumpline at the CS Bittersweet 03-01-13 separator resulted in approximately 2.65 bbls of produced water to be spilled to the ground surface. The spill was contained entirely on pad and a vac truck was dispatched to clean up surficial fluid. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. Additionally, a waste characterization sample will be collected and submitted for analysis of Table 915 constituents. Analytical results will be provided on a supplemental Form 19. The location is within the Bald Eagle Roost Site HPH buffer zone.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised above ground water dumpline at the CS Bittersweet 03-01-13 separator resulted in approximately 2.65 bbls of produced water to be spilled to the ground surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Extraction has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised nipple on an above ground fiberglass water dump line resulted in 2 bbls of fluid to be spilled in the separator doghouse. The spill was contained entirely on pad and a vac truck was dispatched to remove standing fluids. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal under certified waste manifests. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. In addition, a waste characterization sample of the impacted material was collected and submitted for Table 915 constituents. Analytical results will be provided on a supplemental Form 19.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised nipple on an above ground fiberglass water dump line resulted in 2 bbls of fluid to be spilled in the separator doghouse.
properties.Preventative Measure: Bonanza has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: On September 10, 2023, a dumpline failed at the F23 596, releasing an unknown volume of produced water and condensate. The line was isolated and shut in.
properties.Root Cause: The release was caused by corrosion to the dumpline, resulting in the subsurface release of an unknown volume of produced water and condensate.
properties.Preventative Measure: The corroded section of dumpline has been replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: Underground waterline leak from pump skid #2. Volume still under investigation. Line has been shut in.

A compromised produced water dump line resulted in 1.5 bbls of produced water to be spilled at the surface and a currently unknown amount of fluid to daylight to the surface. Upon discovery the line was immediately shut in and the spill was contained entirely on pad. The line has been scheduled to be exposed and repaired. Upon repair, the line will be pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water dump line resulted in 1.5 bbls of produced water to be spilled at the surface and a currently unknown amount of fluid to daylight to the surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Extraction has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: Land Farms, the landowner's company, was installing an underground pipe & struck an underground KPK pipe while digging their trench. The wells were immediately shut in the stop the pressure, the lines were then isolated & evacuated with a vacuum truck. KPK crews excavated a bell hole around the pipe so that the 3" steel pipe can be capped & repaired. Groundwater was present in the bottom of the excavation. A vacuum truck removed fluids from the excavation, contaminated soil was disposed of at the landfill, & 15 bottom hole & 24 sidewall confirmation samples were submitted for laboratory analysis of Table 915-1 analytes. The excavation is roughly 210 feet by 8 feet. The excavation depth varies from 5 feet to 8 feet below ground surface (bgs). Approximately 50 blls of fluid was spilled. An additional 40 blls of fluid was removed from evacuating the lines during emergency response procedures. Disposal tickets for liquids are attached. Results will be presented in the subsequent forms.
properties.Root Cause: Land Farms, the landowner's company, was installing an underground pipe and struck an underground KPK pipe while digging their trench. The damage to the pipe was enough to cause the pressurized contents to be released into the trench. See attached 811 ticket.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK will be implementing an enhanced utility locate awareness program to prevent reoccurrence. On 9.27.23, KPK notified ECMC of the flowline repair that is scheduled for 9.28.23. The 3-inch steel flowline will be stung with 2-inch poly and the annulus will be sealed.

properties.Spill_Desc: Routine LDAR inspection found very small amount of natural gas coming from subsurface line on well pad between tanks and unit. Further investigation revealed that the leaking line was a fuel gas line. No liquids have been encountered and there is no impact to soil that was found. It's believed that the leaking line only resulted in a small amount of gas loss. The line has been isolated, an emergency one call has been completed and the line will be excavated in order to determine the size and location of the leak. Gas loss will be calculated based on operating pressure, size and location of leak. A temporary line has been ran in order to keep equipment running during investigation and repair.

During daily trending of well performance, the lease operator observed production loss on the 6A-32 well. After isolating the flowline and conducting a pressure test, the lease operator determined that the flowline had failed underground. Attempts were made to locate the exact location of the leak but were unsuccessful. A hydrovac will be brought in to daylight typical points of failure. Until that happens, the line will de-energized, isolated, and locked out.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion on flowline. The point of release was exposed via hydro vacuum and the resulting slurry was transported to Greenleaf Environmental for disposal.
properties.Preventative Measure: The line has been replaced with a new carbon steel line and will undergo annual pressure testing.

properties.Spill_Desc: During routine activities, a crew noticed fluid surfacing outside of the maintenance tank containment.  2.8 bbl. of oil/water mix was released outside of containment.  Lines were isolated, area was contained, the release is not ongoing, and cleanup commenced.  Further investigation to the cause of the release is ongoing.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On September 24, 2023, a release of an unknown volume was discovered at the Greenleaf 16N-15HZ O SA Production Facility location, due to produced water observed daylightling from the subsurface. Excavation and site assessment activities to address remaining soil impacts have not yet been initiated, and will be summarized in a forthcoming Form 27-Supplemental update under Remediation Project No. 32663 (approved From 27-Initial Document No. 403567026).
properties.Root Cause: A release was discovered due to produced water observed daylightling from the subsurface within the separator cabinet. Site investigation activities into the root cause of this release are currently ongoing.
properties.Preventative Measure: The integrity of the facility infrastructure will be verified, and any affected equipment will be repaired and/or replaced.

properties.Operator Name: UTAH GAS OP LTD DBA UTAH GAS CORP
properties.Spill_Desc: UGC hired third party contractor to fly drone over sections of pipeline UGC's Grand Junction Field. A report noting the gas leak was generated and sent to UGC staff on Wednesday (10/4/2023) at 1pm. The 6in effected line was immediately isolated, and the point of interest was inspected for surface contamination. No surface impacts were found where the gas leak was recorded. At this time exact liquid volume is unknown, but expected to be minimal.
properties.Root Cause: UGC was notified by a third party LDAR drone company of that there was a suspected gas leak at a creek crossing along West Salt Creek. UGC has since isolated the line has begun repairs and initial site investigation. Suspected root cause of the leak is corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Along with repairing the line, UGC plans to insert a liner along the pipeline to decrease the likelihood of this event happening in the future.

properties.Spill_Desc: operator found produced water in water can access point, they were able to isolate and initiated EH&S on call. The weld on the 4" Tee tying in the 29c to the the water transfer system failed.
properties.Root Cause: Weld on 4" Tee failed on produced water line inside valve can. Failure occurred where the line from 29C pad ties into main trunk line. Effected area was isolated and repaired.
properties.Preventative Measure: Effected equipment will be replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: On the morning of October 8th approximately 09:50 the J14, 23C-14 was shut in because of what looked to be a leaky flange on the flowline going underground.  The vac-truck was not able to get there until late afternoon yesterday the 10th. After exposing the pipe, it was verified that it was the first 3” underground 90 coming off the wellhead. This incident was as reported to Environmental on Wednesday the 11th.  assessment will occur at the Point of Release.

10/10/2023 at approximately 10:00 am, the lease operator noticed oil and produced water surfacing above the flowline corridor within the separator containment. The facility was immediately shut in and the leak stopped surfacing. All fluid was contained on the surface and within the secondary containment.  A hydro-vac truck was brought in and removed all free liquids from the surface and impacted soil.  Clean-up operations are underway.
properties.Root Cause: 10/10/2023 at approximately 10:00 am, the lease operator noticed oil and produced water surfacing above the flowline corridor within the separator containment. The facility was immediately shut in and the leak stopped surfacing. All fluid was contained on the surface and within the secondary containment. A hydro-vac truck was brought in and removed all free liquids from the surface and impacted soil.
properties.Preventative Measure: The line has been repaired and returned to service. The hydrovac excavation has been backfilled and returned to pad grade. The leak occurred due to internal corrosion on the 90-degree elbow of the flowline. Bayswater is working with a 3rd party company to analyze the affected pipe to further understand the cause of the corrosion and to determine mitigation measures to reduce these occurrences.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On October 10, 2023, a release was discovered at the MC 13 1-3HZ O SA Production Facility location. This facility is associated with the Hammer 3-5HZ wellhead and flowline (API No. 05-123-45126) and the Hammer 3-5HZ Oil & Gas Location (COGIS Location ID 451533). It was determined that approximately 4.1 barrels of fluid were released outside of secondary containment, due to corrosion on the water trunk line at this location. Cleanup and site assessment activities are currently ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1. Field notes and a photographic log are provided as Attachment B. The State Notification email is provided as Attachment C.
properties.Root Cause: A release was discovered due to corrosion on the water trunk line at this location. Site investigation activities into the root cause of this release are currently ongoing. This line is associated with the Hammer 3-5HZ wellhead and flowline (API No. 05-123-45126) and the Hammer 3-5HZ Oil & Gas Location (COGIS Location ID 451533).
properties.Preventative Measure: The integrity of the facility infrastructure will be verified, and the affected water trunk line will be replaced. Following replacement, the water trunk line will be pressure tested in accordance with the inspection report from the ECMC. Cleanup and site assessment activities are currently ongoing, and the corrective actions will take place following completion of excavation.

properties.Spill_Desc: During routine night inspections, an lead was discovered near the separator.  Spill clean up and recovery operations were initiated immediately.  A waste characterization sample was collected and summited for Full table 915-1
properties.Root Cause: Water dump line failed by erosion which formed a pin hole at the valve.  This was caused by small volume of sand in the system.
properties.Preventative Measure: Replace valve with a more robust water dump in tandem with a choke nipple to minimize differential pressure and velocity through the dump valve.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised valve on the Pronghorn 31-34-18HNB separator resulted in 3 bbls of fluid to be spilled outside containment. The spill was contained entirely on pad and a vac truck was dispatched to begin the surface clean-up. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised valve on the Pronghorn 31-34-18HNB separator resulted in 3 bbls of fluid to be spilled outside containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: Bonanza has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: Work over rig saw steam coming up from ground. Called operator. Operator isolated flow line and initiated EHS on call.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water dump line associated with the State Pronghorn 31-34-16HNB separator resulted in a currently unknown volume of fluid to daylight to the surface. Upon discovery the line was immediately shut in and the spill was contained entirely on pad. The line has been scheduled to be exposed and repaired. Upon repair, the line will be pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water dump line associated with the State Pronghorn 31-34-16HNB separator resulted in a currently unknown volume of fluid to daylight to the surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: Bonanza has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related releases.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator discovered an underground flow line leak. The operator isolated the leak, called OCC and initiated EHS on call.
properties.Root Cause: The incident occurred at a short radius ninety degree fitting on the flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The fitting was replaced with a long radius ninety degree fitting to reduce erosional velocity.

properties.Spill_Desc: The Caerus Water Team noticed a drop in pressure on the water transfer pipeline on the O29 well pad which moves liquid from the pit into the onsite holding tanks. The Water Team isolated the water transfer pipeline and began investigation on the cause of the pressure drop. The line was immediately shut in and blown down.
properties.Root Cause: Corrosion of the transfer line resulted in a subsurface release of produced water.
properties.Preventative Measure: The line was immediately shut in and blown down, and the corroded section of line has been repaired.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water dump line resulted in a currently unknown volume of fluid to daylight to the surface. The line was immediately shut in and is scheduled to be exposed and repaired. The line will be pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. A waste characterization sample was collected and submitted for analysis of Table 915. Analytical results will be provided on a supplemental form.

A compromised produced water dump line resulted in a currently unknown volume of fluid to daylight to the surface. Upon discovery the line was immediately shut in and the spill was contained entirely on pad. The line has been scheduled to be exposed and repaired. Upon repair, the line will be pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted for laboratory analysis in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1.A waste characterization sample was collected and submitted for Table 915 analysis. Analytical results will be provided on a supplemental form. The location is within Mule Deer Severe Winter Range and Mule Deer Winter Concentration Area HPH.

A City of Fort Collins employee, Andrew Crecca, was inspecting the drainage for an area of new construction and noticed discolored fluid mixed with storm meltwater, in a storm detention pond. Mr. Crecca notified the City of Fort Collins and then notified Prospect Energy at about 9:50 a.m. Prospect isolated and shut-in the valves for the produced water injection line by 10:30 a.m. The path of the spill was noted to be mixed with storm meltwater, and traveled from the release point to under a silt fence, then North 40' to a "rain garden", then east into Number 8 Outlet Ditch, SENW Sec 29. Ditch personnel blocked the ditch to prevent further migration of fluid at about 1 p.m. A hydrovac will be dispatched on 11/1/23 to recover impacted fluids with disposal at Pawnee Disposal.

An outgoing produced water recycle line was discovered to have developed a leak releasing an estimated 15 bbls of recycled produced water over an area of approximately 4,000 square feet. The line was immediately shut in and a hydrovac was dispatched. Approximately 10 bbls of water was recovered. An investigation is underway with a remedial excavation.
Conducting Flowline Pressure Testing, Operator observed loss is line pressure and could hear gas.  Well has been shut-in and isolated.
During Flowline pressure testing, Caerus Lease Operator observed a drop in line pressure and could hear gas releasing. Well has been shut-in and isolated.
During oil sales, Dump Line was shut-in. Operator observed moisture start to appear at the rise near the Tank Battery. Four wells feed the Dump Line, all four wells have been shut-in and isolated.
Ldar inspector discovered underground leak during inspection.  Line has been shut in/isolated. Working to determine the volume/repair the line.

Operator noticed suspected release through trending on 11/28/2023. A pressure test was immediately carried out and confirmed a leak in the subject flowline. Based on trending, the release occurred for approximately 12 hours and a volume will be determined upon measurement of hole size once the point of release is exposed. No liquid came to the surface and the flowline has been shut in, blown down, and isolated.

Staining found around dumpline riser at tank. A pressure test was performed that confirmed the release was from an underground portion of the dumpline. The location has been shut in and the line has been isolated and blown down. Clean up operations are underway.
A pressure loss was detected on the 14D-22 flowline at the N22 496 pad. The well has been shut in and the flowline has been isolated. Clean up operations are underway.
properties.Root Cause: Failure was at underground portion of flowline. Upon excavation the hole size was measured to be 1/6".
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed section of flowline has been replaced. Annual pressure testing will be conducted.

properties.Spill_Desc: Grade 1 gas leak: A union on the condensate dump line broke apart and ignited resulting in the loss of the meter building and damage to the separator. The well was shut in and the fire was extinguished, there is no longer an existing or potential hazard.
The operator was performing work on location and found gas venting near the wellhead. The operator shut in and locked out the well and associated flowline.
properties.Root Cause: Failure was at underground portion of flowline. Gas was observed coming to the surface above the POR. The well was shut in and the line was isolated and blown down.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed section of the flowline has been replaced. Annual pressure testing will be conducted.

properties.Spill_Desc: A failure was discovered on the dumpline for the location. As a result the pad has been shut in.

KPK's pumper arrived on site on 12/5/23 at 10:26 am and observed oil-stained surficial soil around the flowline from the active wellhead. KPK immediately shut in the well, vacuumed the line using a vac truck, and called in an 811 emergency locate. The cause of the spill was determined to be a small corrosion hole on the 3-inch steel pipe at the elbow just below the ground surface (see attached picture). As of 12/6/23 at 8am, the pipe has been replaced and all of the oil and impacted soil has been excavated and transported to the landfill for disposal.

An operator was driving into the field at 06:50 and arrived on location to find a needle valve had failed at the threads, on the bull plug, on the wellhead. He assessed the situation and determined it was safe to proceed on location and shut the master valve. A trend of the automation showed a drop in pressure on the wellhead at 05:30 that morning. Resulting in an event that lasted ~1 hour and 20 minutes. Based on production history it was determined that ~2 BBLs were likely released as a fine mist during the event.
properties.Root Cause: A needle valve blew out at the threads on the bull plug on the wellhead at the Hill 9-14C (B16E location). The master valve was shut to stop the release.
properties.Preventative Measure: A new needle valve and bull plug were installed and will be inspected on a regular basis.

properties.Spill_Desc: A Foreman arrived on location at the H26NW to find parafin on the ground behind the separator. Upon investigation he discovered the western separator had valves that were left in the incorrect positions. He checked the automation and determined that the unit had been blown down at 09:00 the day prior. Reviewing the trending he discovered that the equipment had gone to sales twice between the time the unit was blowdown the day before and the Foreman’s arrival on location the day of discovery. The Foreman recovered as much parafin as he could and a hydrovac was dispatched to clean up the remaining material and any impacted soil. Conservative estimates calculate the fluid lost at less than 3 BBL's.
properties.Root Cause: The incident occurred due to the lease operator leaving valves in the incorrect position and not returning the valves to the sales position following maintenance activities.
properties.Preventative Measure: Operating procedures were reviewed with the lease operators of the area to ensure prevention of reoccurrence of the incident.

properties.Spill_Desc: During pumping operations, differences were noted in intake and pressures on meters. Valve cans were inspected resulting in finding fluid and pulsating from T within M9D valve can for Laramie operations. System was shut in. Estimating 1 - 5 bbls of produced water lost. Recovery/Repairs scheduled and samples will be collected and analyzed for 915.
properties.Root Cause: Carbon steel Tee within valve can. Pitted/corrosion from inside resulted in hole/failure point.
properties.Preventative Measure: The replacement Tee was swapped with a coated steel piece. Laramie is assessing area to determine what piping systems have just carbon steel. Inventory of parts needed first and replacement of these will occur within area.

properties.Spill_Desc: While making his rounds, checking wells, the operator noticed a suspicious spot with no snow on the pad surface. Upon further investigation the operator was able to determine the dumpline appeared to have failed. He shut in the associated wells and made the proper notifications.

KPK was pressure testing the flowline for Lost Creek State 1-32 and identified oil breaching the ground surface. The wells were shut in, KPK excavated the impacted soil (20'x13'x20'), and repaired the leak in the flowline. The impacted soils were placed on a plastic liner. External corrosion of the steel flowline is the root cause of the spill.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the spill is external corrosion on the 3" steel pipe flowline (6 o'clock position).
properties.Preventative Measure: The corroded section of pipe was cut out and replaced with a similar steel pipe that was welded in place. See attached photo.

properties.Spill_Desc:
The LDAR team was conducting FLIR inspections on the well pad when they identified gas leaking near the separator. The gas was 
leaking from the gas dump line between the separator and tanks on location. The wells were shut in to control the incident.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: Fluid daylighted from the subsurface from a produced water bypass line at the Iceman State 5N 5N 32N-A16HZ O SA Facility. Assessment activities are ongoing. The assessment details will be summarized in a forthcoming Form 19 supplemental report. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: Fluid daylighted from the subsurface from a produced water bypass line at the Iceman State 5N 5N 32N-A16HZ O SA Facility. Assessment activities are ongoing.
properties.Preventative Measure: The leaking equipment has been repaired and the area is being cleared of impacted soil.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On December 19, 2023, approximately 1 bbl. of fluid daylighted from the subsurface from a oil gathering line on a separator at the Sater 24C 40N 24N 25C-5HZ O SA facility. Site assessment activities are ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report. A topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic location setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: Pressure and heat build up caused poly line to fail.
properties.Preventative Measure: The poly line was repaired and operations have been altered to avoid future poly line failures.

properties.Spill_Desc: The operator was tripping dumps at the F25NW and he heard and saw bubbling coming out of the ground. The foreman confirmed a dump line leak between the 5 pack and two pack. Everything was shut in at the master valves. All lines were isolated and blown down to tanks.

Approximately 43 bbls of produced water were released from a production load line. The release was completely confined to lined containment. Vac trucks were immediately dispatched to recover the pooled fluid. The integrity of the liner was verified and proved to be in satisfactory condition.
properties.Root Cause: A third party hauler left a valve partially open resulting in 43 bbls of fluid to spill inside lined containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: The third party water hauling company conducted an RCA, and has implemented an updated SOP to avoid future occurrences.

properties.Spill_Desc: Leak from the flowline on the northwest corner of the pumphouse at the C4 facility going to the C4A wellhead. Flowline heads north to meet the wellhead.
properties.Root Cause: Root cause was Microbial Corrosion was the flowline from the pump house to the wellhead
properties.Preventative Measure:
NGL has added combination corrosion inhibitor package to injection fluid to prevent this particular type of corrosion from happening again.

NGL installed new 8 foot section of 4 inch schedule 80 of fusion bond piping

NGL tested new flowline on 1.2.24 by pressuring up to 1325 psi for 30 min. This pressure chart is included in the attachments section.

properties.Spill_Desc: While cutting flowlines to commence the remedial excavation for a previously reported release at this location, Spill ID: 484753, a line was found to have retained some pressure and residual oil. When this line was cut into it began to spray oil over a 20' by 40' area. This location lies within a Pronghorn Winter Concentration high priority habitat.
properties.Root Cause: While cold cutting a oil dump line it was found to have retained pressure and residual oil that sprayed out.
properties.Preventative Measure: Chevron will review the incident and host trainings for necessary employees on blow downs and lock out tag out procedures.

properties.Spill_Desc: operator arrived on location found frozen produced water, he was able to identify the line and found it had spilt. isolated it and initiated EH&S on call.
properties.Root Cause: Above ground produced water poly line associated with tank battery froze and split.
properties.Preventative Measure: Poly line will be repaired and heat trace and insulation will be installed.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator noticed underground dump line leak that had partially surfaced. Isolated leak, initiated EH&S on call.
properties.Root Cause: The release was due to internal corrosion of a T fitting on the dumpline that had a bull plug welded into the extra hole on the T fitting.
properties.Preventative Measure: The fitting was removed and replaced with a long radius ninety degree fitting.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised above ground produced water line resulted in fluid to spill to the ground surface. The spill was contained entirely on pad and a vac truck was dispatched to clean up standing fluid. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. The line will be repaired, and pressure tested prior to returning to service. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised above ground produced water line resulted in fluid to spill to the ground surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Extraction implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: On January 14, 2024, approximately 240 barrels (bbl) of produced water was released outside the containment.  The produced water impacted county road east of the site.  Approximately 220 bbls of produced water was recovered.  The release was stopped/controlled and is being remediated.
properties.Root Cause: The spill was caused when the heat lamp bulb burned out in the water pump building, the murphy control gauges froze not turning on the water transfer pump.  The Bertha Pyles 2&3 were shut in at the time the spill was discovered.  The heat lamp bulb was replaced and pump was turned on and gauges were thawed out.
properties.Preventative Measure: Western Operating installed an electric heater in addition to the heat lamps.

properties.Spill_Desc: operator arrived on location to find fluid in secondary containment, and discovered a two inch line from the tank to the pump had separated. the operator shut well in and reported to eh&s on call
properties.Root Cause: The source of the release was later discovered to be from a two-inch above ground pipeline which connected the production tank to the associated pump which froze causing the release of fluids. An estimated 80 barrels (bbls) of produced water were released inside the secondary containment. Immediate removal of the produced water fluids was not completed at the time of the discovery due to winter access conditions at the Site. Initial Site visits were completed by Caerus personnel on January 18, and 25, 2025 and confirmed liner integrity as the produced water was frozen in the secondary containment. Upon a subsequent field inspection completed by Caerus personnel on May 29, 2024 to confirm liner integrity, no fluids were present in the containment liner indicating a release of fluids from the containment. The secondary liner was found to be compromised.
properties.Preventative Measure: The secondary containment is being re-built and the compromised pump line will be replaced. The location's containment and equipment will continue to be inspected at regular frequencies.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised dump line fitting on the State North Platte 11-14-26HNB separator resulted in 8.5 bbls of fluid to spill entirely inside secondary lined containment. There are currently no impacts to the ground surface. The pooled fluids and impacted pea gravel will be removed and hauled for disposal. The integrity of the liner will be inspected.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised dump line fitting on the State North Platte 11-14-26HNB separator resulted in 8.5 bbls of fluid to spill entirely inside secondary lined containment.
properties.Preventative Measure: Bonanza has implemented an upgraded chemical program to proactively reduce the number of corrosion related spills.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK pumper on site noticed a 6'x6' (36 square foot) patch of oil daylighting at the surface approximately 30' northeast of the wellhead at 10am on 1/18/2024. The well was shut in and the pipeline was immediately isolated and blown down to prevent further contamination. KPK crews then scraped and staged the contaminated soil from the surface into a lined plastic tarp with a berm that was then hauled off site to be disposed of at Front Range Landfill. Further investigation and excavation is needed and ongoing. The cause of failure is internal corrosion at the 12 o'clock position. The 2'' steel line section was replaced with a new section of coated 2'' steel line. The excavation is approximately 36'Lx32'Wx16'D. Groundwater was found at 16' depth.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the incident was internal corrosion of the wellhead line at the 12 o'clock position. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are age, hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: A 2 inch steel flowline section where the internal corrosion occurred has been removed and replaced with a new section of 2 inch steel pipe. KPK was unable to sting the pipe with poly because the diameter was too small at 2''.

properties.Spill_Desc: During a routine inspection, a KPK employee discovered the presence of oil surfacing at near the Ditlev-Simonson C1 well. Appropriate personnel were notified, and the line was immediately isolated and remaining fluid was evacuated. Emergency locates were called in and once cleared, crews began excavating to investigate and repair the failed line.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the incident was internal corrosion of the wellhead line at the 6 o'clock position. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are age, hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK stung the 6'' steel line with 3'' poly pipe in order to repair the line. KPK is systematically replacing steel flowlines with poly pipe to eliminate future corrosion of the flowline throughout the field. Poly pipe does not corrode and is compatible with the materials KPK produces. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing plastic pipe for connection. KPK slips this poly pipe inside the existing steel flowline to provide additional benefits/functionality going forward such as: secondary containment; protection from physical damage by subsequent subsurface digging; and provide the ability to use magnetic locating equipment to identify the flowline location. KPK has developed and submitted a comprehensive Flowline Integrity Management Plan in collaboration and multiple reviews/edits with the ECMC Flowline Integrity Group (attached herein). KPK follows this plan to maintain flowline integrity and employs flowline replacement as the primary preventative measure. For risk mitigation and the elimination of threats to flowline integrity, KPK refers to API Recommended Practice 1160, Section 10. KPK also contracted Multi-Chem® to conduct an analysis of chemical contributors to corrosion on steel flowlines. The recommendation going forward was to inject a biocide in the separator for sites with steel flowlines to mitigate microbial corrosive action where microbial activity may be a contributing factor. KPK employs this biocide application procedure on a site by site basis at locations where pipeline replacement using HDPE is not possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: Condensate was observed coming out at the ground surface from the flowline into the separator on the afternoon of 1/18/2024 at 2pm by a pumper visiting the site.  The Julian Pluss 1 well is predominantly a gas well, the liquids daylighting at the surface are a condensate mist but are contained on location and predominantly within the berm around the separator.  The surface staining is approximately 150 square feet (10’x15’). KPK has shut-in the well and isolated the underground line. Scraping of surface soil with condensate has been completed. Additional excavation and line repair ongoing. Collected source area sample and background soil sample.
properties.Root Cause: The flowline leak was caused by a severe freezing event in the days prior to discovery. Temps were recorded and sustained below 0 degrees F for several days.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK uses insulation and heat trace where possible to prevent freezing. The flow line with the leak was below the ground surface less than 3 feet.

properties.Spill_Desc: operator noticed trending on well, went to investigate.  Flow line wouldn't hold pressure. operator shut in flow line and initiated EH&S on call .
properties.Root Cause: The spill occurred due to internal corrosion of a carbon steel short-radius ninety degree fitting on the flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The short radius ninety degree fitting was replaced with a long-radius ninety degree fitting to prevent reoccurrence of the incident.

properties.Spill_Desc: At 12pm on 1/23/24 a KPK pumper noticed oil coming out at the ground surface. The size of the surface staining is approximately 30'x20' (600sf). KPK immediately shut in the well and isolated and blew down the pipeline. KPK crews then scraped and staged the contaminated soil from the surface into a plastic tarp that was then hauled off site and disposed of at Front Range Landfill.  The cause of failure is due to a poorly secured clamp on the line that was likely exacerbated due to recent freezing temperatures. A new clamp was placed on the line and secured. One source and one background sample were collected from the surface. Results are pending. The spill is not within 0.5 miles of high priority habitat. Further investigation and excavation is needed and ongoing. The spill site is within 0.5 miles of the 100-year floodplain, a freshwater emergent wetland located along the intermittent unnamed ditch, and Sullivan Ditch.
properties.Root Cause: The cause of failure is due to a poorly secured clamp on the line that was likely exacerbated due to recent freezing temperatures. Additionally, KPK determined that there was external corrosion present on the nipple which held the clamp at the 12 o'clock position. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are age, hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: A new clamp was placed on the line and secured. The corroded nipple will be replaced to ensure the security of the clamp on the line. KPK is systematically replacing steel flowlines with poly pipe to eliminate future corrosion of the flowline throughout the field. Poly pipe does not corrode and is compatible with the materials KPK produces. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing plastic pipe for connection. KPK slips this poly pipe inside the existing steel flowline to provide additional benefits/functionality going forward such as: secondary containment; protection from physical damage by subsequent subsurface digging; and provide the ability to use magnetic locating equipment to identify the flowline location. KPK has developed and submitted a comprehensive Flowline Integrity Management Plan in collaboration and multiple reviews/edits with the ECMC Flowline Integrity Group (attached herein). KPK follows this plan to maintain flowline integrity and employs flowline replacement as the primary preventative measure. For risk mitigation and the elimination of threats to flowline integrity, KPK refers to API Recommended Practice 1160, Section 10. KPK also contracted Multi-Chem® to conduct an analysis of chemical contributors to corrosion on steel flowlines. The recommendation going forward was to inject a biocide in the separator for sites with steel flowlines to mitigate microbial corrosive action where microbial activity may be a contributing factor. KPK employs this biocide application procedure on a site by site basis at locations where pipeline replacement using HDPE is not possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK was notifed of a spill from a leak in our consolidated flowline from the UPRR 43 Pan Am B 4, 6, 10, and 12 wellheads. The tenants in the industrial park northeast of the spill heard unusual noises and investigated the sound to see oil at the ground surface. They called KPK and the landowner. KPK’s pumper immediately went to the site and then shut in the wellheads and isolated the flowline. KPK mobilized a vac truck to evacuate the flowline and then was used to recover oil at the ground surface. Excavation equipment was brought to the site to begin cleanup and soil excavation.  The surface staining was approximately 2500 square feet (50’x50’).
properties.Root Cause: The spill was caused by a leak in the consolidated flowline for the UPRR 43 Pan AM B 4,6,10, and 12 wellheads.  The cause of the leak is internal corrosion on the flowline from the UPRR 43 Pan Am B4 well at the 6 o'clock position.  Upon opening the flowline area, KPK has identified at least 20 additional unknown flowlines adjacent to KPKs leaking line. KPK is currently using a hydrovac and excavation to locate and identify the KPK flowlines so that they can be mapped with a gps and its location provided on an amended Form 44.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK is currently addressing impacts to the environment. When appropriate, KPK will be upgrading the flow lines by stinging poly pipe or performing replacement as needed.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK had a spill (ID 485898) on 1/19/2024. On 1/23/24, KPK repaired the leaking line and performed a pressure test but found that the flowline would not pressure up. KPK immediately began walking the line to identify any leak points causing the pressure failure. This spill reported on 1/25/2024 was identified on the same flowline approximately 3300 feet east of the 485898 spill. KPK’s pumper immediately went to the site, shut in the wellheads, and isolated the flowline. KPK mobilized a vac truck to evacuate the flowline. A soil berm was created surrounding the spill, and booms and snow fence were placed around the spill. The surface staining was approximately 8 square feet (2’x4’). The steel flowline was replaced with poly pipe to prevent future corrosion. Following the repair of the flowline, KPK performed a pressure test of the line on 2/15/24. The passing results of the pressure test are attached. See operator comments.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the spill is internal corrosion of the 8" flowline in the 6 o'clock position. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are age, hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: Impacted soil will be excavated and disposed of offsite. The 8'' steel flowline was stung with 3'' diameter poly line and connected with nearby upgraded portions of this consolidation line. KPK is systematically replacing steel flowlines with poly pipe to eliminate future corrosion of the flowline throughout the field. Poly pipe does not corrode and is compatible with the materials KPK produces. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing plastic pipe for connection. KPK slips this poly pipe inside the existing steel flowline to provide additional benefits/functionality going forward such as: secondary containment; protection from physical damage by subsequent subsurface digging; and provide the ability to use magnetic locating equipment to identify the flowline location. KPK has developed and submitted a comprehensive Flowline Integrity Management Plan in collaboration and multiple reviews/edits with the ECMC Flowline Integrity Group (attached herein). KPK follows this plan to maintain flowline integrity and employs flowline replacement as the primary preventative measure. For risk mitigation and the elimination of threats to flowline integrity, KPK refers to API Recommended Practice 1160, Section 10. KPK also contracted Multi-Chem® to conduct an analysis of chemical contributors to corrosion on steel flowlines. The recommendation going forward was to inject a biocide in the separator for sites with steel flowlines to mitigate microbial corrosive action where microbial activity may be a contributing factor. KPK employs this biocide application procedure on a site by site basis at locations where pipeline replacement using HDPE is not possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: Xcel Damage Prevention employee contacted KPK about the spill on 1.26.24. KPK personnel immediately went to the site, shut in the wellheads, and isolated the flowline. KPK mobilized a vac truck to evacuate the flowline. The Hydro-Vac removed fluids/stained soil for offsite disposal. The spill is located between the Kerr McGee Pehr Pooling Unit 1 battery and CR 23. KPK installed a snow fence around the spill. Surface staining was approximately 72 ft2 (6’x12’). See attached pictures.   The spill occurred approximately 20 ft east of CR 23 and roughly 0.2 miles south of Highway 52. Cropland is east of the Kerr McGee battery. KPK notified Weld County, the landowner, and ECMC of the spill. KPK will provide notice to ECMC at least 48 hours prior to excavation backfill, soil boring/monitoring well installation, or any sampling events.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of failure to the flowline is internal corrosion at the 6 o'clock position of the 10'' steel line near a valve set. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are age, hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: The steel flowline was stung with 1400' of 4'' poly pipe running north of the excavation to Facility 8 and 1300' south of the excavation to a valve set. KPK is systematically replacing steel flowlines with poly pipe to eliminate future corrosion of the flowline throughout the field. Poly pipe does not corrode and is compatible with the materials KPK produces. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing plastic pipe for connection. KPK slips this poly pipe inside the existing steel flowline to provide additional benefits/functionality going forward such as: secondary containment; protection from physical damage by subsequent subsurface digging; and provide the ability to use magnetic locating equipment to identify the flowline location. KPK has developed and submitted a comprehensive Flowline Integrity Management Plan in collaboration and multiple reviews/edits with the ECMC Flowline Integrity Group (attached herein). KPK follows this plan to maintain flowline integrity and employs flowline replacement as the primary preventative measure. For risk mitigation and the elimination of threats to flowline integrity, KPK refers to API Recommended Practice 1160, Section 10. KPK also contracted Multi-Chem® to conduct an analysis of chemical contributors to corrosion on steel flowlines. The recommendation going forward was to inject a biocide in the separator for sites with steel flowlines to mitigate microbial corrosive action where microbial activity may be a contributing factor. KPK employs this biocide application procedure on a site by site basis at locations where pipeline replacement using HDPE is not possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release was discovered at the Grigsby AC19-62HN tank battery. An oil dump line developed a leak releasing an unknown volume of crude oil. The facility has been shut in and clean up operations are underway
properties.Root Cause: Crude oil dump line developed a subsurface leak that began to surface inside the separator dog house.
properties.Preventative Measure: Additional investigation into the cause of the dump line failure will be conducted.

properties.Spill_Desc: During normal operations; the route lease operator noticed fluid coming from the threaded adapter from the piping from within the lined tank battery at the Bruton 19-06 pad. The location was shut in and recovery trucks were contacted to begin removal of free fluid. Snow melt and all free fluid was recovered and implemented back into system on site. Due to the snow, some residual melting will occur and a recovery truck will swing by and recover the free fluid until gone. ~270 bbls was recovered from the entire battery (Stormwater) and tank/line system to swap the part, cygnet was utilized to determine loss of tank (Recovery tickets attached).
properties.Root Cause: Piping within containment failed near threads due to corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The process piping was standard schedule 40 and was replaced with heavy schedule 120. Laramie assessed location and did not identify any other piping or liner to be at risk. When possible, the replacements are receiving coating also.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water line resulted in 6 bbls of produced water to daylight to the surface and an unknown volume to the subsurface. Operations were immediately halted, and a vac truck was dispatched to remove the standing surficial fluids. The line is scheduled to be exposed and repaired and will be pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal.
