Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water line resulted in 6 bbls of produced water to daylight to the surface and an unknown volume to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Highpoint implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: Upon arrival on location, the lease operator heard a hissing noise and determined it was coming from the flowline associated with the 7C-16 well. The line has been isolated and plans are being made to identify the failure point.
properties.Root Cause: The incident occurred due to internal corrosion of the flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline will be repaired and the chemical treatment on location will be evaluated.

properties.Spill_Desc: While confirming the 7C-16 flowline failure on the H17 location, another flowline was found to have failed. This flowline is associated with the 3C-16 well. The line has been isolated and plans are being made to identify the failure point.
properties.Root Cause: The incident occurred due to internal corrosion of the flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline will be repaired and the chemical treatment on location will be evaluated.

properties.Spill_Desc: Upon arrival at the N36NWB location, the lease operator discovered pooling fluids near the vertical section of dumpline at the tank battery. The failure point was daylighted and all pooling fluids were recovered via hydrovac.  Assessment of the soil at the failure point was conducted on 1/30/2024 and soil samples were collected.  Results of this assessment will be presented in a future form submittal.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause was determined to be internal corrosion of the ninety degree elbow where the dumpline transitions from below ground to above ground at the tank battery.
properties.Preventative Measure: The entire length of dumpline is to be replaced with material more compatible with produced water.

properties.Spill_Desc: Upon arrival on location, the lease operator discovered pooling fluid near the tank battery. The fluid was determined to be releasing from the dumpline. The line has been isolated and a hydrovac is scheduled to begin removing any pooling fluids and daylight the failure point today (2/1/2024).  Once the failure point has been identified, a soil sample will be collected from the soil adjacent to it.
properties.Root Cause: On 01/30/2024, the site's operator noticed fluids on the pad surface near the tank battery. Shut in and isolated well and initiated EH&S on call. A hydro-vacuum was deployed to expose the point of release, at which point a corrosion hole was identified.
properties.Preventative Measure: The effected section of dumpline will be replaced with new materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: Chevron Oil and Gas Company identified oil at the surface along the KPK flowline at 2pm on 1/31/24 while performing leak survey for nearby facilities using a drone. KPK crews then scraped and staged the contaminated soil from the surface into a plastic tarp that was then hauled off site and disposed of at Front Range Landfill. The cause of the flowline failure is unknown but upon inspection a crack was observed in the poly pipe at the 6 o'clock position at the fused joint. KPK speculates that the line was overpressurized due to a freeze at the header downstream. One source and one background sample were collected from the surface. Results are pending. The spill site is not within 0.5 miles of high priority habitat. The spill site is within 0.5 miles of the 100-year floodplain, 4 freshwater ponds, 1 freshwater emergent wetland, and 1 lake. Further investigation and excavation is needed and ongoing.
properties.Root Cause: The cause of the flowline failure is unknown but upon inspection a crack was observed in the poly pipe at the 6 o'clock position at the fused joint. KPK speculates that the joint was over-pressurized due to a freeze at the header downstream.  The flowline with a leak was not installed by KPK. It is comprised of orange poly piping with unknown specifications.  KPK has never installed orange poly piping. KPK suspects the poly pipe may have been incorrectly fused during installation.   KPK has not experienced significant issues relating to the fused pipe we are using to upgrade flowlines. KPK purchased this well and associated flowline from Synergy Resources effective 4/1/2016.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK will install new poly piping along the flowline.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator discovered an underground flowline leak near the 22C well.  Well has been shut in and blown down.
properties.Root Cause: The failure occurred at the first subsurface ninety degree elbow north of the 22C-14 wellhead.  The root cause of the failure has been determined to be erosion corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed portions of pipe were replaced and lease operators ensured that corrosion inhibitor is being injected down the casing.

properties.Spill_Desc: Loss of pressure was noted on a three-phase gathering line associated with the A28 Pad. The line has been shut in and isolated, and a small excavation was opened to confirm the leak. Two to three loads of potentially impacted soil are being hauled off site to a licensed disposal facility to ensure no impacts migrate away from the release point. As a precautionary measure the adjacent drainage (East Fork of Parachute Creek) will be inspected.
properties.Root Cause: A Loss of pressure was noted on the 8" Lateral Line associated with the A-28 Pad. The pad was shut in, and the effected portion of the line was isolated and blown down.
properties.Preventative Measure: The effected portion of the line will be replaced. The chemical program associated with post 3-Phase metering will be evaluated.

properties.Spill_Desc: While conducting pressure testing on the water gathering pipeline on the location, a 2-inch thread pulled from a check valve on the location and began releasing produced water onto the surface of the well pad.  The pressure test was immediately stopped and emergency response activities were initiated. Two absorbent booms were installed in each of the two stormwater drainages downgradient of the point of release and fluid recovery operations began immediatley using water transport trucks. Additionally, an earthen berm was constructed surrounding the spill path to prevent the migration of impacts from leaving the pad surface through ongoing snowmelt. Approximately 15 barrels (bbls) of produced water was released from the gathering line and was contained to the working surface of the Location. As of March 4, 2024, 160 bbls of fluids, consisting mostly of snowmelt, have been recovered from the Location.
properties.Root Cause: While conducting pressure testing on the water gathering pipeline on the location, a 2" thread plug pulled from a check valve on the water gathering line.
properties.Preventative Measure: The threading on the plug and check valve were inspected.  The threaded plug was replaced with a new one to prevent reoccurrence.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK pumper inadvertently over-pressurized the flowline by incorrectly configuring flowline valve positioning, resulting in flowline failure. The failure created a spray of condensate mist at the surface. The pressurized gas and associated condensate within the flowline exposed the line to the surface, creating a hole. The landowner discovered the spill and notified Southeast Weld Fire District who responded to the scene and notified KPK. KPK crews shut in the well and isolated the flowline. Crews scraped the surface of the area surrounding the flowline point of failure and disposed of the contaminated soil.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause for the spill was the over-pressuring of a flowline by iinadvertently using the entire wellhead pressure to troubleshoot a production issue and failing to open inlet valves to the separator. While the operator had more than 20 years of experience (including the operation of this specific well prior to KPK’s ownership), complacency resulted in a mistake that damaged the flowline.
properties.Preventative Measure: Management has met with the individual and provided additional training to the pumper when troubleshooting high pressure gas wells. The employee has been disciplined for the error. When experienced team members get comfortable with a high level of performance, they sometimes lose the edge needed to sustain it. This overconfidence and feeling of security can lead to failure.  KPK’s standard procedures are to open downstream valves prior to opening the wellhead. Pumpers then partially open the wellhead valve (also called "cracking”) while monitoring the pressure gauge to relieve built up pressure. Pumpers leave partially open valves with a lock and revisit the site after 24-hours to confirm that wellhead pressure will not exceed the operating pressure of the infrastructure downstream. Adjustments to optimal operating pressures occur after any overpressure events have been mitigated.  KPK plans to use this event as a training exercise and learning session for all pumpers at the next production department staff meeting to be held on February 28, 2024. Fighting a false sense of security in the workplace can be a day-to-day challenge. KPK’s goal is to provide workers with skills so they can be focused, remain aware, respond the right way, and counteract complacency as much as possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised fitting inside the separator cabinet resulted in 3 bbls of produced water to spill to the ground surface. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. In addition, a waste characterization sample was collected and submitted for Table 915 analysis. Analytical results will be submitted on a supplemental form.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised fitting inside the separator cabinet resulted in 3 bbls of produced water to spill to the ground surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Extraction implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised valve resulted in 30 gallons of oil to mist to the ground surface. Due to high winds in the area, the vaporized oil mist was carried off the oil and gas location into the adjacent field. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. Due to the release being strictly crude oil, Highpoint requests to amend the sampling and analysis plan to include TPH (C6-C36) and Organics only.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised valve resulted in 30 gallons of oil to mist to the ground surface. Due to high winds in the area, the vaporized oil mist was carried off the oil and gas location into the adjacent field.
properties.Preventative Measure: Lease operators are coached to conduct routine AVO inspections on a routine basis. In addition, operators conduct daily site walks to inspect facility equipment and components. If equipment appears to be compromised, it should be fixed or replaced immediately.

properties.Spill_Desc: A water surge vessel 2" balon on oil proving loop froze at the Booth Fed DD06 Eco CC29-11 leading to oil being released.  Clean up operations are ongoing, so far 0.17 bbls of oil have been recovered and 10 cubic yards of soil have been removed. This location lies within a Pronghorn Winter Concentration Area high priority habitat.
properties.Root Cause: According to the initial report, a water surge vessel 2” balon on the oil proving loop froze leading to a release. However, after further evaluation, it was determined that when automation was cleaning out the guided wave, due to it showing false readings, the heater treater continued to dump over to the water surge and pushed water out through the PSV on the water surge causing the release.
properties.Preventative Measure: The inlet to the water surge will be shut from now on when it is showing false readings until the guided wave is cleaned and reading correctly.

properties.Spill_Desc: Caerus operations control center received a low-liquid level alarm on March 1st from the tank battery at the Railsback produced water offload facility.  Upon inspection it was determined that a release of produced water and parafin occurred around the tank battery area of the facility.  Emergency response procedures were implemented and proper notifications were completed.  The release surfaced at and around the tank battery and flowed along the perimeter ditch and north along the ditch on the west side of CR 315.  Recovery efforts were completed on March 1st to control and recover standing liquid using hydrovac truck equipment.  Additional hydrovac cleaning activities were completed on March 2nd to ensure standing liquid or impacted soil was not inadvertently overlooked during the cleanup activity.
properties.Root Cause: The incident occurred when the pipeline ruptured below ground.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pipe and facility are being assessed by the engineering department to determine future use plans.

properties.Spill_Desc: A suspect surface soil staining area was discovered by KPK while conducting site activities and was reported to the production manager. Upon investigation, the spill originated from a leak in the flowline. The flowline and well were already shut-in at the time of discovery. There are minimal liquids associated with this spill. The surface staining was approximately 25 square feet (5’x5’). While excavating to the line during initial investigation, KPK determined that the hole in the line lies east of the area where the spill was expressed at the surface. KPK is currently excavating to determine the point of failure on the line while removing contaminated soil for disposal.
properties.Root Cause: The cause is likely due to corrosion to the coated 2'' steel flowline but the failure point has not yet been determined. KPK will confirm cause and present the information in the subsequent Form 19 submittal.
properties.Preventative Measure: This section of flowline will be removed and replaced by a new section of coated 2'' steel line.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: A hydrocarbon mist was released from the manifold skid when a gasket failed at the Land Fed 29-11HZ. The gasket failure was caused by a slight alignment issue. Approximately 2 barrels was released. The release has been controlled and no longer active.  Assessment activities are ongoing. The assessment details will be summarized in a forthcoming Form 19 supplemental report. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: A hydrocarbon mist was released from the manifold skid when a gasket failed at the Land Fed 29-11HZ. The gasket failure was caused by a slight alignment issue. Approximately 2 barrels was released. The release has been controlled and no longer active.  Assessment activities are ongoing.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed gasket is being replaced on the manifold.

properties.Spill_Desc: Landowner notified KPK & NRC emergency response line about spill 3/21/24. On arrival, KPK noted the spill had migrated into a dry irrigation ditch (Brighton Ditch) ~100 ft away. Brighton Ditch was not yet activated for the season. KPK informed Superintendent of Brighton Ditch of spill & requested ditch not be activated until impacts were addressed. KPK shut in wells, evacuated the line, placed booms in the ditch & Big Dry Creek (BDC) & immediately began to remove stained soil. KPK installed a 10” sump adjacent to spill point b/w flowline & ditch to monitor for impacts. ~370 yds3 of impacted soil & 10 bbls of impacted GW were disposed of offsite. Source excavation is ~50'x18'x10'. Brighton Ditch excavation is ~400'x10' ranging in depth from 0.5'-2' bgs. Soil confirmation samples were collected. On 4/4/24 & 4/5/24 Brighton Ditch was lined with geomembrane & polyliner with welded seams & sandbags were used as ballasts to keep it down during irrigation season. Water turned on 4/12/24.
properties.Root Cause: This section of flowline collects production from a series of wells which are subject to production restriction via the April 12, 2021 901.a Order imposed by the ECMC. The wells and the flowline have been shut-in since that date, including at the time of the release, and have remained charged with pressure. Based on pressure data from surrounding shut-in wells, it appears that the Sebold B1 wellhead valve has been damaged or deteriorated during the 3-year shut-in and leaked into the flowline. This leaking wellhead valve overpressured the flowline above the maximum operating pressure associated with the HDPE poly pipe and the pipe failed at a fused joint. Since the 901.a order has lockout-tagout on the wellhead valves, the valves and associated flowlines are subject to equipment failures due to being shut-in. KPK believes that if the wells were producing, and KPK had the ability to open/close wellhead valves for regular inspection, any leaking valves and overpressuring trends would have been caught before reservoir pressures behind the leaky valve escaped in the flowline and ultimately exceeded the operating pressure of the flowline. Per ECMC request, a Form 4 (Document #403859318) and Form 44 (Document #403744006) were submitted providing additional information regarding the root cause.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK replaced the leaking wellhead valve at the Sebold B1. The flowline has been repaired with poly pipe and the hole backfilled with clean fill. To prevent this from reoccurring, KPK is going to evacuate all the flowlines downstream of the 901.a Order wells and conduct monthly inspection of the wellhead equipment, pipes and valves through a brief period of open/close manipulation of well valves to check for leaks. KPK will also conduct pressure testing on the flowlines downstream of 901.a order wells using well gas to assess flowline integrity on a periodic basis until the 901.a Order is lifted. Per ECMC request, a Form 4 (Document #403859318) and Form 44 (Document #403744006) were submitted providing additional information regarding the preventative measures taken to prevent the problem from reoccurring.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator found a flowline release, he shut in the well and initiated EH&S on call. As of 4/9/2024, crews are attempting to pinpoint the point of release through pressure testing and excavation.
properties.Root Cause: Operator noted flowline was not holding pressure and shut in the line. Upon investigation and excavation, a pinhole was discovered near the first 90 from the wellhead. Root cause is internal corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The 2" flowline was replaced and the 90 was upgraded to extra heavy fittings. Pressure testing will continue and the chemical treatment program is being evaluated.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water dump line on the North Platte J-F-23HNB separator resulted in 1 bbl of fluid to spill to the surface and a currently unknown volume to the subsurface. The impacted soil will be removed following utility locates and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. The line will be repaired and pressure tested prior to returning to service.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water dump line on the North Platte J-F-23HNB separator resulted in 1 bbl of fluid to spill to the surface and a currently unknown volume to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Bonanza implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release was discovered at the DP 406 Pig Launcher.  An equipment failure led to the release of 2.78 bbl of produced water outside of containment. Upon discovery the facility was shut in and clean up operations were started.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the incident was a pinhole leak due to microbial induced corrosion. The leak was located on the flange of the above ground pig launching pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: Chevron conducts routine, proactive radiography and phased array scanning of all produced water above ground appurtenances. Scanning of the line that leaked had been conducted, however, due to the failure point being along the flange of the piping, the scanning instruments were unable to capture adequate imaging and conduct preventative repair measures. Chevron is conducting a failure analysis to determine if any improvements to current inspection methods can be made to cover the specific area that failed. The compromised section was replaced with carbon steel. Going forward, all new produced water carbon steel piping is being internally lined with corrosion resistant coating to prevent this issue from reoccurring.

properties.Operator Name: UTAH GAS OP LTD DBA UTAH GAS CORP
properties.Spill_Desc: UGC lease operator check the GOV 6-1 well location before leaving work on Friday 4/5/2024 at 2:30pm. He found an oil leak coming from the buried flowline between the separator and tanks on location. The spill had daylighted from the subsurface and less then 1 barrel of fluid was present at the surface. The lease operator immediately shut in the well and all available equipment, and called UGC's supervisor and environmental staff. Oil absorbent pads and 3" x 4' booms were used to mitigate the release, and a hydrovac company was called to schedule the clean-up of the release.
properties.Root Cause: The on-location flowline between the separator and the tanks had pin-hole corrosion, causing a failure in the line. During production, oil seeped out of the line, and traveled along the flowline where it daylighted at the surface. The pin hole corrosion was on a vertically oriented segment of pipe, and the pinhole was on the north side of the pipe.
properties.Preventative Measure: UGC has removed the failed segment of line, and replaced it with a new segment of line.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release was discovered at the Wells Ranch BB01 Econonode Facility. An equipment failure led to a currently unknown amount of condensate and produced water fluid mix release. Fluid was outside of secondary containment. Upon discovery the facility was shut in and clean up operations were started.
properties.Root Cause: An investigation into the cause of the release is ongoing. Additional information will be included in subsequent form submittal.
properties.Preventative Measure: Pending completion of the release investigation a corrective action will be submitted on a subsequent form.

properties.Spill_Desc: The landowner observed oil coming out of the ground surface at approximately 12:00 pm on 4/9/2024. The surface staining was approximately 4' x 4'. KPK immediately isolated the line, evacuated it, and shut-in the well associated with the flowline. The majority of the impacts have been removed using a mini excavator.
properties.Root Cause: The root is cause is external corrosion to the 2" coated steel line at the 6 o'clock position adjacent to a hammer union. The external corrosion occurred due to a hammer union being used to join the lines which was then buried by Amoco in 1977. The cast iron material of a hammer union is not meant to be buried beneath the subsurface. The Sam Funakoshi A2 well and associated flowline was completed on April 6, 1977 by Amoco Production Company.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK has removed the corroded section of steel flowline and the hammer union and welded the 2'' steel line together with a new section of pipe.  The steel line was wrapped with pipe tape following welding. KPK will remove any other hammer unions discovered beneath the surface in the future.

properties.Spill_Desc: A potential release was identified during leak detection aerial flyover. The release was confirmed through onsite pressure testing, no fluid came to surface. The failure is from the sales pipeline found between the separator and sales meter on the pad location. The well pad was shut in and the release was isolated. Proper notifications were completed.
properties.Root Cause: The release was due to internal corrosion of the carbon steel pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pipeline associated with the release is out of service. Caerus will replace the pipeline with a non-corrosive material for continued operation of the well pad.

properties.Spill_Desc: A potential release was identified during leak detection aerial flyover activities. The release was confirmed from onsite pressure testing. No fluids were observed coming to surface.  The pipeline was isolated and the release was controlled. Appropriate reporting and notification procedures were initiated.
properties.Root Cause: The release was caused by internal corrosion of a low spot in the pipeline, which caused liquids to drop out and settle in the pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pipeline low spot was repaired and the gas sales pipeline will be pigged on a more frequent basis to ensure liquids are not settling in the pipeline.

properties.Spill_Desc: A leak was found near the off-location flowline for the Gebaeuer wells on 4/18/2024 at approximately 8:00am. The wells have been shut in and blown down and the valves at each end of the flowline have been shut. Berms were built to stop the spill from expanding. Roustabouts began clean up and assessment today.
properties.Root Cause: Point of failure was determined to be at the flowline riser at a tee point below ground. During clean up activities while conducting excavation around the above ground riser, a buried 3" light wall tee, 3" x close nipple and a 3" LP hammer union were uncovered. It was determined that the 3" LP hammer union failed. These below ground fittings were threaded. Suspected causes for this failure may be due to thermal cycles causing the expansion and compression at the fitting connections, and intermittent livestock intervention as there was not a guard around the riser above ground. Please see attached investigation summary.
properties.Preventative Measure: The riser pipe will be replaced with fusion bond epoxy coated standard wall pipe. All connections below ground will be welded together and the exposed pipe above ground will be threaded. A guard will be placed around the riser once replacement has been completed. Annual flowline testing will continue to be completed, routine on-site inspections will be conducted to ensue the there are no further failures.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On April 23, 2024, fluid daylighted from the subsurface of a produced water line at the Iceman State 32N-A16HZ Facility. As such, a Form 19 Initial/Supplemental Spill/Release Report (Document No. 403776839) was submitted on April 24, 2024, and the ECMC issued Spill/Release Point ID 486756. The release has been controlled and is not an active release. Assessment activities began on April 24, 2024. Groundwater was not encountered during excavation activities. Visual inspection and field screening of soil at the release location were conducted and a soil sample (SS01@0.25’) was submitted for analysis of full list Table 915-1 constituents to establish a waste profile. Laboratory analytical results indicated that sodium adsorption ratio (SAR), barium, hexavalent chromium, and selenium impacts exceeding the ECMC Table 915-1 allowable levels and background levels were present at the site.
properties.Root Cause: A release occurred when internal corrosion caused a hole on the produced water line at the Iceman State 32N-A16HZ Facility. This release has been controlled and is no longer active.
properties.Preventative Measure: The release has been controlled and the equipment has been repaired. Additionally, corrosion inhibitors are being used to help decrease and manage internal corrosion.

properties.Spill_Desc: Oil was observed coming out at the ground surface on agricultural land on 4/23/2024 by a pumper visiting the site. The spill resulted in oil flowing from the release point into the previous excavation as well as a section of the dry drainage ditch running parallel to the road. KPK immediately isolated the line and shut-in the wells feeding the line. KPK crews then scraped and staged the contaminated soil from the surface onto a plastic tarp that was then hauled off site and disposed of at Front Range Landfill. This spill is directly adjacent to the Milton Nelson site Rem ID 23610. Excavation activities are ongoing at this site.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause is external corrosion at the 6 o'clock position on the flowline. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are age, hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK stung the 8'' steel line with 4'' poly piping 500' south to join with the existing poly line. KPK is systematically replacing steel flowlines with poly pipe to eliminate future corrosion of the flowline throughout the field. Poly pipe does not corrode and is compatible with the materials KPK produces. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing plastic pipe for connection. KPK slips this poly pipe inside the existing steel flowline to provide additional benefits/functionality going forward such as: secondary containment; protection from physical damage by subsequent subsurface digging; and provide the ability to use magnetic locating equipment to identify the flowline location. KPK has developed and submitted a comprehensive Flowline Integrity Management Plan in collaboration and multiple reviews/edits with the ECMC Flowline Integrity Group (attached herein). KPK follows this plan to maintain flowline integrity and employs flowline replacement as the primary preventative measure. For risk mitigation and the elimination of threats to flowline integrity, KPK refers to API Recommended Practice 1160, Section 10. KPK also contracted Multi-Chem® to conduct an analysis of chemical contributors to corrosion on steel flowlines. The recommendation going forward was to inject a biocide in the separator for sites with steel flowlines to mitigate microbial corrosive action where microbial activity may be a contributing factor. KPK employs this biocide application procedure on a site by site basis at locations where pipeline replacement using HDPE is not possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: On April 24, 2024, a release was discovered at the Chesnut 27 3/4 Pad when oil was observed on the ground surface adjacent to the balon valve of the oil dump line of the Chesnut 27O-201 separator. On April 25, 2024, one soil sample (WASTE CHAR) was collected from impacted source material at the point of release at approximately 1-foot bgs and submitted for analysis of the full Table 915-1 analytical suite. On May 15, 2024, a second waste characterization soil sample (WC02) was collected at 11 feet bgs and submitted for analysis of the full Table 915-1 analytical suite.  All excavation activities have been conducted via hydro-vacuum excavation and approximately 110 barrels of slurry was removed and transported to Republic Landfill for disposal under PDC waste manifests.
properties.Root Cause: Produced fluid had settled inside of the oil dump line of the shut in Chesnut 27O-201 separator. Over the winter months the fluid inside the line froze and caused the balon valve on the dump line to crack. When the fluid thawed it leaked onto the ground surface thus triggering a release.
properties.Preventative Measure: In order to prevent this issue from reoccurring, PDC will ensure that all shut in separator dump lines will remain open so produced fluids are not trapped within them. Further, upstream lines will be locked to prevent any fluids from entering equipment that is shut in or not in use.

properties.Spill_Desc: During an ECMC field inspection at the Propst B-2 wellhead and production facility, it was reported to Western Operating that an above ground storage tank (AST) onsite was overflowing and causing a release of fluids into the containment berms, which was being wind-blown out of containment onto the location pad surface south of the AST.  Western Operating personnel responded immediately to the release by shutting in the well production and produced water gathering, and utilizing a hydro-vacuum truck to remove any fluids from within containment. Approximately 30 barrels of fluid was recovered from within the berms and surrounding area. Initial root cause investigation determined that the water process path was blocked by an unknown cause, resulting in produced water backing up into the oil ASTs, causing excess of fluids and overflow of the storage tank.
properties.Root Cause: Following discovery of the release, it was noted by responding crew that the produced water dumpline/flowline from the Propst B-2 heater treater to the injection well tank was above maximum operating pressure at the time of the release, causing production water to back up into the crude oil process and into the crude oil above ground surface tank (AST). It is suspected that accumulating solids, waxes, or some unknown blockage restricted the flow in the dumpline causing the excess pressure condition. The volume of produced water in the AST caused LNAPL to float and overflow from the top of the AST and into secondary containment berms. Strong winds caused fluids escaping from the AST to be carried out of secondary containment and either misted into grassy areas east and south of the AST, or overran the containment berms and pooled along the access road. A pressure test on the dumpline was performed on 4/24/2024 which showed no integrity issues (see attached logs). A subsequent pressure test will be performed as soon as possible to demonstrate flowline integrity after the release.
properties.Preventative Measure: Western Operating proposes to flush the dumpline with either fresh water or hot oil as necessary to remove any potential restrictions or blockages in the line, and perform a subsequent pressure test to demonstrate flowline integrity. Dumpline surface riser connections, valves and joints will be evaluated for integrity and replaced as necessary. More frequent site inspections for Operations and Maintenance will be performed to monitor line pressures and production conditions. Furthermore, remote tank level sensors will be installed on all above ground storage tanks in the surrounding area which will notify emergency crews to respond to an impending overflow prior to a release occurring.

properties.Spill_Desc: On April 30, 2024, the operator identified a leak in the flowline to the N. PARACHUTE #EF06D L29 595 wellhead (API: 05-045-11643) through trending data. The well was shut in, and proper notifications were completed.
properties.Root Cause: On April 30, 2024, the operator identified a leak in the flowline to the N. PARACHUTE #EF06D L29 595 wellhead (API: 05-045-11643) through trending data and the well was promptly shut-in. Based on trending calculations, estimated release duration, produced liquid rate, hole size, and pressure data, it is estimated that approximately 3.5 bbls were released. The point of release was determined to be internal erosion/corrosion of the flowline at the second 90 from the wellhead in the 6 o’clock position.
properties.Preventative Measure: The damaged portion of flowline has been replaced, and flowlines are pressure tested on a routine basis.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release was discovered at the Raindance FD Off-Site #20-202HNX Facility.  An equipment failure led to a 36-bbl oil fluid release. Fluid was contained on-site and with-in the steel walled secondary containment structure with attached synthetic liner. No bedding material present within containment. Clean-up operations are underway.
properties.Root Cause: An investigation into the cause of the release is ongoing. Additional information will be included in subsequent form submittal.
properties.Preventative Measure: Pending completion of the release investigation a corrective action will be submitted on a subsequent form.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised oil dump line resulted in 8 gallons of oil to spill to the surface and a currently unknown volume to spill to the subsurface. A vac truck was immediately dispatched to remove the surface impacts. The compromised oil line is scheduled to be exposed and repaired. The line will be pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal under waste manifest. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. Due to the release being strictly crude oil, Bonanza requests to amend the sample analysis plan to include TPH (C6-C36) and Organics only.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised oil dump line resulted in 8 gallons of oil to spill to the surface and a currently unknown volume to spill to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Bonanza implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: Under ground dump line leak. Operator shut in line and isolated leak.
properties.Root Cause: Dumpline did not hold pressure during annual pressure test. Operator performing test saw gas venting behind separator. It is suspected that line did not fail until pressure was placed on line during test. No liquid surfaced. Upon excavation it was determined that first 90 after separator failed due to corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Flowline will be replaced utilizing upgraded materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: Lease operators discovered an underground flow line leak near the 13c well's wellhead.  Leak was discovered via steam coming from the ground where the associated flowline transitioned from below ground to above ground.  Well was de-energized and isolated. A repair crew and hydrovac has been scheduled for 5/9/2024 to daylight and repair the failed portion of piping.  Once the line has been repaired, an environmental assessment will be conducted along the open excavation.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause was determined to erosion corrosion at the first underground ninety degree elbow downstream of the wellhead.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed portion of flowline was replaced.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water dump line resulted in 8 bbls of fluid to spill to the surface and an unknown volume to spill to the subsurface.  A vac truck was immediately dispatched to begin cleanup of the surface impacts. The line is scheduled to be exposed and repaired. The line will be pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. A waste characterization soil sample was collected and analytical results will be provided on a supplemental form.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water dump line resulted in 8 bbls of fluid to spill to the surface and an unknown volume to spill to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Bonanza implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release was discovered on 5/10/24 at the Kortum LD Pad. An unknown volume of oil/water mix was discovered to have daylighted off location due to a flowline failure. All flowlines associated with the facility were immediately isolated and shut in upon discovery. Clean-up and repair operations are complete.
properties.Root Cause: A pinhole leak due to microbial induced corrosion caused Spill/Release Point ID: 486742. The release point was located at a transition point from straight pipe to an elbow along the weld.
properties.Preventative Measure: PDC conducts annual integrity tests on all production lines. Further, PDC uses a chemical corrosion inhibitor to mitigate corrosion within lines. Samples of the chemical will be collected and analyzed on a regular basis to determine the effectiveness of the chemical. Based on the results of the samples the chemical corrosion inhibitor solution can be adjusted to meet the needs of the specific infrastructure that it is in contact with in order to prevent this issue from reoccurring.

properties.Spill_Desc: Dumpline pressure test failure.
properties.Root Cause: Internal corrosion of the short-radius ninety degree fitting on the carbon steel dumpline.
properties.Preventative Measure: Caerus will replace the short-radius ninety degree fitting with a long-radius ninety degree fitting to prevent reoccurrence of this incident.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 5/17/2024 an equipment failure at the Mustang recycle tank caused 50 BBL of recycled produced water to release outside of containment and 50 BBL within containment. Site investigation commenced on 5/17/2024 and a Waste Characterization sample, WC01, was collected. Additionally, all standing fluid was removed via hydro vac on 5/17/2024 followed immediately by the removal of contaminated dirt via excavation. A total of 89 confirmation soil samples were collected between 5/17/2024 and 7/10/2024 and submitted to Summit Scientific Inc. in Golden, CO for full analysis of Table 915-1 constituents. Analytical results are included in the attached Remedial Excavation Report. A Supplemental Site Investigation (SSI) will be completed to delineate pH, EC, SAR and boron. Final delineation operations are underway.
properties.Root Cause: On 5/17/2024 a manifold on the static mixer line, which transports recycled water mixed with treatment chemicals, failed. Prior to the release, the operations crew noticed that the line was having pressure issues. In attempt to fix the pressure issues, the crew torqued down the manifold; however, the line was over torqued and broke under the added pressure.
properties.Preventative Measure: Upon investigating the cause of the release, Noble discovered that the PVC on the manifold of the static mixer line is not rated high enough for the pressure and torque that was applied to it. In order to prevent a release from reoccurring due to pressure issues, the manifold was replaced with stainless steel rated for pressures well beyond that which will be applied to it during all operations. Additionally, the line is injected with corrosion inhibitor to prevent it from corroding. Further, Noble's recycle water department reconstructed the containment area to contain all sections of the treatment system that have connecting units.

properties.Spill_Desc: Oil was observed coming out at the ground surface on 05/21/2024 at 12 pm by a 3rd party employed by Oxy Petroleum. The surface staining was approximately 36 square feet (6'x6'). KPK immediately isolated the line, shut-in the wells feeding the line and has initiated excavation activities. Impacted soil is being transported to Frontrange Landfill for disposal.
properties.Root Cause: Oxy personnel noticed leaking oil at the surface above the flowline and reported it to KPK. KPK immediately shut in the well, vacuumed the line using a vac truck, and called in an 811 emergency locate. The cause of the spill was determined to be internal corrosion at the 1 o'clock position on the 2.5-inch steel pipe going eastward to the header at the joint next to where the steel line had previously been connected to plastic pipe coming from the wellhead to the west. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are age, hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK is systematically replacing steel flowlines with poly pipe to eliminate future corrosion of the flowline throughout the field. Poly pipe does not corrode and is compatible with the materials KPK produces. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing plastic pipe for connection. KPK typically slips this poly pipe inside the existing steel flowline to provide additional benefits/functionality going forward such as: secondary containment; protection from physical damage by subsequent subsurface digging; and provide the ability to use magnetic locating equipment to identify the flowline location.   At this spill point, KPK is excavating the steel 2.5-inch flowline from the joint with plastic and replacing the flowline eastward all the way to the header. This will prevent any future corrosion issues on this flowline. The pre-existing polypipe coming from the wellhead to the west is believed to be poly beneath the adjacent stormwater ditch and fiberglass to the wellhead.  KPK has developed and submitted a comprehensive Flowline Integrity Management Plan in collaboration and multiple reviews/edits with the ECMC Flowline Integrity Group (attached herein). KPK follows this plan to maintain flowline integrity and employs flowline replacement as the primary preventative measure. For risk mitigation and the elimination of threats to flowline integrity, KPK refers to API Recommended Practice 1160, Section 10. KPK also contracted Multi-Chem® to conduct an analysis of chemical contributors to corrosion on steel flowlines. The recommendation going forward was to inject a biocide in the separator for sites with steel flowlines to mitigate microbial corrosive action where microbial activity may be a contributing factor. KPK employs this biocide application procedure on a site by site basis at locations where pipeline replacement using HDPE is not possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 6/3/2024 at approximately 7:30, a Caerus site operator noted a failed pressure gauge on a 4" produced water discharge line at the PCU 23-18 Facility. The failed gauge resulted in the release of produced water onto pad surface. The water pooled and flowed a shot distance offsite. The line was shut in and the gauge was replaced. A hydro-vacuum was deployed to recover liquid and wet soil from around the POR and off location. Initial investigation soil samples were also collected.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause was a failure of a pressure gauge attached to a line conveying produced water.
properties.Preventative Measure: The pressure gauge was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 6/5/2024 at approximately 15:00, a Caerus LDAR Technician was inspecting the P27 595 location and noted gas coming to surface above the flowlines. Pressure testing was conducted and a leak was confirmed on the 1D-34 flowline near the wellhead. The flowline was isolated and blown down.
properties.Root Cause: On June 5, 2024, the operator identified a leak in the P27-596 (1D-34) flowline near the wellhead (API: 05-045-20324) through pressure testing and the well was promptly shut-in. The point of release was determined to be internal erosion/corrosion of the flowline at the second 90° fitting from the wellhead in the 6 o’clock position.
properties.Preventative Measure: The damaged portion of flowline has been replaced, and flowlines are pressure tested on a routine basis.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 6/11/2024 at 2:30PM a KPK pumper noticed oil rising to the surface along the flowline. KPK immediately isolated the flowline, shut in the well, and evacuated all liquids from the line via hydrovac mounted on a trailer. KPK contained the spill and began scraping up soil and excavating impacted soil from the subsurface. Impacted soil has been transported to Buffalo Ridge Landfill.
properties.Root Cause: For reasons unknown to KPK, the prior operator placed a 15 foot section of 3'' poly from the wellhead heading southwest along the flowline followed by a 10 foot section of 3'' steel, then converted to 3" fiberglass southward to the header at the consolidated flowline. The cause of failure was due to external corrosion at the 6 o'clock position on the 10 foot long section of the 3'' steel flowline. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: The 3'' section of steel flowline and the section of 3'' poly line has been removed and replaced with approximately 25 feet of 3'' fiberglass to have the flowline consist of uniform material and prevent future corrosion.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator discovered flowline failure.  Operator isolated the line, shut-in the well and call OCC.
properties.Root Cause: The flowline release occurred due to internal corrosion of the short-radius ninety degree fitting.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline fitting will be replaced with a long radius ninety degree fitting to prevent reoccurrence of the incident.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator noticed an underground flowline leak. The operator shut in the well and isolated the flowline. Upon excavation of the point of release, it was determined that the flowline has failed at the first 90 from the wellhead.
properties.Root Cause: Operator noticed an underground flowline leak. The operator shut in the well and isolated the flowline. Upon excavation of the point of release, it was determined that the flowline has failed at the first 90 from the wellhead due to internal erosion/corrossion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The flowline will be prepared with extra heavy fittings and the chemical treatment program is being evaluated. Pressure testing will continue on at least and annual basis.

properties.Spill_Desc: During a routine LDAR inspection, a small amount of gas was seen escaping from the surface where a lateral is buried. The line was immediately isolated and blown down. Crews are excavating to find the cause of the leak.
properties.Root Cause: Buried 6 inch lateral found to be leaking due to corrosion. Buried piping was not coated and had not been taped properly during installation, had been buried for approximately 50 years.
properties.Preventative Measure: Approximately 20' of 6" line has been replaced. Replacement line was coated as well as primed and properly taped at both ends. Welds on pipe replacement were x-rayed with no issues. This lateral also has cathodic protection.

properties.Spill_Desc: During normal review of locations, a lease operator discovered fluids flowing down the southern roadside ditch between the PCU T87X-3G and PCU T75X-3G locations. Emergency response operations were immediately initiated and the combined liquids line was isolated. Lease operators followed the spill path down until it terminated which is about 277 feet southwest of the road surface in a dry wash. A third party blade, backhoe, two hydrovacs, and a hand crew were dispatched to the spill path. The blade pulled impacted soil from the borrow ditch/roadside ditch and the backhoe began scooping it up and stockpiling it on the PCU T87X-3G pad location (ECMC Location ID 335796) within a bermed containment area. The two hydrovacs began removing impacted soil at the failure point where the fluid daylighted and from where the fluid left the roadside ditch via a ditch relief diversion channel.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause was determined to be internal corrosion of a straight piece of pipe.  Please see maps and photos attached to ECMC Documents 403845689 and 403850532 for more info on the failure point.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed potion of pipe was replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: On July 3, 2024, TEP production personnel discovered a produced water line leak within a pipeline ROW where the line makes an approximate 90-degree turn in direction.  Immediate response actions implemented by TEP include:  1) The source of the spill was immediately stopped (pipeline was shut-in).  2)  Absorbent spill booms were deployed in the stream along the area where fluids entered the stream.  Booms were also deployed across the channel at multiple locations downstream of the point of entry.  3) Water samples were collected from up-gradient, on-site, and down-gradient locations to determine potential impacts to baseline water quality conditions.  4) TEP notified and met with the surface owner representative on-site to discuss plans for remediation.  5) Impacted soils were excavated and removed from the impacted area and are temporarily stockpiled on-site pending completion of remedial activities.  6) Sediment control barriers installed around disturbance.
properties.Root Cause: Leaking flexline on a buried intermittent produced water transfer line at a section that makes a 90 degree turn in direction.
properties.Preventative Measure: Continue with routine inspections and testing to identify potential leaks within the buried line systems.

properties.Operator Name: UTAH GAS OP LTD DBA UTAH GAS CORP
properties.Spill_Desc: At approximately 9:30am on 7/6/2024, landowner called UGC personnel to respond to a spill/release which daylighted from the subsurface on their property. UGC field personnel immediately responded to the spill, and shut in the Hill 9-31 well, which produces into the affected pipeline. UGC personnel then contacted local hydrovac company to remove spilled oil/produced water mixture from the surface. The hydrovac company (Badger Daylighting), will remove all surface impacts by the end of the day 7/6/2024.  Additional spill/release information is located on the attached report.
properties.Root Cause: The pipeline transferring produced liquids from the Hill 9-31 well pad to the associated tank facility failed on Saturday, July 6th. After excavating and inspecting the affected line, UGC has determined corrosion of the line to be the root cause of this spill/release. The point of failure on the pipeline occurred at a depth of 5.5ft below the surface at the three o'clock position on the east side of the pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: UGC has removed the affected segment of pipeline, and replaced it with a new segment of pipe.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator arrived on location per normal daily routine and observed water percolating at a riser along the 6” Water Discharge Line on the working surface of the J25 CDP. Line is shut-in, hydro vac pulled standing fluids and operator is now having the line day-lighted at the riser.
properties.Root Cause: The produced water release was due to corrosion of the pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: QB Energy plans to abandon the below ground sections of the pipeline at the J25 CDP facility and will replace it with above ground sections of pipeline at the facility.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised fitting inside the Hawkins 5-61-20-4033B2 separator cabinet resulted in 2 bbls of oil to spill. The spill was contained entirely on pad and a hydrovac was dispatched immediately to begin cleanup. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Due to the release being strictly crude oil, Highpoint requests to amend the sampling and analysis plan to include TPH (C6-C36) and Organics only.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised fitting inside the Hawkins 5-61-20-4033B2 separator cabinet resulted in 2 bbls of oil to spill.
properties.Preventative Measure: Lease operators are coached to conduct routine AVO inspections at all oil and gas locations. If components appear to be worn or damaged, they should be replaced immediately.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 7/16/24, an independent bypass line became compromised during pressure testing activities. Fresh water was used to conduct the pressure test; however, residual crude oil in the line mixed with the fresh water and daylighted to the surface. An estimated 0.32 BBL fresh water/oil mix was released. Impacted soil was excavated using hydrovacs. Approximately 12 cubic yards of impacted soil were removed and transported to Republic Services Tower Road Landfill for disposal.
properties.Root Cause: An independent bypass line failed during pressure testing activities.
properties.Preventative Measure: PDC pressure tests lines as a preventative measure. The line was being pressure tested to ensure that it could withstand normal operations when it became compromised. In order to prevent this issue from reoccurring PDC replaced the old Schedule 40 piping with Schedule 80 3" coated and fusion bonded material.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK promptly responded to a notification from the Fort Lupton Fire Department regarding a release. KPK took action to shut in wells and call in an emergency locate. The team then proceeded to mitigate surface impacts by directly loading them into a dump truck for proper disposal at an authorized landfill. Additional investigation is necessary to determine the cause of failure of the steel Consolidation Line.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause is external corrosion at the 6 o'clock position. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK is systematically replacing steel flowlines with poly pipe to eliminate future corrosion of the flowline throughout the field. Poly pipe does not corrode and is compatible with the materials KPK produces. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing plastic pipe for connection. KPK slips this poly pipe inside the existing steel flowline to provide additional benefits/functionality going forward such as: secondary containment; protection from physical damage by subsequent subsurface digging; and provide the ability to use magnetic locating equipment to identify the flowline location. KPK follows this plan to maintain flowline integrity and employs flowline replacement as the primary preventative measure.  KPK has contracted Multi-Chem® to conduct an analysis of chemical contributors to corrosion on steel flowlines. The conclusion was that corrosion inhibitor was not needed and the recommendation going forward was to inject a biocide into separators to mitigate microbial corrosive action where microbial activity may be a contributing factor. Multi-Chem® also concluded that KPK should inject a paraffin inhibitor into specific wells within the system depending on need. KPK injects paraffin into a select list of wells as monitored and recorded by the production team. KPK employs this biocide application procedure on a site by site basis at locations where pipeline replacement using HDPE is not possible.  In addition, KPK conducts annual flowline pressure testing for all flowlines at the same time as bradenhead testing to document integrity and prevent future releases. KPK utilizes a boreal laser for pipeline inspection annually at all major producing facilities and associated flowlines.  Biocide is also used to prevent corrosion and is placed into separators prior to first time startup of new equipment and subsequent replacement and startup.

properties.Spill_Desc: Gathering line was being pressure tested and failed test. OCC was called and EH&S oncall was initiated. LDAR with OGI camera went to location to identify the release area. the area was found and the pipe line was isolated
properties.Root Cause: The root cause was corrosion of a straight piece of pipeline pipe.  Please see photos attached to ECMC Document 403935147 for more information of the specific locations.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed portions of pipe were replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK promptly responded to a notification from Butch with Occidental Petroleum regarding a line strike. KPK took action to shut in wells and call in an emergency locate. The team then proceeded to mitigate impacts. The cause of failure was a backhoe struck the buried KPK fiberglass pipe. KPK notified Occidental Petroleum of the line in that area.
properties.Root Cause: The failure of the KPK fiberglass pipe occurred when a backhoe struck the buried pipe, causing it to fail upon impact. Despite a KPK employee notifying Occidental Petroleum of the pipeline's presence, the Occidental Petroleum crew working in the area inadvertently struck the underground pipe, leading to damage. The root cause of the failure was determined to be the backhoe bucket striking the buried pipe during excavation activities. The fiberglass line could not be located precisely using standard locating equipment, however, KPK provided an estimated location within the proposed dig area.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK will update its map with submeter accuracy GPS coordinates of the uncovered flowline section to enhance the accuracy of predicting the location of the remaining flowline.

properties.Spill_Desc: The lease operator reported that the dumpline going from the separator to the tank battery failed the annual pressure test.  The well pad was shut in and proper reporting was completed.
properties.Root Cause: The incident was due to corrosion of the dumpline.
properties.Preventative Measure: The dumpline will be replaced with a dumpline composed of non-corrosive material.

properties.Spill_Desc: The lease operator was completing a pressure test on the 6" water pipeline from the H06 well pad.  The pressure test failed so the lease operator shut in the line and went to investigate, finding liquid had come to surface on the pipeline right of way.  The water pipeline was shut in and proper notifications were completed.
properties.Root Cause: The incident occurred due to internal corrosion of the pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: QB Energy is in the process of determining the future for this pipeline.  QB Energy will either abandon the pipeline or will replace the section of failed pipeline and will monitor and treat the pipeline on an increased frequency to ensure reoccurrence of the incident does not occur.

properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised produced water line resulted in 5 bbls of produced water to daylight and spill to the pad surface and an unknown volume to spill to the subsurface. The impacts were limited to the pad only and a vac truck was dispatched to begin cleanup of surface impacts and expose the compromised line. The line will be repaired and pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. The location is within 2024 Pronghorn Winter Concentration High Priority Habitat.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised produced water line resulted in 5 bbls of produced water to daylight and spill to the pad surface and an unknown volume to spill to the subsurface.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Highpoint implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: During investigation of the 6" water pipeline from H06 incident (CECMC Spill/Release Point ID 487351), an additional point of release was identified.  The line had already been shut in and the incident was reported to the CECMC.
Contractor noticed liquid on the surface. Notified the operator. The operator shut in the pipeline, notified EH&S on call.
properties.Root Cause: Internal pipe corrosion. 3 phase lateral line.
properties.Preventative Measure: Assessment underway.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 8/19/24 a KPK employee found contaminated soil at the ground surface and notified supervisors of the spill. Personnel immediately shut in wells and a crew was sent to perform source removal. The cause of the spill was due to a joint failure at the junction of 3'' fiberglass to 3'' steel line. KPK repaired the line by replacing the 3'' steel line section with a new 3'' fiberglass section. KPK began excavating and field screening the sidewalls. One source sample was collected and analyzed for full Table 915-1. More excavation at the southeast corner of the excavation is necessary. Groundwater is shallow at approximately 2' depth below ground surface.
properties.Root Cause: The cause of the spill was due to corrosion at the junction of 3'' fiberglass to 3'' steel line at the 6 o'clock position on the carbon steel line.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK repaired the line by replacing the failed 3'' steel flowline section with 3'' fiberglass. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing pipe for connection. KPK has developed and submitted a comprehensive Flowline Integrity Management Plan in collaboration and multiple reviews/edits with the ECMC Flowline Integrity Group. KPK follows this plan to maintain flowline integrity and employs flowline replacement as the primary preventative measure. For risk mitigation and the elimination of threats to flowline integrity, KPK refers to API Recommended Practice 1160, Section 10.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator was pressure testing line and noticed pressure was not holding. Isolated leak, shut in line and notified OCC.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause is most likely the corrosion of a ninety degree elbow where the dumpline transitions from below ground to above ground at the production separator.
properties.Preventative Measure: The elbow will be replaced.

properties.Spill_Desc: Once notified by the landowner on 8/23/24, KPK immediately isolated the underground line and shut-in the well supplying it. KPK has completed initial response activities by containing the spill and excavating contaminated soil that was then disposed of at a certified disposal facility. CPW was notified of the spill via email since it occurred within the buffer zone of the Bald Eagle Roost Site. The correspondence is included as an attachment.
properties.Root Cause: The 2'' steel flowline experienced a failure due to external corrosion at the 3 o'clock position. The cause of the failure was due to degradation of the flowline material over time. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing.
properties.Preventative Measure: The failed section was replaced with a new section of similar 2'' steel pipe. To prevent future external corrosion, the new steel section has been coated with corrosion protective pipe wrap and primer.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release occurred on 9/3/24 at the Ridgway 6N wellhead flowline riser. Upon initial inspection, PDC operator believed an unknown volume of crude oil/produced water mix had daylighted to the surface; however, after conducting a follow up investigation by PDC personnel and a third-party consultant, it was determined that the source of the release was an aboveground leaking flange. Based on release calculations, it was determined that the total release quantity was approximately 1 gallon. Clean-up operations via hand shovel have been completed. A waste characterization sample was collected on 9/3/2024 in the most densely impacted soil. Since then and all impacted material has been removed and properly disposed of.
properties.Root Cause: The threads of an aboveground fitting collar on the Ridgway 6N wellhead flowline riser corroded and began leaking on 9/3/2024. PDC's construction personnel dug down to 3' below ground surface in order to replace and weld the section of material with compromised threads and remove all impacted material.
properties.Preventative Measure: PDC replaced the compromised section with Schedule 160 steel as opposed to the previously used Schedule 80 steel. This new, stronger material will be able to withstand higher pressures and is less corrosive. Additionally, PDC will utilize a chemical corrosion inhibitor in effort to prevent corrosion from reoccurring. Upon replacing the compromised section, PDC hydrotested the line to ensure there were no other release points and there were not.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: A release was discovered due to a corrosion hole in a temporary produced water tank at the Land Fed 29-11HZ location. The volume of the release was approximately 165 barrels into a lined containment. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1.
properties.Root Cause: A release was discovered due to a corrosion hole in a temporary produced water tank at the Land Fed 29-11HZ location. The volume of the release was approximately 165 barrels into a lined containment. This release has been controlled and is no longer active. Assessment activities are ongoing.
properties.Preventative Measure: Routine maintenance checks of temporary storage tanks will be implemented with field personnel.

properties.Spill_Desc: During pressure testing with gas and a FLIR camera, a leak was detected on the H06 6 Inch Waterline on pad surface of the H06 396 just below the combustor.
properties.Root Cause: The incident occurred due to internal corrosion of the pipeline.
properties.Preventative Measure: QB Energy is in the process of determining the future needs for this pipeline.  QB Energy will either abandon the pipeline or will replace the section of failed pipeline and will monitor and treat the pipeline on an increased schedule to ensure reoccurrence of the incident does not occur.

properties.Spill_Desc: QB Energy initiated flyover by contractor potentially identified a gas release along the Starkey 2 Dehy Trunk Line/Starkey Gathering Line. LDAR Technician confirmed release. Line is shut-in.
properties.Root Cause: Upon excavation, internal corrosion was observed on the low point in the line where fluids could accumulate.
properties.Preventative Measure: The line was repaired with new material. The chemical treatment program is being evaluated.

properties.Spill_Desc: The weld on 6 to 4 schedule 160 reducer had cracked and failed on the flowline for the C5B wellhead.  Injection pump A was immediately turned off and master valve closed at pumphouse closed to stop flow to wellhead shed. NGL Operator then shut both valves on C5B wellhead, isolating the line for repairs. An NGL vac truck was dispatched to begin capturing standing fluid outside of pipe, there was 25 BBLS released outside containment that was not able to be recovered.
properties.Root Cause: The weld on 6 to 4 schedule 160 reducer had cracked and failed on the flowline for the C5B wellhead. Injection pump A was immediately turned off and master valve closed at pumphouse closed to stop flow to wellhead shed. NGL Operator then shut both valves on C5B wellhead, isolating the line for repairs. An NGL vac truck was dispatched to begin capturing standing fluid outside of pipe. The weld has been replaced on the steel line. Impacted soil has been excavated. The impacted area has been sampled and is currently being tested to verify all containments have been removed.
properties.Preventative Measure: The weld has been replaced on the steel line & successfully tested for integrity.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator found fluids surface near the tank battery, operator isolated dump lines and initiated EH&S call.
properties.Root Cause: Dump line failure on 90 degree elbow. Corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Dump line is set to be removed from service and replaced with an above ground replacement of upgraded material.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release occurred on 9/17/24 at the Gracie LD22. An unknown volume of crude oil/produced water daylighted to the surface from a separator dump line. Pressure testing confirmed that the release occurred at the dump line, however, the exact location and cause of the release is under investigation. A waste characterization sample, WC-01, was collected on 9/18. Clean-up operations are underway.
properties.Root Cause: Pressure testing on 9/17/2024 confirmed that the release occurred at the separator dump line, however, the exact location along the line and cause of the release is currently under investigation.
properties.Preventative Measure: Pending further investigation.

properties.Spill_Desc: A KPK employee driving by observed surface staining near a lease road and promptly notified supervisors, ensuring a swift response upon discovery. The surface staining was not easily visible to the pumpers on the standard route due to a surface depression and vegetation obscurring the view from the standard path. The KPK employee that identified the spill was an experienced supervisor that no longer works in the DJ Basin. He was in the area doing oil field maintenance work to cover for regular operations personnel.   In accordance with our protocols, the possible affected wells were shut in to prevent any further environmental impact. A crew was mobilized to initiate containment and remediation activities. Containment measures were established using berms and plastic liners to securely stage the stained soil pending offsite disposal.
