properties.Root Cause: KPK has determined that the point of failure occurred at the 6 o'clock position of a steel dresser sleeve on the 3'' fiberglass line. The cause of failure is due to internal corrosion. The operator prior to KPK had placed this sleeve over the fiberglass line. The root cause of this spill is due to inadequate repair measures employed on a fiberglass line by the prior operator of the flowline. Rather than placing a steel sleeve over the fiberglass, the entire section of compromised fiberglass line should have been replaced with new fiberglass and manufacturer's recommended fiberglass fusing technology at each end of the new section.  There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of this incident, the steel sleeve should have never been used as a repair alternative due to propensity for future corrosion. These sleeves are not meant for permanent repair on flowlines.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK plans to replace the failed section of flowline with 3'' fiberglass. KPK will fuse each end of the replacement section to the existing fiberglass flowline using manufacturer's recommended protocols.

properties.Spill_Desc: During normal operations, a leak was discovered on a surface line. The location was shut in and repairs were scheduled. Estimate 3bbls of produced water was lost on working surface. A water truck was on site during leak and recovered what was possible. Total #s will be displayed once received from operators.
properties.Root Cause: 1-13 is our primary UIC in the south operations, the line that failed had corrosion in the carbon steel. (Awaiting pictures of failure point under clamp on first round of pictures).
properties.Preventative Measure: The carbon steel line was replaced with 6" DR7 poly that will not corrode.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK received notification from Phillips 66 on 9/28/24 that there was surface staining visible along the Facility 5 @ 42 Pan Am E Consolidation Line. KPK responded immediately on site by closing the valves, shutting in the lines, depressurizing the system, and scraping the 2'x3' surface staining to contain the release. On 9/30/24 KPK began using a hydrovac to expose the line and remove free product from the soil.  KPK has exposed the flowline and we have excavated most of the impacted soil using a backhoe.  Additional excavation is needed and in progress.  Though not indicated in the section below. KPK notificed Weld County OEM on 9/30/2024 via webform.
properties.Root Cause: The spill was caused by internal corrosion in the 10'' steel pipe at the 3 o'clock position. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are age, hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: The 10'' steel line is being stung with 4'' poly pipe. KPK is systematically replacing steel flowlines with poly pipe to eliminate future corrosion of the flowline throughout the field. Poly pipe does not corrode and is compatible with the materials KPK produces. This flowline replacement occurs at the leak point and typically goes in both directions of the flowline for many hundreds of feet to the closest section of existing plastic pipe for connection. KPK slips this poly pipe inside the existing steel flowline to provide additional benefits/functionality going forward such as: secondary containment; protection from physical damage by subsequent subsurface digging; and provide the ability to use magnetic locating equipment to identify the flowline location.  For risk mitigation and the elimination of threats to flowline integrity, KPK refers to API Recommended Practice 1160, Section 10. KPK also contracted Multi-Chem® to conduct an analysis of chemical contributors to corrosion on steel flowlines. The recommendation going forward was to inject a biocide in the separator for sites with steel flowlines to mitigate microbial corrosive action where microbial activity may be a contributing factor. KPK employs this biocide application procedure on a site by site basis at locations where pipeline replacement using HDPE is not possible.

properties.Spill_Desc: During pressure testing by air, Laramie's 4" produced water line had a failure. Once the failure was noted on gauges, the test was stopped. It was discovered by Logan Wash road where the hole had free standing fluid. Water hauling company was called to recover fluids. TBD on fluid amount estimate 25 - 35bbls lost that was residual within the line during pressure test. Initial findings of failed line look to be a kink that was weak part. More details to follow on SF19s
properties.Root Cause: Appears from installation that there was a kink in the line is failure point resulting in the rupture. To make the corner, Laramie assumes that they bent line in or/during backfill the line was manipulated in a way to kink.
properties.Preventative Measure: Lines will be re-installed per best practices with competent contractors and inspect lines prior to any testing and burial. During repair, line will be place in with less of a angle to avoid any wrongful placement and during backfill after spill cleanup, line will be monitored so no excess dirt moves line out of alignment.

properties.Spill_Desc: A pinhole leak in a below ground produced water line resulted in 7 bbls of produced water to daylight to the surface and a currently unknown volume to spill beneath the surface. A hydrovac was immediately dispatched to begin the surface cleanup and expose the produced water line. The damaged line will be repaired and pressure tested prior to returning to service. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. A waste characterization sample was collected from the area immediately impacted and submitted for Table 915 analysis. Analytical results will be provided on a supplemental Form 19.
properties.Root Cause: A pinhole leak in a below ground produced water line resulted in 7 bbls of produced water to daylight to the surface and a currently unknown volume to spill beneath the surface.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Highpoint implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: During routine trending of production data, a drop in pressure associated with the 5B-22 well's flowline was observed.  The line was isolated and de-energized.
During pressure testing of Water transfer system line, a rupture occurred resulting in release.
properties.Root Cause: During pressure testing of Cascade 4" produced water line; a rupture occurred. Once the failure was noted on pressure gauges, the test was stopped. Water hauling company was contracted to removed free fluid where 30 bbls was recovered. Point of failure was within ROW near access road (39.466556/-108.243791) During inspection of line, it appears to have been struck at some point. This would weaken the line resulting in the failure point.
properties.Preventative Measure: Part for repair on order. Lines will be re-installed per best practices with competent contractors and inspect lines prior to any testing and burial. During repair, line will be place in with less of a angle to avoid any wrongful placement and during backfill after spill cleanup, line will be monitored so no excess dirt moves line out of alignment.

properties.Operator Name: KERR MCGEE OIL & GAS ONSHORE LP
properties.Spill_Desc: On October 22, 2024, approximately 20 barrels of E&P exempt liquid condensate was released to the surface at the inlet pipeline header at the Dougan Compressor Station. The release was stopped and contained inside the compressor station of which Western Midstream is the landowner. The release is under investigation and further detail will be provided in a supplemental report. The topographic Site Location Map showing the geographic setting of the release is provided as Figure 1. The State Notification email is provided as Attachment B.
properties.Root Cause: A release was discovered following the discovery of condensate spilling onto the surface at the Dougan Compressor Station location, beneath the inlet air gap pipeline. Cleanup, site assessment, and site investigation activities into the root cause of this release are currently ongoing and will be summarized in a forthcoming Supplemental Form 19 Spill/Release Report.
properties.Preventative Measure: The affected infrastructure has been removed and taken out of service.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK pumper noted stained soil surrounding a separator at the Jeffers-Hart tank battery. KPK immediately shut in wells and isolated the line to prevent further contamination while addressing surface impacts. The spill has been contained at the time of reporting. The oil dump line from the separator to the oil tank failed. KPK is in the process of exposing the line to determine the cause of the line failure. Details of the cause of the spill will be included on the form 19 supplemental.
properties.Root Cause: The root cause of the failure to the 3'' steel riser was due to external corrosion that occurred at the 12 o'clock position. There are many causes of corrosion in buried steel lines including (but not limited to): age; insulation failure; low pH; hard water; water temperature; microorganisms; chemical and electrochemical reactions; soil type and quality; chlorides; pressure; and/or oxygenated water. In most cases of both internal and external corrosion, more than one of these factors contribute. Every site has the potential for a different combination of contributing factors. In the case of KPKs flowlines and consolidated flowlines, the most common contributing factors are hard water, chemical and electrochemical reactions; microbial conditions, chlorides, and insulation failure. Determining specific causes of corrosion at a single site requires many chemical and physical parameter investigations and testing. It is not practical nor appropriate to conduct such investigations at every release site, especially when KPKs preventive measures employed following the identification of a corrosion root cause eliminates corrosion as a future potential.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK replaced the 3'' steel riser with a new riser with the same size and type of material. Pressure testing along the remaining buried dump lines was also performed and no additional leaks were noted.

properties.Spill_Desc: A release occurred on 10/19/24 at the Jacobucci 1 Tank Battery. Approximately 2 BBL of crude oil released inside containment when a produced water vault overfilled. Excavation operations reached 10 CY of impacted material removed as of 11/4/2024 making this release reportable. Tanks and liner within the release extent have been removed for remediation operations.
properties.Root Cause: On 10/19/2024 the separator crude oil dump line became plugged with paraffin as a result of cold temperatures. Fluids were  consequently routed through the water line and crude oil was dumped into the produced water vault causing it to overflow.
properties.Preventative Measure: The produced water vault automation is only registered to read water. PDC is evaluating several preventative measures in effort to  prevent this issue from reoccurring. One measure would be to install a kill switch in the produced water vaults to sense both water  and oil. Another preventative measure would be to regularly hot oil the crude oil dump line to prevent paraffin from forming and accumulating in the line.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release occurred on 11/16/24 at the 70 Ranch State BB17 Econode. An unknown volume of crude oil/produced water daylighted to the surface from a corroded combined fluids dump line. Clean-up and repair operations are underway. A site investigation was conducted and a waste characterization sample was collected on 11/18/2024.
properties.Root Cause: On 11/16/2024, a pinhole leak in the 70 Ranch State BB17 Econode combined fluids dump line formed due to microbial induced  corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Noble conducts annual integrity tests on all production lines. Further, Noble uses a chemical corrosion inhibitor to mitigate corrosion  within lines. Samples of the chemical can be collected and analyzed to determine the effectiveness of the chemical. Based on the  results of the samples the chemical corrosion inhibitor solution can be adjusted to meet the needs of the specific infrastructure that it  is in contact with in order to prevent this issue from reoccurring.

properties.Spill_Desc: KPK was called by OXY regarding a spill caused by a line strike by an Oxy roustabout crew (Naill Services) on 11/19/24 at approximately 9 am. KPK informed the OXY crew prior to digging that our flowline was constructed of fiberglass and that it was located within the area of Oxy’s planned dig. The locate ticket number is B43001075-00B. KPK marked the line on 11/4/2024 from the ticket request made on 10/31/2024. The Oxy crew was using a hydrovac to excavate due to the close proximity of KPK’s line. While the Oxy crew was using the hydrovac, the stinger probe hit the fiberglass line and caused the fiberglass pipe to crack. Oil was released into the hydrovac excavation and was observed coming out at the ground surface. KPK was called and crews mobilized to the site to shut-in the well and isolate the flowline. A vacuum truck was brought to the site to evacuate the flowline of all fluids.
properties.Root Cause: Oxy hydrovac operator was using probe tip too aggressively in a sensitive area with known fiberglass lines. Operator punctured the fiberglass line with the probe tip.
properties.Preventative Measure: From now own, KPK plans to blow down any fiberglass flow lines that area within 20 feet of a proposed dig area prior to allowing excavation operations to be initiated.

properties.Spill_Desc: Freeze at Hammer Union on above ground line, caused separation.
properties.Root Cause: Operator discovered an above ground Hammer Union had separated and Condensate had been released onto the working surface. The line was tied into the well dump lines. It was determined the Hammer Union separated due to a freeze in the line.
properties.Preventative Measure: This section of line removed form service. A valve allowed this section to be isolated.

properties.Spill_Desc: At approximately 8am on 11/28/2024, a release was discovered at the off-location flowline near the NWAU #12 tank battery. The flowline line was immediately shut in and spill was contained. Approximately 2-5bbls of oil and ~15-20 bbls of produced water was released. A hydrovac was called onto location to remove the surface fluids. Mull is coordinating with contractors to determine the caused the release at the flow-line and to make repairs. The flowline will be shut in until assessment and repair has been completed.
properties.Root Cause: The flowline which comes from the NWAU #12 and connects to the Tank Battery associated to the NWAU #11 (Location ID 321783) (flowline system segment Facility ID 482884) which located just east of County Road 45, broke due to being in a low spot at an intersection where multiple flowlines cross each other. Mull Field personnel identified rodents burrowing that may have compromised the soil around Hwy 45 leading to road flexing; additionally, it was identified that a top crossing water line may have added top pressure to the line ultimately leading to the line break.
properties.Preventative Measure: The Schedule 40 PVC 45* pipe was replaced with new 3” fiberglass 500# rating line from the road bore to the NWAU #12. Sackrete has been placed beneath to stabilize the line.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release occurred on 12/8/24 at the Raindance FD tank battery. Approximately 19.8 BBL of produced water released from a corroded load out line. The release was fully contained within poly lined containment with steel berm walls. Hydrovac operations are complete and all standing fluids have been removed. An investigation into the integrity of the liner was conducted on 12/9/2024 after all produced water had been removed from containment. Note that no pea gravel had been in containment. The liner was determined to be fully intact with no rips, tears or holes.
properties.Root Cause: On 12/8/2024, a Raindance tank battery load out line corroded between the tanks and pump.
properties.Preventative Measure: In order to prevent this issue from reoccurring, PDC has replaced the entire load out line with steel piping. Additionally, PDC uses a chemical corrosion inhibitor in all Raindance wells to mitigate corrosion within lines as produced water is highly corrosive. Samples of the chemical can be collected and analyzed to determine the effectiveness of the chemical. Based on the results of the samples the chemical corrosion inhibitor solution can be adjusted to meet the needs of the specific infrastructure that it is in contact with. Further, PDC conducts annual integrity tests on all facility lines.

properties.Operator Name: BONANZA CREEK ENERGY OPERATING COMPANY LLC
properties.Spill_Desc: A compromised dumpline riser resulted in approximately 11 bbls of fluid to spill to the pad surface. The spill was contained entirely on pad and a hydrovac was dispatched immediately to begin removing surface impacts. The impacted soil will be removed and hauled for disposal. Confirmation soil samples will be collected and submitted in compliance with ECMC Table 915-1. A waste characterization sample was collected of the most impacted material and submitted for Table 915 analysis. Analytical results will be provided on a supplemental form.
properties.Root Cause: A compromised dump line riser resulted in approximately 11 bbls of fluid to spill to the pad surface. The spill was contained entirely on pad and a hydrovac was dispatched immediately to remove surface impacts.
properties.Preventative Measure: In addition to routine AVO inspections, Bonanza implemented an upgraded integrity management program focusing on the reduction of internal corrosion related releases. This program includes increased pressure testing and preventative maintenance frequencies, installation of anodes and fluid detection kill switches on tanks and production vessels, and updating facility designs to utilize more corrosion resistant materials.

properties.Spill_Desc: On 12/10/24, a KPK employee noted staining at the surface along the Dwinell #4 flowline. KPK immediately shut in the well feeding the line and began cleanup measures by scraping the contaminated soil at the surface and excavating down to the flowline. Excavation is ongoing to ensure the removal of contaminated soil.
properties.Root Cause: The 3'' poly line failed due to the injection pump shutting off due to malfunction, which then caused the wells to shut off, leading to the contents within the 3'' poly line to freeze and split.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK has replaced the ruptured section of 3'' poly line with a new section of 3'' poly line and has begun repair of the injection pump.

properties.Spill_Desc: Around the same time the Dwinell #4 Flowline Spill was discovered on 12/10/24 approximately 5pm, a KPK employee noted staining at the surface at the flowline 3'' poly riser. The riser is an interchange water line between the Cody and Dwinell tank batteries. The riser failed due to malfunction of the injection pump which shut off and allowed the material in the line to freeze and split. The equipment connected to the line was shut in at the time of discovery and KPK has started scraping the stained soil at the surface. KPK has replaced the ruptured section of 3'' poly line with a new section of 3'' poly line and has buried the riser to prevent further exposure to the elements and freezing. KPK is now excavating contaminated soil and scraping the surface where impacts are observed.
properties.Root Cause: The riser failed due to the injection pump shutting off due to malfunction, which then caused the wells to shut off, leading to the contents within the 3'' poly line to freeze and split.
properties.Preventative Measure: KPK is in the process of repairing the injection pump that malfunctioned. KPK has replaced the ruptured section of 3'' poly line with a new section of 3'' poly line and has buried the riser to prevent further exposure to the elements and freezing.

properties.Spill_Desc: flowline between west well header and separator leaking under surface and .  well production shut in so leak has stopped.  investigation and cleanup under way.
properties.Root Cause: An underground wellhead flowline failed from a pinhole leak that caused liquid to come to surface.  The flowline pinhole failure occurred on the outside of the elbow (90 degree turn on flowline) at about 3 o’clock position on the pipe.  This pinhole leak was caused by internal CO2 corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: The section of pipe effected by corrosion was removed and replaced.  The wells utilizing this flowline and the other wells on this pad added continuous treatment with a corrosion inhibitor to minimize CO2 corrosion to the wells, downstream flowlines and equipment servicing those wells.  The flowline was pressure tested and passed prior to being returned to service.  See attached pressure test.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release occurred on 12/19/24 at the Waste Management Y11-28 facility. Approximately 2.88 BBL of produced water released from a corroded dump line outside of containment. Clean up and repair operations are complete.
properties.Root Cause: On 12/19/2024, produced water released from a corroded dump line on a separator at the Waste Management Y11-28 facility.
properties.Preventative Measure: Noble conducts annual integrity tests on all separator dump lines. Further, Noble will coat the replacement dump line with a chemical corrosion inhibitor to mitigate corrosion within lines. Samples of the chemical can be collected and analyzed on a regular basis to determine the effectiveness of the chemical. Based on the results of the samples, the chemical corrosion inhibitor solution can be adjusted to meet the needs of the specific infrastructure that it is in contact with in order to prevent this issue from reoccurring.

properties.Spill_Desc: Operator discovered an underground flowline leak. He shut in the well, isolated the leak and initiated EH&S on call.
properties.Root Cause: Buried flow line was compromised due to internal/external corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Point of release was exposed, verified, and repaired. Compromised section of line was removed and replaced with new upgraded material.

properties.Spill_Desc: A reportable release occurred on 12/9/2024 at the Grigsby AC19-62HN facility. An unknown volume of freshwater and residual produced fluids daylighted to the surface during a hydrostatic test of the flowline associated with the Grigsby PC AC #30-73HN wellhead. The exact location where the flowline is compromised is currently under investigation. The release has been controlled and clean up and repair operations are scheduled to begin 1/17/2025. The release area lies within the Mule Deer Severe Winter Range and Pronghorn Winter Concentration High Priority Habitats.
properties.Root Cause: This release occurred during a hydrostatic test of the flowline associated with the Grigsby PC AC #30-73HN wellhead. The exact location where the flowline is compromised is currently under investigation. The reason for failure is likely due to corrosion.
properties.Preventative Measure: Upon discovering the source of the release, the compromised section of flowline will be replaced with new material. Additionally, chevron conducts annual integrity tests on all production lines. Further, if corrosion is deemed to be the cause of the release, Chevron will evaluate the effectiveness of using a chemical corrosion inhibitor to mitigate corrosion within lines.
